cons:
The experience can vary based on your manager and I don't think there's a great way to coach and grow leaders that are not serving their team the best. 
There needs to be a tighter link between product feedback from customers small and large and product development. It's a hyper competitive market and they need to respond quicker to competition and customer asks.
advice_to_mgmt: Implement better feedback loops! You hire great people but pay attention to those managers that are not performing where you thought they would- I bet the signs form their team are coming in loud and clear. Overall my time at Dropbox was magical and it's a great place to work, learn and grow.

review_title: Great place to work, normal big company woes
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros: Big, successful tech company that makes money by selling a product rather than its users’ private data; product is beloved by many; practically limitless scope for career growth of individual contributors, without needing to transition to management; effective processes for high-level product and technical decision-making; great work/life balance; top-tier office and job perks.
cons: Reorgs are common and engineers tend to move teams a lot, reducing incentives to write maintainable code; aggressive internal deadlines add incentives to write unmaintainable code in order to ship quickly; issues are bounced around as teams refute “ownership” of the code in question; no strong company-wide standard of people management is in evidence, and managers’ aptitude for the job varies; career advancement seems to hinge more on following the letter of the leveling guidelines than actual job performance; NYC office gets next to no natural light.
advice_to_mgmt: Take people management more seriously as a skill; work with technical leadership to foster a stronger culture around code quality.

review_title: DON'T BOTHER WORKING HERE: RUTHLESS - ARROGANT - OUT OF TOUCH WITH REALITY
years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time
pros: Okay pay, decent benefits, great product
cons: Run by a bunch of arrogant kids that think they know it all. My manager had no social skills - when I first started and was in the process of moving from one state to another, I asked for two weeks to complete the moving process and his answer was "I don't get paid to resolve your housing arrangements." Then, I honestly filled out a survey and pointed out the lack of empowerment, when I pointed out the bad decisions he was making, he was up set and fired back with a new set of performance rules just for me. He manages a territory without having put foot in it, until recently and would not listen to advice.
advice_to_mgmt: Deliver what you preach: Truly care for employees, don't leave it up to managers that care more about their pride and not about DBX, protect your people when they speak their mind. Put someone that knows about the culture of a territory to manage it vs. an American that has no clue about the territory or the culture of the territory and is out of touch with reality, and arrogantly wants to impose his views in a different culture.

review_title: Don't Be Wooed by the Food
years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros: TuckShop serves up the best food in the Bay Area. Great benefits including health, dental, vision, commuter subsidy, cell phone, health/wellness subsidy, and more. Outside of work specialty events such as company picnic and holiday party were a blast. Great support teams for employee on-boarding. Fun work environment and great community of people to work around.
cons:
Don't let the food distract you from what is going on. I was merely hired as a diversity box to check. Upper level leadership states that diversity and inclusion are "important" and a "high-priority" but in researching the trends of POCs and women in the Dropbox workplace, you will see that there are major swings, not allowing for POCs to get comfortable in the workplace. You will also be paid less than your counterparts who are in the same role, with the same level of experience but display a less diverse demographic background. ERGs were great to find community in but that message needs to not only be a safe space to find community but it should mean something to upper level leadership. 

Dropbox promotes people into positions of power who have never lead a team before and who should never be allowed the opportunity to offer guidance to other human beings. There is zero intention behind the hiring and separation process which directly displays the patriarchal, "Boy's Club," stigma of the Bay Area Tech Industry.

If you want to make an impact here, I highly suggest knowing someone higher up and not deviating from their ideologies. New and differing ideas are not welcomed from my understanding.

There is also not a very clear direction that this product is heading in. There are multiple different value propositions, giving employees the feeling of having their hands in too many buckets at one time. There is also no clarity on who to turn to when trying to problem solve.
advice_to_mgmt: Be intentional about your hiring and promotion process. Often times length of service, age, traditional tech industry demographics, or technical acumen does not directly correlate to high quality leadership. Hiring people that are different from you may actually benefit the overall camaraderie of your organization and provide a higher ability to achieve greatness.

review_title: you will make a big impact here.
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
great culture (have been in tech ~6 years, best culture I've experienced thus far)

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
I've interviewed and all types of tech companies, from scrappy startups, to mid-stage post-PMF Series B startups, as well as most of the big name consumer tech companies. 

TLDR: Dropbox, by far, was for me the best candidate experience, and after I was hired, my onboarding was thoughtful, seamless, reasonably paced, and there were no culture shocks or surprises—everybody has been so kind; also, Dropbox has awesome values that put people first (both employees and users). 

+ The recruiter was exceptionally kind and thoughtful, as well as deeply knowledgeable about their area of focus. They were genuinely advocating for me every step of the interview process. 

+ The general approach and philosophy was assessing mutual fit, both for culture and for the technical aspects of the role I was applying for. It was explained that this was a conversation, and there was no rush to get me through the funnel. This was awesome because many other companies play the numbers game and just try to get people through. Dropbox's approach feels more human and respectful.

+ Every interview I met with throughout my interview process was engaging, enthusiastic, knowledgeable, and attentive. I've been in interviews at other companies where people are literally falling asleep in our 1:1 or on their phone during my presentation.

+ The documentation and resources are extensive and well organized. For new employees, there's a good balance between in-person instruction/coaching/onboarding and self-serve.

+ The benefits are outstanding. Probably some of the best in the industry.

+ Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion seems to be real here, and not just paid PR lip service.

+ Dropbox does seem to value work/life balance.

+ Dropbox has a clear leveling system with a clear career framework for assessing real business impact as a way to objectively promote employees.
cons:
+ Like all companies, Dropbox isn't a perfect machine, and every team is different. So, you should be prepared to come in with fresh eyes, get to know your team's strengths and weaknesses, and bring your expertise to bear on processes and collaboration.

+ I'm a new hire, so I'll need a few more months to get oriented.

review_title: The Best Company to Work For
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time
pros:
Company Benefits: commuter benefits, free food (amazing!), health care (paid for by company), events that get everyone together, gym (and wellness subsidies), unlimited vacation, I could go on!

cons: So why not 5 stars, you ask? Like others have mentioned, the company is growing, and with that come growing pains. They need to establish more processes to add the discipline needed with a big company. We don't want bureaucracy, but in big companies, unfortunately that's needed. We sometimes hire leaders that talk a big game, but when it comes down to it, don't know how to execute. So it's a matter of finding our pace.
advice_to_mgmt: Don't get blinded by "glitzzy" candidates. Look for style & substance. Don't be afraid to establish processes that will help us remain disciplined and accountable. Set a direction and stick to it.

review_title: Large Company with large company strengths and weaknesses
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time
pros:
Great benefits
Tuck Shop food is really good. The Wellness Benefit is large and you can use it on a very wide variety of equipment and services. Company matches donations up to a certain amount.

Work Environment 
Newish building with many different work areas. Day to day functions are well organized so that you have relatively little administrative unpleasantness. An awesome Dropstop on every floor takes care of IT needs promptly.

Pockets of Engineering Excellence 
Some parts of the engineering organization are strong: Magic Pocket, sync, and machine learning stand out. Hack Week lives on.

HelloSign Acquisition
The company may have realized that it is organizationally/culturally not equipped to grow organically and now seems willing to acquire for growth.
cons:
Weak Strategic Thinking
"Evolving" strategy as each year's strategy proved to not work. Each year's strategy is based on models of the industry where either the model is unconvincing or it is not at all clear why Dropbox's approach is the winning one.

Passive Aggressive Culture
People are always friendly face to face but beneath the veneer there is a lot of jockeying for power. Power distribution is evident when prizes projects get done by in power teams even though the area is theoretically another team's area of responsibility. People assign overflow tasks to other people even though they are responsible for it. People initially promise to do work and then shirk it without repercussions.

Politics
Ultimately unsuccessful projects were created and pushed out the door to get people promoted. Many people jump on board early on and generate immediately ridiculous shoddy user research to back up the work. Shallow technology is hyped as awesome and weak initial indicators are seen as good. Many of the promoted people still remain or get promoted even further up to do more damage.

Promotions are based on getting backing from managers and hopping on board initiatives that staff engineers or managers push. Each new set of staff engineers or managers disparages the work of the previous set and advocates for their own work. No one is willing to push back against what they say.

Levels are uneven with some staff or senior engineers/QA who are anything but that. Long time mediocre people are accumulating. Some title inflation for new hires.

The attempt to make the culture more innovative is not working because the people who enforce and benefit from the culture are all still in positions of power.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep on acquiring companies.

review_title: Losing their way and not scaling well
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
Food

-Work/life balance

-Benefits
-There are a lot of chances for ownership and a ton of work still to be done.

-The people are great. Dropbox is incredible at finding a diverse range of high quality people.

-Diversity.

-The company culture is very inclusive.

-Still has the feel of a much smaller company.
cons:
People are churning out very fast in the past 9-12mo.

-Busy work is rewarded. A lot of people put out a ton of "work", but very little has impact. The volume of work is often used by people to vouch for promotion, bonuses, or transfer to higher roles in other teams.

-Reorgs. The company has had 6 internal re-orgs on teams I have been on since I joined. Imagine working on a project for 6 months, getting everything in line and then leadership decides to do something completely different. This makes it super hard for many people to actually accomplish something start to finish.

-A lot of teams are made up mostly by people who come in through the Dropbox Rotation Program out of school. I find that these teams are highly tribal, not open to criticism, and often do not do very high quality work but know how to play the system very well.

-Peer review process is hit or miss and a lot is open to what feedback your managers choose to include. Moreover if you move to another team you can often be "re-leveled" and miss out on promotions or career path opportunities.

-Due to there being so much work to be in certain divisions, a lot of time is wasted on things that have minor impact. On one hand employees milk this because it makes them look like they do a ton of informative work, but on the other hand if you look at things from the big picture we learn slowly and can't scale ideas well.
advice_to_mgmt:
Stop reorganizing divisions every few months.

-Invest more in data quality and analytics..

-Stop letting relatively inexperienced or junior staff interview technical candidates with more experience. You miss out on so many amazing candidates because the interviewer is simply not on the candidate's skill or communication level.

-Tuck Shop is cool, but you should trend towards serving healthier options. It becomes patronizing after the initial awe wears off.

Our mission and product strive to create a more enlightened way of working and that is evident in all that we do. The people that work here at Dropbox are INCREDIBLE. review_title: Great product and people, but company hampered by slow execution
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time
pros:
Strong culture; nice, high-EQ coworkers across all teams; very little politics and infighting 
- Competitive compensation; nice perks (especially Tuck Shop food in SF office)
- Good product that has been adopted by a massive customer base; large market opportunity
cons:
Analysis paralysis; slow pace of decision making across many parts of the company
- Slow pace of execution; problem is especially acute in certain key teams at the company
- Talent quality across many teams has degraded significantly compared to a few years ago
advice_to_mgmt:
Senior leadership needs to provide much clearer direction for future of company - that means laying out not just some grand “vision” but an actual plan on how to get there
- Make major changes in certain teams that have consistently underperformed in the last few years

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
Benefits and pay are truly excellent. There are generous stipends for transit, wellness, learning and development (books and conferences), and others. Dental, vision, and health are all covered. There is donation matching up to a $1000 per year, unlimited volunteer and paid time off (which, if you're daring enough to request, truly seems unlimited—I have yet to hear of someone's PTO request being declined), and if you're in an office with a Tuck Shop, world-class food served every day. You can gift Dropbox space to friends and family.

The culture values kindness and open-mindedness to a fault, and teams are given massive autonomy to work and ship as they see fit. This means you can have very different experiences depending on your team and manager. This also means if you see something broken, you're generally given the OK to go and fix it if you have the will.

There are company events throughout the year, including team offsites (I've been hiking, on a cruise, to an escape room, and to countless dinners and happy hours), guest speakers, parties, etc. Dropbox seems to spare no expense on events and travel, although I've heard it was even more extravagant in the past.
cons:
Dropbox lies squarely in the "ruinous empathy" quadrant of business culture. Promotions are measured by the number of friends you make, not the results you achieve, which results in decision making by committee and projects that lag on for months at a time because nobody is willing to take ownership or say "no." At the same time, projects spanning 6+ months of research, design, and engineering can be derailed by the opinion of a single manager in the pursuit of "perfect" rather than "better".

Staff lack a clear vision for Dropbox. Milquetoast strategy updates and new opportunities receive endless bravado but when it comes to actual execution there's little follow-through. Meanwhile, the core Dropbox product continues to suffer from longstanding problems like convoluted sharing and horrendously slow performance.

We use Dropbox Paper, our own docs offering, for absolutely everything—from project management to calendaring to to-do lists to meeting notes. What results is total chaos. There is no sane way to organize docs, which get produced at an astounding rate: product managers regularly compose dozens of new Paper docs in any given week. There is no way we would organize ourselves this way if we weren't so committed to using and abusing our own tool.

Simple bugfixes languish in backlogs for months or years without resolution. Abysmal developer tools and nonexistent analytics slow the company to a crawl. 

We talk a big talk about "designing a more enlightened way of working" (corporate thinkpieces go up on the blog every few weeks) but how can we hope to improve work for others when our own house is a mess?

All these issues aren't new, and they're well-known to anyone who has been in the organization for longer than a year. We will talk about them and collectively agree they need to be addressed, but for whatever reason, nothing ever seems to happen.
advice_to_mgmt:
LEAD. Where are you? From down on the ground, seems like you've tapped out. Commit to a direction and see it through. Hold people accountable for results and set real deadlines. Fix the basics.

Standardize from the top down. We aren't a startup anymore, but we still act like one. We need standard platforms and processes across the org for project management, hard requirements for shipping, easily accessible analytics for *all* teams, and a continuous, direct line of communication with customer success so we understand the real problems that users are facing, not the problems we make up for our user personas to face.

Treat remote offices as first-class citizens. There's a lot of thrash that most likely goes unnoticed in SF. Check in to see how people are doing.

Pursue diversity more aggressively. And no, this doesn't mean just hiring more white women. We aren't doing well. Start with staff.

review_title: Great place to work, although company vision is lacking
years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros: Unbeatable perks and wellness benefits, food, people, etc. Compensation is one of the highest in silicon valley after Netflix which is in the middle of nowhere. High employee happiness and great work life balance. Focuses a lot on growth and career advancement. Company and management are very invested in employees and employee retention.
cons: Very young managers many of which who are ex-engineers. Many employees don't believe in the long term company vision. Company is struggling to differentiate itself from competitors.

years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time
pros: Culture, people, perks and benefits. GREAT work life balance despite people complaining.
cons: Slow decision making and entitled culture that does not produce as fast as it should.
advice_to_mgmt: You need to speed up, bring more products to market and show you are winning.

review_title: Some growing pains, but overall excellent place to work
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
Everyone who works here is super smart, humble and kind. The recruiting team has done a great job maintaining that culture as we've grown.

- The perks are insanely generous, especially the food served in the Tuck Shop.

- We're working on interesting problems and thinking critically and empathetically about how to improve the way people get work done

- Especially in the younger parts of the company, there's still a lot of opportunity to build teams/processes/etc from scratch. Could be frustrating if you'd rather have all that figured out already, but if you enjoy that challenge you'll be happy here.

- If you care about work/life balance, you can definitely find it here.
cons:
There's a lot of fear internally about breaking pieces of our business model or product or website that have traditionally worked well for the company, which stifles our own ability to take risks and innovate. 

- People are almost too nice, which had led to a culture where you need to get everyone's buy in before your project can move forward. This slows us down and also allows one person to block an entire project on a whim.
advice_to_mgmt:
Get serious about setting up processes that will help move work forward, faster. 

- Don't be afraid to put a stake in the ground with your vision for the future of our product. If we can't commit to points of view around industry innovations, we'll get trounced by competitors who can.

- Empower employees to take more risks. The lawyers shouldn't be the ones running the company.

review_title: Couldn't have made a better decision
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Smaller company, impact of my individual work is magnified. Collaboration between teams is amazing. The leads care about my growth and are providing learning opportunities on a everyday basis. The gym in SF is a perfect size. Only a 5 min walk from the train station. Work life balance is recognized by leadership.
cons: The food is too good

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
Great attention to the inner workings of all processes, and to the underlying needs of employees
- Transparency and candor around key business objectives and results
- Care about employee buy-in to company strategy and future
cons:
Atrocious treatment of lower-level talent. Frequent and poorly-executed management changes and poor resource allocation lead to burn out, lack of recognition, lack of strategic direction/support, and high attrition risk at lower IC levels.
- Too much talk too little action. So much time is spent discussing how to do work and how to be more efficient, but no decisions/actions/tangible or impactful changes are actually implemented.
- Lack of direct communication. Difficult questions aren't addressed nose -on and danced around, with a patronizing approach vs a 'lets find a better forum and talk this through' approach more appropriate for a smaller company.
advice_to_mgmt:
Focus on giving lower level employees more channels to resolve their concerns (they should not be at the mercy of their leads, with little opportunity for change)
- Be more direct in communication, even if it's not what employees want to hear (i.e. policy/approach toward CW conversions)

years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time
pros: innovative and upcoming if looking for excitement
cons: chaotic at times......because new

review_title: Political culture, constant re-orgs, not a great place to start your career

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time

review_title: Lots of Energy but Often Misdirected
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time
pros: Really smart, passionate people in all facets of the job. Food and soft benefits are fantastic and unrivaled by most other companies.
cons: Unfortunately, being in a crowded market requires us to make product bets that often turn out to be dead ends or put pressure on backend infrastructure.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year

cons: can be a bit chaotic. Still feels like a fast-moving culture despite the size, but this can make you miss the stability

review_title: Great company, not so great lower management
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
Amazing benefits
Flexibility to work from home
Smart people
Teammates feel like family
Relaxed/comfortable environment
Great product!!!
cons:
Weak lower/middle level management
Scattered processes
Inconsistent / biased performance reviews and ratings
Too much work about work
Some teams are very short-staffed
advice_to_mgmt:
I would love my job at Dropbox if I felt like my time was well spent on the job I was hired for, and if lower/middle level managers were stronger. Lack of strong team leadership from managers, being short-staffed, and going through ever-changing processes make work stressful and take away any possibility of going above and beyond with innovation. Putting out fires is the norm , and that makes me feel very uncomfortable and unmotivated at times. I don't feel like I'm growing in my career.

Overall Dropbox is an amazing company. I love the product, the C-level management team is fantastic, and I've met some great friends and coworkers. I hope processes improve and resourcing is more appropriately fitted to each group that needs support.

years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
A company that truly values its people. It's so rare to work in such a caring and kind environment. The group of folks that Dropbox recruits are innately collaborative and open-minded. I know that this culture has been maintained by the people in senior management and they have been cautious about adding the right talent.

I'm so glad to have been part of the team and look back fondly on my time spent there.
cons: Some career paths are not as developed as they should be. It would be great for more junior folks to have an idea of what their futures could look like.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the great visibility to employees in all offices. It was great getting color on how executive decisions are made.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Really strong engineering team. Teammates are curious and competent. I enjoy knowing that any random person I meet on a cross-functional project will generally be a pleasure to work with.

Plenty of big challenges to sink your teeth into. If you're up for the task, career growth has a stellar trajectory.

Work-life balance is excellent both on a weekly basis and regarding vacation. Unlimited vacation lives up to its claims here.
cons:
Managers frequently come from engineering which leads to uneven quality. This is both a cause and symptom of high churn at the lower levels of management -- bad if you subscribe to the idea that people work for good managers, not jobs. Let's just say that you should really like the job.

Lots of competitors in the space. Unfortunately the heavy hitters are closer to existential threats rather than healthy rivals.

While the core systems are robust, duplicated efforts, wildly changing technical strategy, and poor knowledge-sharing abound. The same kind of self-defeating chaos that politics would generate at a larger company arises here naturally due to ... dare I reuse that startup cliche ... growing pains.

Poor retirement matching.
advice_to_mgmt:
Control the quality of lower management more carefully.

Outline a stronger technical and product strategy with a time horizon of greater than a year. While it's nice that so many of our recent innovations have come out of random engineers hacking around, it does diminish confidence in leadership's ability to, you know, lead.

The recent rebranding, which appears to have been driven from the top down, makes my eyes bleed.

The core business has been and is doing well, so good job so far.

review_title: Overall great company to work for within the tech industry
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time

years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time for more than a year

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than 3 years

cons: The outbound sales org is in shambles! Senior and Middle Level Sales Managers are completely out of touch with reality and have sucked the Dropbox DNA out of the org. Note that I didn't use the word "Leaders" or "Leadership". Don't be fooled into thinking that they care about your success. Top performers are running away to other companies.
advice_to_mgmt:
Advice to Dropbox Executive Leadership. You are losing really great employees because of a handful of managers. 

"Employees don’t leave Companies, they leave Managers"

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:

years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros: Dropbox is a top-tier tech company with interesting challenges, great coworkers, and a nice environment to do it all in. The benefits are competitive.
cons: Incredibly uneven quality of low-level management. Some long-time engineers are allowed to interfere with any team or engineering project they like, and this has sometimes destroyed teams. Company culture is intolerant of political differences. Retirement plan is not at all competitive.
advice_to_mgmt: Don't hire engineers as managers. Don't promote engineers to management. Prevent managers from making engineering decisions.

years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time
pros: Great culture, smart people, and incredible perks/benefits.
cons: Dropbox waited too long to scale it's support structures which led to some growing pains.

review_title: Come and do the work you’re destined to
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
Dropbox can be an intimidating place - extremely smart & capable people, everyone moves fast, decisions happen quickly, tons of exciting work and projects to grab on to, but where to start…

Then it hits you. Dropbox has made it possible for you to come and do your life’s work. It’s a place where you can do and be what you want to be. The culture and atmosphere buzzes from excitement & innovation and exudes passion. 

They make everyday decisions easy & painless so you can focus on the work that matters. From the incredible free food to quality healthcare to unlimited vacation to an environment where you’re free to work from where and how you want worry-free (which includes work/life balance).

What you’re left with is the freedom and time to do the work you’re meant to do. And that’s when you graduate from intimidation to empowering.
cons:
Giving people the freedom to work how they want means dozens if not hundreds of ways of working. Email, meetings, slack, chat groups, wikis, paper docs, text, etc.

It can be easy to fall in the trap of doing stuff vs. doing what matters.
advice_to_mgmt: Encourage simplicity and free people from non-productive distractions (e.g. reply-all chains, documentation paralysis, etc.).

years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
Lots of perks - breakfast, lunch, dinner , $100/mo wellness benefit
Team events
cons:
Doesn't walk-the-walk, often provides lip service to real problems and concerns
Organizational structure and leadership is constantly shifting as are priorities of the different managers brought in.

review_title: Great company with good benefits but still figuring some things out
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time
pros: Wonderful people who are always willing to help each other out and teach colleagues, great perks at the SF office including an amazing corporate cafeteria, great opportunities to grow your career, volunteer time off, and company culture
cons: Managers can get overloaded, there is some lack of consistent processes in engineering, not a lot of women in infrastructure engineering, few mentor/mentee opportunities
advice_to_mgmt: Make sure managers are supported and have opportunities to train and improve.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time
pros: Really challenging work with a great team who are very self-aware, apolitical, and interested in improving the product, the world, and themselves.. Highly enlightened policies and excellent benefits. Really good work-life balance,
cons: San Francisco location can be challenging for the commute. Dropbox does sponsor a Caltrain Go Pass, which helps tremendously.
advice_to_mgmt: For scalability, the company will need to expand beyond San Francisco in a more significant way than it has done to date.

years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time
pros: I worked at Dropbox more than 3.5 years. Was great early on and had some amazing people. Lots of my friends were there and I felt it was a supportive place.
cons: The amazing people are gone. Didn't really see how I would grow there if I stayed. EPD sort of had things together by the time I left. The Operations part of the company world was very badly organized with lots of people churn.

review_title: Dropbox has a long way to go.
years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
The food is honestly one of the best parts about working at Dropbox. The culinary teams really go above and beyond almost every single day to serve up really unique and high quality dishes. 
- The office aesthetic is very cool and clean. Dropbox as a company is very design focused and it seems like they took that into account when designing their new office.
cons:
Cocky attitude about being a "small startup" that thinks they "made it" because they have fancy perks like the other big tech companies
- Work/life balance 
- Very little room to grow within certain teams
- Need a lot more process before they'll be successful for the long term
- Give managers (especially new managers!) much more training before taking on new reports and build teams
- Need to be more transparent in recruiting process into what job will actually involve
advice_to_mgmt: I would re-evaluate some of the lower-level managers you have running teams with very little experience, along with how the recruiting process is being managed. I was misled during the recruiting process and ended up being miserable in the job because I was oversold the role. The recruiting team specifically told me I would be doing certain things I was passionate about to "close" me when I was in the offer stage, and that's not a great way to close talent.

review_title: Wonderful, collaborative culture with awesome people and benefits
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than 3 years

cons: A bit too hierarchical - decisions take forever to get made, and execution can get hampered at the last minute by management
advice_to_mgmt: Trust your reports and enable them, don’t micro-manage them. Build vision!

review_title: Dropbox is a great place to work

Everyone is welcoming, and fully engaged, the business outlook is impressive, and the perks aren't too bad either (They are top notch!). In a sea full of tech companies and start-ups in the Bay Area, they are holding their own, and more people need to know about what a great place it is.

advice_to_mgmt: Increase visibility of the amazing work environment & culture.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than 3 years

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time

review_title: I can't recommend working here to my friends or family
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than 3 years
pros: The Tuck Shop serves great meals, the gym is nice, and so on so forth. The perks are the only real pro.
cons:
The best, most visionary leaders in Engineering have left and/or are in the process of leaving.

Drama is embraced.
People with real and meaningful experience are ignored routinely.
advice_to_mgmt: Stop letting middle managers play dumb political games, it's killing your company.

years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time
pros: Great food, lots of in-office perks, good team to work with
cons: Long hours, projects were at times redundant

years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
The engineering team is some of the best people to work with that I've ever met. The team isn't just smart people: the company does a great job of selecting people who will be able to work well with others. 

For an engineer, it's a fun place. They've got a range of really exciting technical problems to solve. And when you solve them, you get to see people actually use what you built.

The company is built as an actual business. The management has been carefully building a sustainable, long-term business. They provide a valuable service, which people are happy to pay for. They've got a good plan for how to continue and grow the business.
cons: Shocking amount of abandonware in the technical stack. Senior people are strongly encouraged to have side-projects in addition to their primary work. But they aren't given time to support it. So there's a lot of widely used code implemented by trusted people, but which is completely unsupported.
advice_to_mgmt:
* Cut down on the amount of political games among managers.
* Take a hard look at the what you reward. The current system is good in many ways, but it is encouraging people to build things and then abandon them.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros: Great Coworkers, office space and perks
cons:
GTM is a complete miss!, haven't had the same offer for more that a qtr, at a time.
Customer Service is a oxymoron.
Quotas are too high for the size of deals & discounts needed to win.
advice_to_mgmt: Scrub direct sales. Support CX, CS and Engineering, and just admit you are a personal & SMB solution at best.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time
pros: Great peers - smart, dedicated, helpful, considerate, rockstars.
cons: Middle management not trained well, they won't roll up sleeves to help and continues to dump busy work on the team. Systems and tools confusing with no manpower to fix issues and train sales force. Politics heavy and HR doesn't listen to what employees are saying. Beware "revenue operations & strategy" team - they don't operate or strategise.
advice_to_mgmt: Read these surveys you keep sending around, we've been waiting for you

years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time

advice_to_mgmt: Build out a more robust sales organization with more transparency.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than 3 years
pros: High impact projects affecting millions of users. The technical challenges are immense, and there are many interesting product problems to tackle as well.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros: Amazing culture, amazing leads, amazing food and benefits. People really care about you as a person and all seem to be enthusiastic about their work and the role they play in making it an awesome place to work.
cons: Not great career mapping within recruiting, as there doesn't seem to be a clear vision as to what the possibilities for ones career is. I do believe this is coming soon. The Global Head of Recruiting is learning on the job. They give an impression that they don't really care about technical recruiting and that we are just laborers working to hit a number so they can get a promotion and a bonus.
advice_to_mgmt: Don't avoid the Technical Recruiting side of the house. It honestly feels like you don't care at all, and I am not the only one that feels this way.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox part-time for more than a year
pros: It's a well known company that will look good on your resume when you leave, which you will want to do as soon as you start.
cons:
1) managers have no respect or concern for the welfare of their employees 
2) the product is a nightmare - it's coded like something 10 years ago and no one cares - they just want to sell this crap as quickly as possible to as many lemmings as they can find to increase their user count, which they think will drive up the IPO price
3) customer support? are you kidding me? What a nightmare. It's not just that it's impossible to get support - the customer service agents actively share what should be confidential files and information from a user account when that user writes in with a complaint. I have regularly seen protected information shared among staff members
4) you'd better be in the clique or else there is no opportunity for career advancement
advice_to_mgmt: pack it in. bigger and better cloud sharing services are already eating into your market share and the utter contempt and disdain you show for users and employees is going to come back and bite you.

advice_to_mgmt: Since no new ideas have come in 8 years. Think about hanging it up.

review_title: Lots of smart people to work with and learn from
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
Great place to work as product manager. Smart people to challenge your thinking if you are looking for constructive feedback. Dropbox gives PMs the opportunity to focus on why a problem is worth solving rather than just focus on churning out features.

It is at a great size where the PM team is large in the sense that there are a lot of great folks to learn from, but small enough that you will likely know all other PM's and can really scale your impact.

More importantly, the co-founders and the executive team really cares about broader issues such as diversity and respecting people from all background. Great perks when it comes to food, insurance, maternity/paternity, wellness etc.
cons: Will have to figure out a way to transition from a single product company to a successful multi product company for long term success.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time
pros: Strong cultural values, people have higher integrity than other tech companies I've seen, truly cares about investing in and caring for its employees.
cons: Tons of change all the time, lots of context switching, has trouble making important decisions quickly especially if they hurt feelings

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than 3 years

review_title: Reasonable place to work, huge product issues
years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time
pros:
* Lots of employee perks

* Beautiful office

* Amazing food

* Still a good chunk of smart people remaining at the company, though this is changing quickly

* Coworkers were really nice and generally had strong character
cons:
* Zero product direction -- CEO has had lots of trouble strategically and has effectively stepped back from that role, meaning that no one with power over multiple orgs is steering the company

* High-level goals dumped at the feet of inexperienced senior managers, who are then responsible for vague product goals ("more collaboration!") and can't translate them into a product roadmap

* Projects are often too safe, and amount to UI tweaks (a giant overhaul of the barely-used website, for example) or moonshot projects with no strategy or go-to market that eventually die before reaching customers

* A recent de-emphasis on business/sales objectives in favor of shiny consumer toys, despite major strategic pitfalls
advice_to_mgmt: Chart a course more concrete than "collaboration" or "the best place to get work done" -- something that directly translates into a product roadmap with a clear go-to market and value prop for customers. Put customer problems first and business problems second.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year

cons: Retention especially as the org continues to change and define itself. Need to do better job of managing org-wide changes
advice_to_mgmt: Preserve the culture at all costs

years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time

cons: Upper management brought in hordes of ineffective middle managers from Microsoft and Google to manage business teams in a misguided attempt to 'grow up' ahead of an expected IPO. These people were universally terrible at their jobs and are now in the process of being let go. People at Dropbox are also extremely nice, but usually not very effective.
advice_to_mgmt: Stop letting good people leave in favor of managers who produce literally zero benefit for the company.

review_title: Great Culture and Ready to Help Grow Your Career
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
cons: questions about valuation brought up last year;
advice_to_mgmt: keep being crisp about why Dropbox is better than the competition;

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
After having been a fan of the product itself and a long-time user, I was hopeful when I joined that they would live up to my very high expectations. So far I've been very pleasantly surprised to learn that the culture and environment is even better than I had expected. After having worked at several large tech companies in the area, I have realistic expectations when it comes to culture and work environment and often after seeing behind the curtains am disappointed with the results, however here I haven't seen anything that is popping that bubble. Even though we work in a satellite office (the HQ is in San Francisco) they are very careful to ensure that we maintain that environment that makes Dropbox special, as well as including everyone and being very transparent so that we don't end up feeling like a lonely island. 
*Benefits here are amazing (even compared with Microsoft, Facebook and the like)
*Perks include having a catered breakfast, lunch & dinner (if you are going to be working past 5) every day. If you are lucky enough to work in the SF office, then you have your own restaurant with options crafted by a Michelin star chef. We also have a fully stocked kitchen and full bar. We also have a lounge area complete with Xbox One & Sega (old school), full band set-up, pool table, foosball, ping pong table and lots of different working spaces for any kind of work environment requested. 
*Company founders are onsite and super accessible, they really do care about each and every employee and put a lot into everything.

The transparency here is amazing, and if you have an idea or want to try something new out, I've been met with "yes" every time. Which is amazing and can offer up unlimited career progression, just don't be afraid to get in and get your hands dirty and get 'er done.
cons: The only con I can find is the location, although we are in the Columbia Tower and the views are seriously the best in the city, I live on the Eastside and thus commute is a headache for me. Luckily we have a generous transportation benefits and a flexible work environment, so I can work from home as needed. The bus routes are the hardest part, trying to find one that will work with my schedule has needed a little work, but that's not really the fault of Dropbox.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to keep the transparency intact, that's a very important part of this culture and the success of the product itself, so it's great to have that to showcase. As we are still very much growing, and growing at a very fast pace, it's important to make sure that we continue to hire people who will maintain that uniqueness that keeps us at Unicorn status, I've seen cases where bringing in the wrong leadership can tank an entire product line, so that's my biggest worry at this point.

years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Super smart engineers
- Great product design team
- Fantastic perks and location
- The founders are down-to-earth and relatable
cons:
There is an ever-prevalent sense of entitlement throughout the engineering org
- Lack of basic social skills - people don't believe in greeting others in hallways
- Inexperienced and egoistic managers have caused a lot of damage and attrition in the past year
- If you are a person of color, you may not exist for the rest of them for a long time (I am not a person of color, but I noticed the bias against my colored co-workers)
- There still exists a boys club 
- Career growth and mentorship is limited
- Don't work at Dropbox if you are a Product Manager or want to become one in the near future. The attrition rate in PM org is huge and lack of mentorship is appalling. Lots of unhappy PMs.
advice_to_mgmt: Fix management issues, if you want you attract long-term experienced employees. Engineers have many options in the Silicon Valley, nobody wants to work for jerks!

years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox

review_title: Driven Culture, Nice and Friendly Environment, Room to Grow
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time
pros:
A great working environment with a warm, inviting, and friendly culture.
Opportunities to learn from others with a wide range of experiences 
Great brand name recognition
Strong perks and benefits
Off the charts food options
Leadership is very transparent regarding company direction and financials
Individual growth opportunties
cons: An excess of documentation on any number of topics. Streamlined and simple data can sometimes be tricky to locate
advice_to_mgmt:
Continue to provide transparent information on the direction of Dropbox and where we're going.
Do not try to grow just for the sake of growing.

years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Like many companies, Dropbox has amazing perks -- excellent food, really nice onsite gym, and there's no commute as it's located in SF. Most people at the company are nice, smart, humble, and hardworking, but the hiring bar has been lowered quite a bit over the last year. This is a great place to start your career if you're entry-level.
cons:
All that glitters isn't gold. Despite the glitz of the perks, many people at Dropbox are really unhappy. This is due to several things:
- Bad managers. Like, really bad. Very little training offered to new managers, and the company does not take action on managers who are consistently rated poorly or who have a lot of turnover on their team.
- Very little career development. If you're mid-to-senior level and you're looking for autonomy and responsibility, this is likely not the place for you.
- Dropbox is NOT a meritocracy. Many leveling and compensation decisions are based on favorites and are inconsistent from team to team, or level to level.
- Despite being a relatively small company, it's tough to get things done. Weighed down by red tape and bureaucracy. If you're someone who is execution-oriented and likes to move fast, look elsewhere.
advice_to_mgmt: Stick to the values and raise the hiring bar. Stop hiring and promoting bad managers. Train new managers, and get rid of the ones who aren't effective. Provide greater development and mentorship opportunities for people who want them. Hire a more seasoned and effective HR team. Be fair and consistent with compensation and leveling decisions.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time
pros:
Really smart, motivated people.
Very collaborative culture - people are always willing to help solve problems or answer questions.
Amazing office space and fantastic perks.
cons:
Growing pains as the company grows from a small, agile startup to something bigger that needs more process. 
Leadership can be hit or miss - some projects Dropbox executes on amazingly well but others feel like vanity projects for leadership that won't go anywhere.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros: The benefits are great, but they are dwindling as the company looks at saving money. Nevertheless, they are far better than most companies in the area.
cons: The majority of the management have very little experience (due to their age) so the management makes many immature mistakes. The company also things very highly of itself as a global leader that employs only the best in the field, but that's not actually something that's substantiated outside of the company itself. Advancement is nebulous and relies a lot on subjective traits and who your friends are.
advice_to_mgmt: Value experience that employees bring from outside of your company walls. Start leveling down the management that are in high levels simply because they have been at Dropbox for years, and start replacing them with experience managers with more industry experience.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year

cons: The only thing i can see so far is there is no downtown parking, however given an allowance a month helps with this. Plus in my opinion the amount of Pro's outweigh this.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the amazing work. As a new hire I have never felt more welcomed and appreciated at any other company that I have ever worked for. I am so happy to be apart of this culture and hope to show this type of care and attention to all of our future new hires as well.

review_title: Lots of great smart people, very sexist and cliquey "bro" culture
years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time
pros: Dropbox makes money no matter how badly management makes strategy. Because people love the product. It's great to work on such a valuable product, and there is some incredible talent wandering the halls.
cons: Dropbox culture, at large, will strike you as a bit entitled. But management culture is the real challenge: slow decision-making and widespread lack of trust create a situation of insiders and outsiders, regardless of role or title. Ego is a driver of most c-level decisions (or lack of them) and the result is often visibly sexist. (Especially do not plan to be a new mother here). Ageism here also seems more pronounced than at other comparable tech companies.
advice_to_mgmt: Management is decision-averse which trickles downward.

years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time for more than a year

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than 3 years
pros: GREAT co-workers, lots of opportunity to have outsized impact. Beautiful office in ATX with advantageous pay and benefits. Working with counterparts in SF and Dublin make this role more nuanced and interesting.
cons: Some of local leadership need to be more focussed on their team instead of conceptual paths to success or efficiency. Austin office beginning to feel like you can only progress so far before you have to try something else or move to SF.
advice_to_mgmt: Local MGMT should focus on the team more than the metrics sometimes. Company MGMT should invest in maintaining our product infrastructure as much as developing new products/features.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year

cons: Dropbox is still a startup so if you're not comfortable defining processes, ambiguity, and owning solutions to problems you discover you should look for a more corporate, legacy company. Moreover, if you're uncomfortable with change, look elsewhere.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue hiring talented, seasoned professionals to compliment the young workforce at Dropbox.

employee_status: Engineering Manager in San Francisco, CA
review_title: awesome place to work! Company culture really improved since 2013
years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox for more than 3 years
pros:
awesome place to work! People are all very "nice". Some amazingly smart people work at Dropbox...the creator of Python, a couple ex-principal engineers from Google, and some top competition coders from MIT/Harvard/Stanford/etc just to name a few.

Internally the culture and practices have really matured as well. Lots of investment in engineering tools and people development that didn't exist before. 3 years ago Dropbox was much less formal about this and it meant that if you were passive you might not get the feedback/opportunities you need to grow. These days that's fixed with the company investing lots in building up its people and helping them to find the right opportunities that fit them.

I'm still very optimistic about the business. Dropbox's renewed focus on enterprise (while still supporting a best-in-class consumer product) is unlocking a huge revenue stream and the team is laser focused on building it right. Given recent revenue, the 10B valuation seems pretty fair.
cons:
still some growing pains, but overall the company has become much more mature!
- larger company makes it hard to know everyone and develop empathy for other teams and their goals
advice_to_mgmt: if you can sell the company for 20B, do it.

advice_to_mgmt: Dropbox tired to do too many things at once. I think they would have been better suited to focus more on creating a few great experiences.

cons:
Lots of young people working late hours because they have no reason not to; it skews the work/life balance situation
- New, inexperienced managers. The company is working on that, but the damage has been done
- Many orgs within Dropbox are so mired in bad process and red tape that getting work done is shockingly hard, especially considering how small of a company it is
- For many, there simply is no career path. Put in your time, vest, but go somewhere else to truly grow.
- You will get fat

review_title: Dropbox is a feature, not a product" - Steve Jobs (He was right)
years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox for less than a year
pros: Free meals are excellent. Most individual contributors that joined the company during the last year are technically talented and pleasant to work with.
cons:
Due to the "Peter principle" in action - the workload is heavy in most departments due to high employee attrition.

There is a juvenile (unprofessional) social culture (7th grade) that feels more like Sesame Street and less like a business. It was hard to take this place (and some leaders) seriously. One example: Unrestricted access to free alcohol at work combined with the 7th grade social culture is a bad combination.
advice_to_mgmt:
1: Read how the "Peter principle" has made Dropbox mediocre and not sustainable.

2: Recognize that not all graduates from "prestigious" universities are talented or have common sense. 

3: Recognize that not all engineers are business management material.

4: Recognize that your 7th grade social culture was appropriate when you had less than 100 employees.

years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time
pros: Upper management are great people to work for. Listens to all of their employees and really tried to give honest answers.
cons: Rapid growth changes company culture and middle management doesn't get enough training.
advice_to_mgmt: Provide more training and opportunity for growth.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:

Strong senior management team.
cons: Company is transitioning from smaller "startup" culture, to mature enterprise, with all the expected growing pains and threats to cultural integrity.
advice_to_mgmt: Ensure that the vision and roadmap to success is communicated clearly and often.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros: Wicked smart people. Everyone is very Friendly. Free food and alcohol. Coffee is great. Location and benefits are competitive.
cons: Most managers are only manager by virtue of being there for a couple years. There isn't really a career growth or training for you to grow. The company changed a lot when they moved buildings. A bit of a boys club culture.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox for more than a year
pros: Highly motivated to grow. Had a great vision but no business model. Diversity is still a problem but not being shied away from.
cons: Business model is not sustainable and vague at best. Senior leaders are trying to re-imagine their mission 8 years on. They want to be slack or Salesforce or even box...but those companies already exist and are better at being them.
advice_to_mgmt: Think about taking a staff job at more mature businesses. Think about why key leaders have left over the past year.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
Dropbox is making the transition from a startup to a real company. And they're doing it in an audacious way: make something people want, charge them for it, and sell it to millions of people. There's no "capture a fraction of the transaction cost" or "throw ads at people to extract value from something they'd like to get for free" here. It's a very clear, "make something people want enough that they'll pay you for it" business model. And as a maker, that's an exciting place to be.

The level of vertical integration (buy electricity, server components, and dark fiber/sell to mom and pop consumers) is the kind of thing you only expect to see from the phone company, or maybe Google or Amazon. Certainly not from a company with a couple hundred engineers. On a day-to-day basis, that means that the impact any particular engineer can have is HIGH.

The overall philosophy at Dropbox seems to be, "hire the best people you can find, and give them the freedom to do their thing." On the engineering side, this means the team is friendly, smart, and eager to help each other, making it a great place to learn.

That same philosophy applies outside of engineering, as well. Take the tuck shop (cafe), for example: Chef Brian and Chef Danny have hired great talent and given them the latitude to be creative, and as a result Dropbox has the best company food I've come across. My friends at Google love coming to Dropbox for lunch because the food is such a treat.
cons:
Dropbox is making the transition from a startup to a real company. And that means having the downsides of both a startup and a real company.

The real company downsides are pretty familiar: there's not as much openness as at a small company, you can get stuck with a lousy manager or on a project that gets canned, there's things you can't know and hoops you have to jump through for confidentiality/strategy/compliance reasons, etc.

The small company downsides are also real: your stock is monopoly money, there's a lot of uncertainty, and if you get stuck with a lousy manager, there might not be the systems in place to deal with it.

My biggest concern personally is that leveling and career progression seems fairly haphazard. Reviews have happened about twice a year since 2014, and every single review cycle has used a different set of criteria. And they're developing a new one for this fall's reviews. On some level, the things that make you a good engineer are universal across evaluation frameworks, but on another (e.g. does the system emphasize how well you facilitate other teams' work or how well your team executes its own tasks) it can make a pretty substantial difference.
advice_to_mgmt:
The current management framework puts managers in a position of having to choose between company values and their team's OKR's. Different managers will err in different directions when it comes to that tension. Consider how values and OKR's map to each other.

Well over half the company has joined within the past two years. Spend more time with those people; they're who will be driving the company forward.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
You get to work with some amazing people. Everyone is affable, intelligent, and focused on their jobs. 
- Solid products that users love. From a sales perspective, it makes your job a lot easier. 
- Exceptional benefits and perks. Having worked for Google and Microsoft previously, I can confidently say that we're on par if not better than what's offered anywhere else.
- Food. Lots of it.
cons: I have nothing negative to say about the company so far. Great culture and opportunity outweigh any minor gripes that could potentially come up.
advice_to_mgmt: You're doing a great job taking care of your sales people, and giving them a chance to succeed. Keep up the good work.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
1.) Leaders are transparent, collaborative, have high integrity, and are passionate about our customers and the tool we provide to make their lives easier 
2.) A culture that is inclusive - a huge push to make sure we're building out an incredible culture where everyone feels like they are equal and can contribute
cons: 1.) Not a sales company - which can be a good thing, but it takes a long time to get product pushed out to market because of how many quality checks and hands are in the kitchen. Could also be a pro, but sometimes I want things released in the market sooner.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep it up, I love it here.

years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox for less than a year
pros: Flexible schedule, unlimited vacation time, amazing amazing food (all free).
cons: You don't get to wear a lot of hats as most roles are specialized and those in them are all experts.

years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros: Great work life balance, amazing office with amazing benefits. A lot of talented people to network with and learn from.
cons: Company vision is lacking, the teams are always changing and the company as a whole tends to hire hard skills over soft skills which can make for a bit of a bizarre culture. A lot of long term employees are leaving too, which can make work challenging since there wasn't too much documentation and process in the past.
advice_to_mgmt: Don't hire people just to fill headcount, there should be a need for that position.

years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Open to ideas, flexible, collaborative, forward thinking, very smart employees, great working environment, Tuck Shop!!! Founding Leadership, great COO and CFO!
cons: Political at times, slow to make product decisions, sweat details too much at times, not diverse, internal favorites, needs better middle managers.

review_title: Win/Win: Resources of a well known brand + the bigger impact of that of a startup role
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
You have an ability to work on projects that have a global impact from anywhere in the company which makes for interesting and challenging work and you learn a lot in a short amount of time 
-People are not only the best at what they do, but they're also super humble and down to earth (i.e don't be intimated by all the ivy league linkedin profiles, they're also really cool, genuine people and you don't need to come from an ivy league school to work here contrary to what others say)
-Prior to joining, I thought the team was much larger and much further along than it is and as a result there's a lot left to do as we scale and grow. You get the luxury of an already well known brand but the infrastructure of a small to mid-size company with a lot of things to still tackle! 
-Perks and benefits are way above market 
-They do a really good job of empowering/involving offices outside of HQ so we get to be a part of the strategy conversation vs. just implementation/execution 
-On the sales side you get to be the first and only ones calling into large Enterprise accounts, you don't have to worry about competing internally or dealing with a bunch of red tape internally to sell
cons:
There are a lot of factors involved in your total comp, and they are working on improving cash comp but it's slow in the making 
-Internal Comms is 'owned' by too many people across functions so you have to be proactive to find out the correct and current info at times (yet this is always a challenge in a hyper growth, global company), but it's also improving slowly
-Slow to fire people 
-Parking downtown is expensive and they reimburse less than half the cost
advice_to_mgmt:
The focus and leadership development have vastly improved in the last few months, keep it up! 
-Learn how to fire faster
-Identify and alleviate bottlenecks in legacy people who have taken on too much for too long
-Consensus decision making no longer works at this size and we end up not pleasing anybody and taking less risks, let's find a better way.
-Bring EPD opportunities to Austin and take advantage of the talent (and space) here!
-Implement a better tool to provide anonymous, specific feedback internally apart from our surveys and Glassdoor.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros: Lots of room to influence the brand, visually. Getting to work on several products ranging in dynamic messaging. Respectful of your work/life balance.
cons: Not a lot of personal growth opportunities, career-wise.

years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time
pros: You work hand in hand with some great people, it's a really laid back atmosphere with transparency and communication, and they really provide for their employees.
cons: No negatives or opportunities at this time.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep on keepin' on! You all do a great job!

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros: Phenomenal free food, really high caliber people. There is enough quick growth and development within the company to provide room to get your hands dirty and get involved in projects that on paper, would be beyond your experience level
cons: The company is definitely doing through a "growing-up" phase that is palpable. Straddling the tail-end of startup chaos with the beginnings of a not yet well-refined structure can be painful at times, without properly yielding the benefits of either of those states.
advice_to_mgmt: Learn the product!!!

employee_status: Team Lead in San Francisco, CA
years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox for more than a year
pros: Very smart people and the best of intentions.
cons:
There are very few layers of hierarchy. And unfortunately those layers are overly controlling. Managers do not control their teams or pretty much any decisions within their teams, from hiring, structure, communications, even strategy or logistics. The main function of manages becomes to run meeting logistics, be a point person for recruiting, and taking the heat for any problems.

Most folks in the company are very young, including most leadership, and do not have the perspective to understand that this is not typical and does not allow leadership to thrive or develop. There is much hand-wringing about how to develop good leadership, training programs being rolled out, etc. But I'm afraid that without working on reducing the culture of micromanagement that has developed, they're focusing on the wrong things to cultivate strong and experienced leadership, much less retention of those leaders.
advice_to_mgmt: Let your managers do what they're good at. Let go of some central control, create a culture of trust, and you will develop and retain the leaders you want.

review_title: Great people, excellent culture, big ambitions
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
Dropbox is a leader in our category because our product is so well loved by consumers & working professionals alike. It's not an accident that the product is so good, there is a tremendous amount of investment in product, design & engineering. As a salesperson this goes a long way toward backing us as we approach prospects for conversations to sell Dropbox Business and I'm able to show how quickly we've grown into an established enterprise software player.

Also, there are many brilliant & cool people at Dropbox in Austin that make coming to work everyday a blast. The free food is nice and all, but the people are the most important thing to me.
cons: There are definitely moments of chaos as we're still a maturing organization. For some, moments of uncertainty are stressful, though for me I enjoy opportunities to fix what's broken and tend to thrive in fast growing/maturing organizations.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep improving sales operations & continue to hire high caliber salespeople.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
There are some good people working in the trenches: smart, fun and easy to get along with
- Downtown location (pay to park, though)
- Solid medical benefits and meals
- Gym & shower in the building
cons:
Leadership lacking at every level; minimal mentorship or coaching, leads care about how you help them to their number, but not about you as a person
- Unclear career path, especially in satellite offices; dozens of people have left for other offices with better opportunities
- Bro culture on the sales side with a local "leader" who is unable to relate to anyone not exactly like him
- Because of the above point, attempts at diversity are feeble and just for show 
- No transparency as to how sales quotas are determined; they seem to be picked from the sky
- Compensation is not on par with other software companies; if you want to make money as a seller, good luck
- Atmosphere is no longer positive and encouraging; morale is low 

Bottom line: if career progression or sales success if what you're looking for, be sure to ask very specific questions about how leadership will help you get there and use caution; don't let the fluff reviews cloud your judgement

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
My peers at Dropbox are definitely what make the days bearable, especially the "old guard" who were some of the first people to start the Austin office, extremely genuine and caring people. Unfortunately, there aren't many of them left in the office... 
- The perks are great. It's nice to not have to worry about food, and the health benefits are better than in most companies I've seen. 
- The office location is in the heart of downtown and the building has a great rooftop deck and gym in the basement.
cons:
For enterprise sales, you are promised high multipliers coming into the company, while less than 10% of the AEs on the enterprise team made their quota in 2015, so very few people ever reach these supposed numbers and most end up making less than they did before they came to Dropbox. The MM reps have the same quota whether their territory is NYC or Kansas (they consider a knowledge worker in one state equivalent to another) so quota achievement in that group is almost entirely based on whether you get a good territory. 
- The senior sales management in Austin is the worst I have ever worked with in my career. Countless sales females who were working in Austin have left the company, moved to other offices, or switched teams to get away from it. To date, there are no female sales managers in Austin and any female who could have been promoted, but who has disagreed with them, has been run off, leaving only newly hired people to choose from. 
- Inexperienced people in the company are given authority and power to do things they should not be allowed to do, i.e. the territories for the entire sales team were cut by someone 1-2 years out of school with no background in finance or consulting. 
- There is a clear lack of communication and coordination between teams in and around sales, which leads to a lot of confusion and course correction from week to week. It's hard to focus on selling when you have to keep track of so many things outside sales that affect your day to day. 
- The focus from the company is on the "wedding not the marriage" when it comes to sales. They do everything to help bring you in the door, but once there, there is little done towards retaining top talent which has led to an exodus of some of the best sales reps over the past months. 

Overall, know what you're getting into when joining Dropbox. There are still good people here and if you can find a good manager, you can create an enjoyable work environment. Unfortunately, with the senior sales management currently in Austin, I would recommend the other offices over this one, especially as a female.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox
pros: Dropbox has one of the strongest and best cultures of any company I've worked at.
cons: Dropbox is growing very quickly and that doesn't come without its challenges – be prepared to roll up your sleeves to get real work done.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep walking the path that you're walking – things have improved dramatically in the past 3-4 months.

review_title: Company struggling to keep its identity and carve out where we should be
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Dropbox continues to have great people. We really care a lot about trying to maintain a lively, social work culture. Todd Jackson is a refreshing addition to our leadership team and is going to (hopefully) drive the product strategies to the fullest potentials.
cons:
There's still a lot of growth that our leadership team needs, but I think it's getting there. 

- If you're looking for a small, scrappy start up, we're not longer that. Processes are harder than ever to get through - people aren't on the same page (including the people who should be running them). There are layers upon layers of management and approvals needed that things sometimes take weeks to turnaround.

- We care more about what we are perceived to the outside world than valuing our employees. We work so hard to recruit talent but don't carve out paths or reward systems for them once they join. 

- Line and mid level managers are very junior IE this is the first management experience they have, and the training they receive leaves you with a hammer and no nails. On top of this, some of the best engineers are asked to move in to management when they don't desire to be, which really doesn't help anyone. 

- A lot of the company is built on referrals, which really doesn't help with diversity (of social, economic, or thought). People who think differently aren't encouraged to continue the conversation. I have heard of and seen many people just told that they are wrong.
advice_to_mgmt: I think that there are really good foundations that are trying to be implemented, but please don't forget about the employees.

review_title: Could take better care of people
years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
Interesting product to work with
Good people at the company (for now)
Growing up as a business
We know what we need to do
cons:
Hours are longer than other places
Comp is below market
