Not enough people to get jobs done
advice_to_mgmt: Take better care of existing employees

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox
pros: awesome working environment, feel confortable using Python
cons: work load is heavy sometimes, but overall its interesting
advice_to_mgmt: nope

review_title: Startup culture with TONS of upside
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros: Awesome time to work for the company with so many changes coming down the pipe on the business side. There is a real chance to impact product development and the sales process as everything is still being built.
cons: Dealing with ambiguity. If you are not okay with a startup culture then this probably isnt the place. Not a lot of concrete direction given from management but that is a plus in my mind.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep building the product to fit the enterprise space and amp up the sales productivity team

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
* Incredibly bright, kind, and humble pool of talent. I have never met such a unique group of people and have made some of my best friends here over the last 2 years
* Strong values - compared to other tech companies, Dropbox stays true to its core and continues to forge ahead without being super obnoxious by way of culture (other posts will talk about our entry-level/new grads who are entitled and have attitudes...welcome to working with most early 20 somethings in Silicon Valley - if you want to avoid this, leave tech where the perks are too good to be true for anyone)
* Great location if you live in SF - it's wonderful to work at a highly reputable tech company without doing the south bay commute
*Food is absolutely incredible - better than most restaurants - and far beyond any of the other tech companies
* Overall excellent C-level team - our COO is incredible and our co-founders are down to earth, brilliant, accessible and honest people
cons:
* Cash pay not as competitive as most tech companies...we still try to sell people on equity, which makes sense, but seeing that it's diluted and that the tech market is dying out right now, our execs need to acknowledge that handing out RSUs isn't going to cut it for the talent we want and need - and the folks we want to retain 
* Very high growth, fast moving so decisions can seem hasty or unthoughtful at times
* Not a good place for someone who wants the start up experience - we are too big now and layers are being added into the fold; (a pro because we need more delegation and need to make sure we don't have too many people trying to boil the ocean, but a con if you want a ton of autonomy and a big stake in multiple projects)
advice_to_mgmt:
Work on cash pay....we are seeing more and more regretable attrition amongst top talent whom probably felt no other choice but to leave for the $$$ offers out there, even if at heart, they preferred to stay at Dropbox

Keep holding VPs and mid-management accountable for delegation and clarity when it comes to structuring their orgs. Exec team is pretty together, but this does not trickle down as well as it could/should to lower level management

review_title: Still a great place to work
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time
pros: Brilliant co-workers and a collaborative culture. Exciting product pipeline.
cons: Growing pains around communication and coordination.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep the team's eye on the ball. Ignore critical/misinformed press.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox
pros: People, impact, mission, and benefits. The best company to work for!
cons: None, this place is awesome!

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
Young and vibrant culture
Everyone wants to succeed
cons:
Poor work life balance
Culture praises execution over creativity
Employees focus too much on IPO vs being a great company
Strategy changes too much
advice_to_mgmt:
Hire stronger leaders. Stop promoting the young leaders who have minimal experience.
Focus on our strengths. Stop trying to play catchup to our competitors.
Understand why employees are leaving to our competitors or other companies. Learn from our mistakes.
Refocus the company away from IPO and towards a better vision as a organization.
Stop wasting money on poor technological decisions. 
Align everyone from the bottom up on who we are as a company and what vision we are truly trying to pursue. The chaos and confusion is really demoralizing all employees.

employee_status: Software Engineer in San Francisco, CA
review_title: High-leverage, if you end up in the right place
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox for more than a year
pros:
You will work with others who care deeply about bringing their best to work every day.

Your coworkers will be incredibly passionate about doing right by our users.

The company displays a surprising amount of flexibility to employees in complex extra-work situations.
cons:
Like everywhere else, your experience will vary based on your manager.

Mentorship in many parts of the organization can be lacking, unless you stay on top of it.
advice_to_mgmt: Provide mechanisms for people to escalate unhealthy scenarios. When an employee expresses a desire to leave, treat that as a high-priority incident.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros: Best culture. Great benefits. Great People. Great sales team. Just the right amount of sales reps in each territory. We don't try to differentiate ourselves by saying we're a "platform" company like our competitors.
cons: The field team doesn't get to travel as much as we would like to. Focused on our territories.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
All engineers here are extremely smart, but what makes Dropbox stand out is the sense of shared ownership and willingness to push the boundaries. I'm also blown away by the caliber of employees outside engineering too, from the legal team, to recruiting, to the Tuck Shop.

Employees tend to be direct and vocal about giving constructive criticism, which is a refreshing break from the sugar coated Silicon Valley culture.

Dropbox has very solid core product, rapid pace of development, and some innovative big bets.

Perks are great: the Tuck Shop stands out. Compensation is more than fair and meritocratic.
cons:
Some of the big bets didn't pan out, which is sad as they were very innovative. This could be demoralizing to some employees. The company has changed its direction in the last few years, with a few rocky transitions.

Some technical debt can come as a shock to new grads or Xooglers, but it's nothing eng org doesn't intend to fix.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you're doing. I love our VPs. But focus on articulating company goals and build camaraderie.

review_title: Unbelievable perks, but little to offer in career growth

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros: Dropbox hires only the best, so you'll be working with jndustry elite. Despite being a large company, if you land on the right project you can still have large scale impact.

review_title: Kick the jerks out and you'll be good!
years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox
pros: Amazing company that has an amazing product. The workplace, office, benefits were great. Even most of my colleagues were friendly, kind and good to hang out with.
cons:
My boss was a jerk- Plain and simple. He was rude, solo star wannabe and ridiculed me. He'd try to put any blame on me, make me look bad, take credit for my work and keep me out of the loop. 

Was sad to leave because of the jerk, but life is short and I don't have to endure crap from power tripping bosses anymore. I found something better.
advice_to_mgmt: If you see rude bosses and don't speak up/do anything about it- you support it! I thought the YC credo of 'Don't be a jerk' would be paramount here. Clearly it wasn't.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros: Great food, flexible work schedule, comfortable office
cons: Lack of experienced managers and coaching

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros: The perks are breathtaking, and coworkers are generally a great bunch. Good location, great compensation. Great sense of purpose as employee.
cons: Too heavy on the junior side, needs more senior engineers and leadership. There's a lot of very green employees just out of ivy leagues who think they're hot stuff, when in reality they're just "ok".

years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros: Excellent perks (best corporate food there is, great benefits, wellness reimbursement, you name it). Dynamic and fastly growing environment
cons: There is an emphasis to hire what they call "Dropboxy" people. "Dropboxy" might as well be a proxy for entitled, youthful, conceited, and inexperienced. The general lack of experience and professionalism at the company is appalling and the scalability of the current business model is not really there. They have some severe issues with diversity as it relates to diversity of opinion or interests. Basically if you aren't a Brogrammer, you will not like it. Most amount of crazy politics I have ever experienced in a job.
advice_to_mgmt: Be open to change, hire more experienced leaders. Hiring smart kids out of MIT is great, but should have some people with more corporate experience if you want scalability. There is a culture of childishness, gossipers, and backstabbing that seems to pervasive across departments.

review_title: Run by a bunch of kids
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Well they consider 3 meals a day a perk, give me a break. Pay me more and I could afford to buy my own meals.
cons: Where do I start. In sales and they under pay people, run by a guy in Austin that is a kid (and plays on his Google 'success'), they have zero clue how to penetrate the enterprise, they don't hire good candidates because they don't pay well and the smart ones go to Box, it's like a frat house there, trying to be 'cool' but at the end of the day product doesn't sell.
advice_to_mgmt: Get some real leadership.

review_title: Amazing culture, ridiculously talented people, has not won yet
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
The culture is governed by a set of values that is pervasive and has buy in from the employees. There is ownership in the work and it's easy to feel bought into what the company is trying to accomplish. There is a strong sense of community outside of work. The culture promotes continuous learning and provides the resources to do so; for instance, if someone wanted to learn how to code, play a new instrument, or learn a new language, it's very easy to do so at work. There is an interest group for pretty much anything you can think of, from soccer to poker to smash bros to Taylor Swift, which makes it easy to meet others and keep hobbies active.
- The talent bar has managed to stay incredibly high despite the increase in company size. There is probably no other group of 1,000+ individuals working on the same product as smart and talented as the team at Dropbox. Even though everyone is insanely smart and accomplished, people are unbelievably down to earth, approachable, and nice. In a recent internal survey of what it meant to be 'Dropboxy', humble was the most cited response by far.
- Have personally not had issues with work / life balance, but some individuals have probably had unfortunate experiences. I feel the company provides enough ownership and responsibility that one has control over work schedule and cadence, leading to much more predictability in hours. Even if I have a lot of work, I can still make plans on any day of the week, honor them, and finish up afterward from home if necessary. Increased ownership also means I'm directing my work more, so I don't find myself re-doing work unnecessarily. Only times I've worked longer hours are because I've wanted to do so on my own accord.
- Business is strong. A lot of external criticism regarding valuation and how well the business is actually doing, but company is on a growth trajectory most companies wish they could ever experience. Senior executive bench is stacked (COO, CFO, VPs); Dropbox has managed to bring in incredibly impressive individuals who've accomplished a lot at other companies.
- Compensation and perks are benchmarked to be among the top in the valley. Food is definitely the best in the valley, and probably of any corporate environment in the world.
cons:
Regarding point above on business being strong, Dropbox cannot say it has won. Cloud storage / collaboration space is very competitive with giants like Microsoft and Google wanting a piece. Company appears to lack a sense of urgency given success to date, but needs to keep pushing forward to sustain growth.
- To maintain extremely positive culture, a sub-culture of conflict aversion seems to have developed. Leads to some group think.
- Related to above, company has a hard time with having difficult conversations and making difficult decisions. More prevalent in inexperienced decision makers who want every piece of information and unanimous decision making, instead of just making a call.
- As company scales, increased emphasis is placed on processes and planning, which can make things feel more bureaucratic and progress is being made at a slower pace than it could be.
advice_to_mgmt: Need to establish an unambiguous product strategy. My impression is many teams are not 100% sure how to prioritize work because they're unsure what they're supposed to be prioritizing for.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros: Having a product built by the finest engineering talent in the industry makes being among the best and brightest on the business side incredibly rewarding.
cons: Lots of candidate interviewing, but who can blame anyone for wanting to work here?
advice_to_mgmt: Keep accelerating - it's still just the start of many great years ahead.

years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time for more than a year

cons: Many of the leaders have little to no experience outside of Dropbox. The lack of structure & role clarity is sometimes worn as a badge of honor, but it often leads to duplicate work, cyclical feedback, and stunted professional growth. I was really sad to say goodbye to my coworkers, but extremely eager to go somewhere more mature.

review_title: Great perks, good people and opportunity to land grab
years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox
pros:
Great perks:
-Average compensation
-Company offers a mix of Options + RSUs which is positive. Many startups only offer options
-You will have to pay for nothing. Food, Gym, Commute, Snacks, Accessories, and Clothing (if you're okay wearing tshirts) are provided

Good People:
-I won't speak much about this. If you're considering Dropbox, you're probably also considering Google, Facebook, Twitter, AirBnB, Pinterest, etc... Good people at the top startups are a given these days.

Opportunity to Land Grab
- If you're positive, you call it opportunity. If you're a cynic, you call it a Land Grab. The result is the same. In any regard, it's a great opportunity to build functions and develop teams from the ground up. Since the company was arguably understaffed for much of it's early history, lot's of table stakes functions that are only being built now.
cons:
Speaking from the business team perspective only

Hard to get things done
-Poor collaboration with non-business teams. There's a clear divide between Engineering/Product/Design and Business within Dropbox. Can be incredibly tough to get things done.
-Consensus culture. You generally need passive sign-off from a number of stake-holders. It's never clear when you have the sign-off, as some teams may still block a project before launch despite clear agreement from the start.

Recognition
-Most teams are still finding their groove. That means defining success is often subjective. Can be challenging to newer teams or teams without a clear goal
advice_to_mgmt:
Defer to your senior leaders
-Break barriers and allow the 'smart creatives' you've hired to do their job

years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time
pros: Amazing talent across all functions.
cons:
CEO is not a fit for the role. Was good when the company was smaller, but has no vision.
- Sr. Leadership is extremely political.
advice_to_mgmt:
There needs to be clear direction & accountability.
- Start caring about your employees again!

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time

cons: Satellite offices are challenging (everything happens in SF), management is either too junior or too busy, sales organization is still developing an identity
advice_to_mgmt: Develop and communicate clear strategy for sales organization growth/development, create career paths for junior and experienced sales people

review_title: Exciting growth, the most talented people I've worked with

High caliber of talent. I've never once been frustrated by someone else's lack of competence.

cons: Need clearer career paths and better programs for mentorship, career growth and development. Also, lots of inexperienced managers who are new to managing people.

review_title: The best place to learn and grow

focus, focus, focus

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time
pros:
Super smart people

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Dropbox has some of the smartest - and nicest! - people around.

The company is growing rapidly, which means there are more interesting problems to solve and growth opportunities than there are people to solve all of them. It's also a chance to see how things really work at a high growth company - management is extremely transparent.

The problem space is well beyond simply file sharing at this point, and there are plenty of interesting new projects in development for product-focused folks. Our infrastructure challenges are second only to a handful of companies (like Google or Facebook), but we're getting to build that infrastructure from the ground up, with a chance to learn from those that have come before us.
cons: For some folks, the constant change might be a con - Dropbox is growing incredibly fast, so everything that worked a year or two ago needs to be re-evaluated against higher scale.

review_title: Great company but needs a South Bay Engineering Office
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros: Great benefits, great people, great food. The work is interesting to do and the Tuckshop is the best food i've had.
cons: Its in San Francisco. The cal train is bad in it's best days, and unusable whenever an accident occurs, which seems to be at least once a week since the start of 2015.
advice_to_mgmt: Open an engineering office in South Bay, There's many engineers who do not like the city and the commute is bad. This would open up a larger pool of engineers, particularly ones who currently live in south bay for Google, Apple, Facebook, etc.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time
pros: Great people to work with, fun environment, and flexible hours
cons: Not much in terms of career progression and middle management is struggling to keep people engaged.
advice_to_mgmt: The moment you stop worrying about your people leaving, is the moment that start leaving.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox
pros: Great culture where you learn quickly
cons: Hard work, growing pains of scaling a business

years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox full-time
pros: More than generous compensation and perks.
cons:
Everyone at Dropbox spends a lot of time telling themselves and each other how great it is to work there, and not enough time making it a great place to work.

- Whenever Dropbox makes a public announcement, employees are encouraged to the point of cajoled into leaving positive comments and favorable reviews on public forums with personal accounts ("Don't forget to upvote the announcement on Hackernews! But don't do it on the office wifi because that can trigger a spam alert...", etc).
- Troubling company value: We not I. This means that you should put Dropbox before your own personal wellbeing. Employees that make personal sacrifices for the benefit of the company are deified at the all hands meeting.
- Cross-functional communication or collaboration is effectively impossible without the involvement of a manager or three, as everyone is worried only about completing their own sprint goals. The "start-up mindset" is useless for a 1000+ person corporate entity.
- Interviews and hire decisions are conducted in a very haphazard and non-transparent way, with more than a few interviewees mysteriously turned away after a consensus "hire" decision. 
- If you're not a 22 year old, male, Stanford/MIT/Carnegie Mellon grad or a Facebook/Google alumn, prepare to feel very out of place and marginalized.
- Good work goes unacknowledged unless you are a relentless self-promoter or part of the in-crowd. With respect to code, quantity counts more than quality.
- Working hours regularly extend late into the night. I once tried to hold a 10:30 am meeting, and was told by a manager that this was "ridiculously early". Another time, I came into the office around 11 PM to pick up something that I had forgotten, and it was half full with people working and playing video games.
- Consequently, important business decisions get made during non-standard business hours, so when you come into work at 9 AM, you'll be greeted with an inbox full of new decisions, priorities and tasks.
- Heavy drinking is commonplace at most official and non-official company functions, and opting-out is seen as being "not part of the team". When many of your coworkers/managers end up at a bachelor party in Vegas, you will definitely hear about it at your next sprint planning meeting.
- Gossip-y. Again, if you're not in the in-crowed, you will be at its mercy.
-- This extends to HR. Do not share anything with HR that you don't want your manager and coworkers to also know.
- Rampant entitlement among employees. At dinner, one can frequently overhear such gems as "I'm too good for MUNI" and "Well it's easier for women to get hired, so that's probably why she was hired and not X (male person)".

Summarily, I felt that my career prospects would be limited as I was not part of the in-crowd, and unwilling to put in 60 hour weeks among less-than-desirable company. Ultimately though, Dropbox will continue to make buckets of money despite its troubling culture.

review_title: Amazing place where you learn every day, collaborate with incredible people, and feel like you're part of the mission.
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year

cons: Everyone is moving very fast around you on many projects and at times it feels a bit hard to keep up.

review_title: Great company, smart people, amazing perks
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox

years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox

employee_status: Sales Development Representative in Austin, TX
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox

Freedom & autonomy in your role starting day 1
