years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
The company has a very employee-friendly culture: a lot of time they go out of their way to make sure employees are happy & productive. A few times they even go too far, making me as an employee feel that they are spending too much money / time on small employee perks.

You can easily see the results of Dropbox having a very high hiring bar - everybody here is ridiculously smart :)
cons:
Some growing pains are expected, given the company's trajectory and current size. I doubt they could have done it better. 

Biggest con: everybody is smart but sometimes part of the work doesn't require you to be smart, just meticulous. It's sometimes tricky to balance that out (Google had the same problem back in the day).

review_title: Move fast, learn a lot, work with great people. But work a lot.
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros: Working with really sharp engineers is great. I don't have to worry about other people following through. I can trust that feedback is thoughtful & on point. Fantastic perks, great company values that people seem to take to heart.
cons: It can be intimidating to start. The interview process is hard & we hold ourselves to a high standard. I had some imposter syndrome at the outset.

employee_status: Product Manager in San Francisco, CA
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox
pros:
Working with and learning from a generally motivated, smart, and humble team.
Perks, especially the food, the gym, and the exceptionally beautiful offices (forgiving the blue books and water bottles).
Working on a widely used product that has managed to (so far) serve both consumers and businesses.
cons: Nothing too unexpected here. There are times when teams I've been a part of push hard to hit a deadline, and there are the occasional bad apples, but overall not much to take issue with. Decision making can feel limited to a pretty small set of folks at times, but this has already started to improve.
advice_to_mgmt: As long as Dropbox can continue to attract great people by being a desirable place to work, I think it has the potential to be a great place to work for years to come.

review_title: A great company with growing pains.
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox
pros: Chance to impact millions of users. Working with literally some of the smartest people in the world. Everyone wants to win.
cons: Everyone wants to win; sometimes your colleagues confuse that with winning against each other as opposed to other companies. Internal recognition, promotion, resource allocation are ad-hoc and weak.
advice_to_mgmt: You've built a great product but building a great company means getting the boring things, like performance reviews and incentives, right.

review_title: The sky is the limit and you'll have a lot of fun along the way!
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros: You get to work with the absolute best people - period. They're down to Earth, incredibly smart, fun loving, and go the extra mile to produce quality work for our customers. We have a lot of opportunity in front of us and we're still in the building phase of the company so there is a lot to do and learn professionally and personally. From a sales perspective the team is still really small so we're a close group and constantly learning from eachother and we plan to keep that culture even as we continue to aggressively grow.
cons: Growing a little too quickly so things are constantly changing and communication takes some effort, but that's understandable and the growth is also what makes it so fun and exciting so I wouldn't have it any other way right now.
advice_to_mgmt: Work life balance is challenging because we're all really enjoying what we're doing and the challenges we're overcoming so it's hard to turn it off, but can stand to improve at all levels of the company.

review_title: Replete with smart, motivated, kind people and amazing benefits.
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros: The people. Everybody I work with inspires me. The benefits and compensation are great. The culture is fun but we get work done.
cons: We still don't have the great internal tooling that large tech companies like Google or Facebook might have. But we're getting there.

review_title: A Software Company that Focuses on the User
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
We focus on making the users life simpler and are trying to build a company that makes money because people pay us for what we offer, which is fairly unique in this day and age where most companies are focused on eyeballs to show ads.

We also solve challenging technical problems at scale both on the client (large amounts of personal data, in fast low resource clients, across a wide variety of platforms) and in our backend (large amounts of data, mostly unique per user). And when we build things we strive to build them correctly. Both because we're protecting data that is precious to our users, but also because we believe in quality and things just working for our users.

Benefits, time off, etc are all world class; but they're not the reason you should work here. The reason to work here is the focus on the user, the focus on quality, and solving hard engineering problems.
cons: The company is growing fast, and growing causes pain. Medium term goals change more often than at a big company or than they would if it was a less competitive space since we're always trying to balance being nimble without getting distracted. It's part of the fun, but it can take a little to get used to.

review_title: Exceeded my wildest expectations: optimize for learning with brilliant, humble, and hard working peers
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
At times, I have to pinch myself that I'm working here. My coworkers here are so incredibly talented, authentic, good-natured, and dedicated. From the first day I started work, I was blown away by how competent yet kind-hearted everyone was. More than that, it's clear that Dropboxers take their work responsibilities seriously as we continue to build the best home for everyone's stuff. Transparency at a company this size is difficult, but I've been very impressed with management's commitment to making the company still feel small. 

Even as we grow, there is consistently a focus on optimizing for our own personal growth. Overwhelmingly the leads here have proven again and again that they are willing to invest in you.

On a company level, the quality of life at Dropbox is simply beyond any comparable company I've seen or heard about. Still blown away by the delightful perks like the on-site gym to a "Black Market" holiday catalog to the Tuck Shop (which can rival most SF restaurants) to the generous commuting or wellness subsidies.
cons: Dropbox is growing fast, which brings its own set of growing pains. Desks move almost monthly and reorgs abound. If you're willing to roll with the unexpected punches, this is definitely a place that you can grow exponentially
advice_to_mgmt: Stay true to our core values and scale with caution since the quality of the company is one of the huge draws

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than 3 years
pros: This is a fun and exciting place to work. Great perks and the company puts a lot of effort into maintaining the culture.
cons: The company is professionally immature and lacks accountability. The hiring is focused on "potential", so the company is mostly young, inexperienced, and oblivious. There's an overwhelming sense of entitlement, which takes some of the fun out of the culture.
advice_to_mgmt: Focus on experienced hires. Someone has to know what they're doing.

review_title: Dropbox: A Fantastic Place to Work
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros: Dropbox is a zany, high-velocity, awesomely creative, best-food-in-town, friendly place to work. I really enjoy: great engineering talent, well-reasoned decisions, high end restaurant quality food, a multitude of perks, creative projects, and great transparency.
cons: There are still a lot of organizational growing pains -- Dropbox still hasn't quite figured out how to do the peer reviews well, the office is a little crowded, and so on. This is certainly all going to be resolved in time -- everyone here has good intentions.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue keeping your decisions transparent and all will be well!

years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox
pros: Good benefits, good pay, fun play to work, with great management.
cons: None at this time.
advice_to_mgmt: Place you can grow as a professional

years_at_company: I worked at Dropbox
pros:
awesome
great perks
was an amazing experince
cons: lots of work, no promotions caus eim an intern, lots of focused people

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
Very smart colleagues
- Incredible perks
- Widespread excitement about what we are all working on daily
cons:
Growing pains (keeping personality while adding people)
- Cross functional communication lacking sometimes

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Management is good at identifying weaknesses in company culture/policies/direction and making changes. Very little dogma.

Extremely strong team, I'm constantly impressed and occasionally intimidated by how smart and effective my co-workers are.
cons: There are a lot of growing pains. We've only had a year where we couldn't fit the whole company onto a single floor or a building, and there was a lot of communication we took for granted that doesn't happen anymore, especially between product/engineering and sales/support/marketing
advice_to_mgmt: Have more structured ways for people to learn new skills and try out new roles. It's hard to make time for personal development and isn't an explicit priority for many leads.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
Dropbox is full of talented people with the freedom to express their talents. People have a lot of freedom to choose which projects they work on and how they work on them. And that culture extends throughout the company.

The perks and benefits are good, and people use them. Free food is the norm in tech these days, but what Tuck Shop turns out is unlike anything I've seen at any other company. Actually, that doesn't do it justice. The Tuck Shop turns out food that can go toe-to-toe with any trendy SF restaurant you can name. Or you can always get a sandwich, a burger, pizza, or salad, if you're of the less adventurous type (but what's the fun in that?)

There's also a slew of other benefits: health/vision/dental, 401k match, donation match, commuter benefit, cell phone, gym (both on-site w/ free laundry and a $100/month subsidy for an outside gym), basically, you name it, Dropbox has it.

The culture embraces the fact that people work better when they have breaks, so people actually use their vacation days. And people work pretty flexible hours.
cons:
The pace of growth brings some problems. For one thing, everyone has to spend a lot of time interviewing potential new Dropboxers. For another, growth means every week there are more desks and fewer marginal spaces (e.g. couches) until we get more office space, and the people you're sitting next to today are unlikely to be the people you're sitting next to two months from now.

Also, to make the freedom work, there are a lot of meetings.

review_title: Medium sized tech company with small company feel. Young, humble, smart, quirky.
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros: Entrepreneurial, network of amazing people, insanely generous benefits, work-life balance
cons: transitioning from start up feel to large company feel

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox
pros: At Dropbox you get to work with motivated talented people who truly own their work. Management is amazing, and even through the ups and downs they keep team morale up. You are independent, trusted, and valued as an employee.
cons: It's growing and adjusting constantly. But that's part of the fun!
advice_to_mgmt: Keep the high bar for hiring, continue to communicate and explain decisions to the entire company!

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros: After working at other major/top silicon valley companies, Dropbox is definitely the best company I've worked at. The level of technical talent here is better than pretty much any other company (and Dropbox maintains a high hiring bar to make sure that it doesn't drop). This provides a lot of opportunity for learning and means that I can fully trust my coworkers to produce excellent work. I also get a lot of control over what I work on and how it should be implemented. My manager/PM are always open to suggestions on how things should work from the technical to the product level, and I don't usually have to go through them anyway. Work/life balance is great. I don't work weekends at all and I have yet to go above 50 hours a week (not including meals at the office). Compensation is on par or better than any other company in SV and the perks are great (best food of any tech company!).
cons: The company is still growing very quickly which means that a lot of the processes aren't as set in stone as they are at larger/more stable companies. This means that when trying to do certain things, no one really has a good idea of how to go about it (e.g. compensation reviews were only standardized relatively recently). This doesn't actually affect much in practice, however, as everyone I've met is more than wiling to work with you to make sure things are made right.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
the security of a stable, name brand company
-the excitement directly impacting the companie's trajectory
-positive, caring culture
cons:
lack of day-to-day structure 
-sometimes minimal training 
-"figure it out" mentality

(all of these are not necessarily cons)
advice_to_mgmt: Our management is the reason this company is so wonderful. It starts with Drew and Arash. I'm grateful to of had positive, supporting mentors here.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox
pros: Dropbox has an amazing company culture and drive to win. Great people, great benefits, great product
cons: Work life balance can be hard

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
Our founders -- Drew and Arash are amazing! They've built this tremendous company and yet are so humble and approachable. They are driving the best culture and values throughout the entire company.

People -- smartest, nicest people I've ever worked with. There are no politics, everyone watches out for each other and tries to do the best work of their lives. 

Problems we get to solve -- we've built this simple, yet powerful technology that makes life easier. 

Brand -- our users love Dropbox and they write to us almost every day. It's rare to get to work for a company that's loved for its products. 

Perks -- OMG the Tuck Shop. Best food in the Valley, PERIOD.
cons: What we're trying to accomplish takes a lot of effort. People often burn the midnight oil. That being said, the company is trying hard to give people the flexibility they need and is consciously focused on the needs of people with families (kids, etc.).
advice_to_mgmt: I think they're doing all the right things for the company, as we scale globally.

review_title: Amazing company, amazing product, amazing people and off-the-wall amazing food!
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
The people are smart, engaging, passionate and interesting. 
The food we get each day is just outstanding - it's SF restaurant quality food. 
The office environment is fun and conducive to productive work happening. 
The perks are on par with the top companies. 
Work-life balance is great, considering how much work everyone still gets done.
cons:
The workforce is very young, so if you're over 30 you can feel very old ;-)
The dental plan is Guardian, instead of Delta, but this is a VERY minor con.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you're doing. Get ahead of any conflict/politics issues - we will have them, so let's figure out how to best deal with them rather than pretend they don't exist.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
By far the best thing about working at Dropbox is the people I get to work with every day. Everyone in this office is amazing.

Not to mention the incredible benefits; my monthly budget basically involves rent and utilities because Dropbox pays for so much.
cons: WLB can be tough unless you really work for it. The office is such a great place to be that it's easy to get sucked into it and never leave. I sometimes have to remind myself to get out of the office and do other things.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
Aligned with mission: personally, I think it's nice to work in a company that is working to be successful without being an advertising company. For most, the constant obsession with improving the product and our internal procedures is probably the biggest draw. If you have a good idea, MGMT is very receptive to criticism of the status quo, and moves quickly to improve. Sense of ownership over work. 
-People: Biggest perk is the people -- really enjoy spending time with my colleagues. Very familial. I am in a satellite office (Austin) so I don't know if this is the same as in SF, but it is very closely knit here. Also - I'm gay, and it has never come up as an issue (not that I am very surprised, but it is worth noting). We have a very supportive queer community in the office, going to LGBT events in town, etc. I rarely feel like an outsider, even though most of the office is straight. 
-Work-life: Although my colleagues are all very hard workers, they also have a lot going on outside of work. One has a top-rated EE Cummings poetry blog, another is working on releasing a rock EP, or is playing a show at a bar down the road, or is doing standup comedy, or inviting people to go volunteer at a local school, or go to an art show etc etc... everyone has an interesting life outside of work, and really cares about engaging with Austin. I think that is rare in a lot of organizations, where the conveniences offered by an office, and the drive to succeed, isolate employees from forming roots where they life. 
-Hiring: I have done some interviewing for prospective candidates, and the training is very value-oriented. I think we attract top talent, sure, but if the person doesn't contribute in some way, or bring a diverse viewpoint into the organization, then the talents will not meant as much. Good balance of finding good workers + human beings. Makes me comfortable to know that, as we grow, the org will still be filled with people you care about, outside of work relationships. 
-Transparency: management is super, super open. This might change as we grow, but they work hard to keep everyone in the loop.
cons: The rate of change here is very fast -- which is great in many ways (rarely boring, easy to address flaws, etc) and is something I was attracted to at first. However, it is a bit hard to imagine what my career will look like a year out. Again, the unknowing is part of the charm, but can be a bit frustrating when you are trying to plan for the future. It's impossible to know what opportunities will arise (or disappear)
advice_to_mgmt: Make sure culture scales with growth...clearer outlines of possible job openings / paths / promotions... not much else. Great job!

review_title: I'm excited to work with Dropboxers every day!
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros: I'm challenged by my work, and always provided with new opportunities to learn and grow. Dropbox takes cares of their employees so unbelievably well (time off, gym classes, 3 gourmet meals a day, team activities, and so many others perks) that I in return have the upmost respect for the company and our leadership.
cons: There's growing pains when we're expanding as quickly as we are, but I do appreciate all the company is doing to keep our incredible culture in-tact as we add new Dropboxers.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep the hiring bar as high as possible for as long as possible. It's the incredible caliber of the people here who make Dropbox such an incredible place to work.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
There are so many pros about working at Dropbox that I personally get to experience every day:

- Working on hard problems that I want to solve. Everyone here believes that a challenge is only worth your time if you're motivated to solve it and if it's worth solving (meaning it's hard and nobody has)
- Flexible office arrangements in terms of time, location, etc.
- The perks are incredible, starting and ending with the food. Best in the business, maybe the best corporate food on earth!
cons: Dropbox is still growing extremely quickly and as such, many key areas lack infrastructure. People Operations (HR) is just starting to get their feet underneath them. Product decisions and prioritization of resources are just now starting to get a bit of objective process put behind them. There is always the typical rush to market with products that, while bug-free, may not have enough features to capture the space at launch time.
advice_to_mgmt: I like the trajectory that management is on right now. Focus on people development - help them understand their mid- and long-term goals, rather than what they hope to accomplish in the next 1-2 quarters.

review_title: Best environment and benefits you can imagine for a company
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox
pros:
Really care about employees, top-notch benefits and working condition 
Transparent and open communication
cons: Too much food, dropbox 15

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox
pros: Most talented team in the business. Very human and caring culture, but also holds people accountable.
cons: Lots of people working really hard. Extreme competitors.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
Everyone is extremely motivated and excited about helping the organisation succeed. When I first joined, I swore there must've been something in the water.

There's a lot of freedom; some change projects every 2-3 weeks, others (if they so desire) can stay on one thing for months at a time. Working on projects unrelated to your team is encouraged, if it would be the best way to move the company forward.

The org is growing, but they seem to be growing responsibly.
cons: The lunchroom gets too crowded at 12:05pm.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros: i feel spoiled every day
cons: it's a fast growing place—some learn to deal with some ambiguity!

review_title: Can't ask for a better work environment - people are unbelievably talented and always willing to help out!
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros: The perks are great, of course (better than any company in the Bay Area I've been to, and I've been to most of them), but the most important thing at Dropbox is the people and the culture. The environment is really positive and people are not only smart, but actually seem to care about the company and each other. There's a ton of opportunity to move around to different teams if you're interested in trying something new or want a different career path.
cons: The company is definitely growing fast, and people move around a lot, so roles get shuffled around. This isn't necessarily the best place to work if you're not comfortable with change, as that happens a lot around here. Things are still getting figured out, which can sometimes be exciting (and sometimes confusing).
advice_to_mgmt: Not much that I would criticize here. Maybe find some way to mix teams a bit more? It's been a little difficult to meet people in other functions since the Wharfside building is so separated.

review_title: Hands down the most exciting place to be right now!
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time
pros: Dropbox has the highest concentration of extremely intelligent, fun, and genuinely humble people I have seen. Everyone here -- from recruiters to engineers to chefs -- works really, really hard and is amazing at what they do. Folks are recognized by their work and not necessarily by how loudly they toot their own horn. There isn't a need for any strategic play / "networking" because most Dropboxers are actually interested in you and will want to invest in your growth whenever possible. The company is also extremely transparent, mirroring the strong sense of trust and respect within the Dropbox circle.
cons: If you don't have top-notch work ethic, you will feel like a slacker here. There is no room for cruisers, which is what Dropboxers love! The demographic profile of the company is also diversifying (e.g., gender, age, non-technical background), which is great, but there is still some catch-up we need to do to meet those diverse needs (e.g., functional nursing rooms for young mothers). Fortunately, diversity is a top priority for the company and Dropboxers themselves are encouraged to find solutions for the gaps they notice (instead of just grumbling about them).
advice_to_mgmt: As we continue to grow at rapid speed, let's all do our part in keeping the bar as high as it was on Day 1, while staying humble.

review_title: Amazing place to work and learn.
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros: Wonderful office culture with awesome perks. Really smart and caring people.
cons: There are a lot of empty promises being made to employees.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time
pros:
Working at Dropbox was the best decision I ever made. I was a little wary before I interviewed, concerned that it might be just another hot tech company with inflated egos and over-the-top perks. Thankfully, these concerns were extremely far from the truth. I adore my team members -- they are incredibly talented, humble, passionate, hardworking, collaborative, and just generally good people. 

The flat organizational structure means no one thinks twice about pitching in on something where their expertise is needed, and it also means that opportunities to get involved across a variety of different projects are yours for the taking. 

The company is maniacally focused on doing the right thing for users, and on making beautifully simple products that genuinely make people's lives easier. So refreshing and motivating.

And of course, there are the perks :) The food is AMAZING, the gym and massages are awesome, etc. It really is the most incredible place to work.
cons: There are definitely some growing pains; we've been growing so quickly that we've had to hack some solutions together. Now we need more established processes.
advice_to_mgmt: Stay true to our mission and values, and I'm confident we'll continue to thrive.

review_title: Wonderful environment filled with amazingly smart and humble people
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros: I love working at Dropbox because the company really cares about our customers and our employees. I feel like my voice is heard and the work I do has an everyday impact on our base. The people are really smart, humble and all a little quirky - everyone works hard and sometimes long hours, but everyone also has some interest outside of work. I think this is really important and also lends to creating a more dynamic and interesting culture.
cons:
The company is at an interesting growth point right now - there are the normal growing pains you would expect from any younger company i.e. establishing career tracks. The upside is that Dropbox is aware of this and every team is actively working to make improvements.

Additionally, the environment is very fast paced and unstructured like most younger companies. I could see this being a huge challenge for someone coming from a job where they were told what to do and when to do it. You have to be comfortable with creating processes, taking the lead and pushing for change when you believe it's necessary - some people will thrive doing this and others won't.
advice_to_mgmt: Career development is very important and I'm happy to see the company focusing on it.

review_title: I couldn't care less about perks etc, I work here because the people are great.
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
The company has evolved a lot over the years and I think it's in a really great place right now. I'm happy whenever I'm working on interesting projects with people I respect - I think I got really lucky in that regard by coming to Dropbox. This is still a place for engineers with energy and drive to do great things.

The size of our infrastructure and technical challenges is much higher than people expect. I could be working on infra basically any company in the world right now, but I feel like I have the highest leverage and direct impact at Dropbox than at any alternative.
cons: It's still a growing company and we need to keep scaling the organization. How well will we handle having remote offices, or more of an org chart, or scaling communications as the company gets big? No real problems right now, but it's still a work in progress. (This is something I enjoy by the way.)

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
I have a fierce respect and sense of adoration for the people I work with. My colleagues are helpful, they're ridiculously intelligent, and most importantly, they're down-to-earth, genuinely good people who are committed to creating something special. 
- Leadership is informed, capable, and does a great job empathizing with all areas of the company. Our office lead has spent time on every team to better understand what's working and what's not working so well. My team lead gives me the support I need to do my job well and gives appropriate feedback to help me perform even better. If something about my job is "broken," my team and my lead work together to fix it rather than say "there's not much we can do about that."
- I am challenged to teach myself new things, and I'm also given the latitude to tackle projects that 1) appeal to me and 2) need to be done without the tons of red tape you might find elsewhere. I'm pushed to step outside my comfort zone without being overwhelmed. Also, I'm given lots of opportunity to be recognized for my work.
- Every consideration has been made to ensure that our working environment is healthy, productive, convenient, and fun. The benefits are excellent. My stress levels are low. I look forward to coming to work. 

Dropbox puts its people first, and we return the favor by working hard and thinking creatively every day.
cons:
It can be a challenge working with some users.
- Dropbox is such a complex service that it takes awhile to learn the ropes, and a very long time to become a technical expert.
advice_to_mgmt: Listen to what our users are saying and devote as much time and energy as you can to fixing their (legitimate) pain points. Do more with less. Be concerned by competition, but also let it motivate you to achieve more than they can.

review_title: Excellent job at a company rife with opportunity
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
Dropbox is a company that's growing like wildfire, and with that comes opportunities to grow your career. We're laying the foundation, both technically and culturally, for years to come, and we all have an opportunity to make an impact. This is especially true in New York, where we're building the company's first remote engineering office. I feel that the company headquarters in San Francisco supports us and is empowering us to succeed.

Across the company, I've worked on meaningful projects with incredibly-smart people.
cons: Work-life balance is a tricky thing at a company that's doing so many different things and growing in so many different directions. Dropbox has (to great benefit) been stingy about hiring, but it means that there are fewer people to do more things. Work-life balance is certainly respected, but I find myself sometimes struggling to disconnect, though that may be me more than Dropbox.

review_title: Diverse, high-growth startup who knows how to have fun
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros: Smart people, driven to a common mission to make Dropbox great. Fun atmosphere to counter balance the hard work everyone puts into their own work. Everyone, despite their years of experience, values mastering their own craft. We take our work very seriously, but have we have a lot of fun along the way. As someone who is 40, I enjoy the atmosphere and I feel included in everything that Dropbox does.
cons: Standard growing pains of a high-growth company. Processes are still maturing and management staff is slowly growing. I'm confident we will work out the kinks, but in the meantime we have to endure many changes along the way. The good news is that the changes are in the right direction and every employee has direct input.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
very democratic in all things
humble
accept criticism and work on it (campaigns encouraging diversity)
amazing perks such as 3 gourmet meals a day, gym on site and additional stipend, travel benefits, luxury suite at AT&T park
people are super smart and they only hire the best
cons: growing super fast so there is a lot of change
advice_to_mgmt: keep working on growth for employees.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
I'm in my mid-30s, and I've had plenty of "regular" jobs in the past that required me to work 9-5pm, and asking for time off or asking to work from home made me feel like I wasn't a good employee. At Dropbox, though, the flexibility I have with my hours and working from anywhere other than the office makes me even more productive, surprisingly. All I really need is my computer and wi-fi. 

This allows me to have a work-life balance, and it allows me to cater to my kids' needs whenever I need to. I can be there for my kid's doctor's appointment, I can be there to pick my kids up and drop them off, I can stay at home and work from home if my kid is sick, etc. etc. The flexibility is incredible, and your leads/managers trust you as long as you get the job done, and done well.

The benefits for my family are great, as well. And the number of times they have Dropbox Family Night or Dropbox Kids Night is incredible. I have never wanted to bring my family to my work this much. The team in charge of all these family events really puts their heart into making sure the food and activities are one to remember.
cons: Given how many non-tech "office jobs" I've had in the past, I seriously cannot complain about ANYTHING when it comes to Dropbox. I feel so incredibly lucky to be here, and the number and quality of benefits we get is ridiculously huge. I feel sorry for people whose first job is at Dropbox, because if they were to ever have to go into the real world, they will be extremely disappointed!

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox
pros: I can talk about the food - best culinary team south of the French Laundry. I can talk about having a company box seat to the Giants games. I can even talk about the in-office massage, haircut, gym, gym-laundry service and commuter's benefit. But the best part of working at Dropbox is the brilliant engineers I get to learn from and work with and the focus with which we prioritize our objectives.
cons:
As other reviews have mentioned there remains a little bit of the "bro"-ish culture that's now starting to dissipate (at least in engineering) with the growth of the company. So not too big of a concern.

I wouldn't call this a con but there's more work to do here than you can count and we need more people working here. While the recruiting effort is genuine, there needs to be better maturity/experience around interviews (faster response time, consistent expectation/calibration) without lowering our bar.
advice_to_mgmt: As the company grows, having a better vision of compensation growth, stock refreshers, etc would be great. Knowing that the company values my continued presence and not just as pump-and-dump will go a long way in getting, and retaining, talent.

review_title: Wouldn't want to be anywhere else
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
If you have a vision and can rally a team you can really get a lot done
- Perks (food, gym, massage, food, company trips, happy hour, food) are amazing
- I challenge you to find a better team of people to work with at any other company in the bay area
- There are so many awesome things in the pipeline ;)
cons: The company is growing rapidly so there are still some processes that are less than clear so you have to be comfortable with ambiguity. If you're looking for a small company then Dropbox isn't it and if you're looking for a large company then Dropbox isn't it either. This adolescent stage (just like your teenage years) can be a little strange sometimes.
advice_to_mgmt: The company is growing up, but it needs to stay Dropboxy!

review_title: Top notch engineering team, great perk
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
Definitely one of the best engineering team. 
- A lot of freedom to pursuit even craziest product idea/hack.
- Chance to work with world class designer/product people.
- One of a few companies that will make it BIG.
- Great perks, best food option in the Bay Area.
- Great commute South Bay (office right at the Caltrain station) or San Francisco.
cons: A lot of challenge and competition from other bigger companies.
advice_to_mgmt: Should focus more on the core product, especially the business option.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
The team at Dropbox is truly top notch (across all functions)
- Management cares deeply about empowering employees to get things done
- Everyone is a part of growing and scaling the business
- Awesome perks (specially the Tuck Shop food)
cons:
With growth comes change, and with change comes ambiguity and you've gotta be ok with it
- Org structures are still not fully defined which can lead to inefficiencies --> however management is focused on solving this int he short term!
advice_to_mgmt: Better defining org structures, and increasing direct accountability on leads will be a huge step forward.

review_title: Work with great people, have massive impact
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros: Dropbox should really be one of the companies you are considering joining. We have a great team of people working together to build awesome product that makes life better. Apart from that, pay is good, benefits great and culture amazing.
cons: We have some intense challenges ahead of us so if you want a rest & vest position don't bother applying.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep on being as relaxed and approachable as you are.

review_title: For those who are driven, creative, and super smart but down-to-earth and have high EQ/like positive people
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time
pros: Everyone - from senior leadership to interns - is extraordinarily positive and committed to making the company the best place to work anywhere. That shows up in everything from benefits to the training process to how people work / communicate with each other.
cons: Like any start-up in hypergrowth mode, there are some growing pains and struggles to maintain the culture as the company gets bigger. Dropbox is also in a competitive landscape, so that's a risk--but the upside is incredible, and the journey so far has been more than worthwhile for me.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
Very, very smart people (best engineering team in the valley!)
- Lots of opportunity to improve the product
- Very good at reacting quickly and nimbly to changes in market dynamics, etc.
cons:
Growing this fast incurs a lot of growing pains (systems consistently break and then you have to fix them)
- At times our focus is a little scattered
advice_to_mgmt: Articulate the focus areas a little more clearly

review_title: Doesn't get much better than this -
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
Dropbox is truly one-of-a-kind place. When I was looking at tech companies, I was fortunate enough to be considered at places like Google, Facebook, and Amazon. Frankly, I didn't really seriously consider Dropbox until I received a call from a recruiter who had received my resume, and wanted to set up a phone screen. Wow - was I missing out on the best place to work in the valley right now. Upon receiving an offer here, there was zero question or doubt in my mind about accepting - Google could have come back with all the compensation in the world, but the opportunity to help build the next big thing at Dropbox was unparalleled. Here are a few of the reasons I decided to join, and love working here:
- There's no bureacracy at this place. Sure, we are still small-ish (about 700 now, about 500 when I started), but things just get DONE. There isn't a lot of 'approval' and 'review' for little changes that need to be made or for ideas that folks want to give a whirl. Such a refreshing process.
- The leadership team is phenomenal. There is no hiding behind walls (literally - even our co-founders sit in our open-space desk arrangement amongst everyone else) and they are available and accessible. Exec. team is super grounded and humble, and this allows us to grow in a healthy way, because egos don't get you anywhere here.
- The opportunity that is available is the KEY to joining this place. If you are willing to work super hard and get your hands dirty, you will be able to join products, drive initiatives, and actually get stuff done. Your work doesn't feel menial -it feels like you are actually helping to grow this place.
- The PERKS are just as fabulous (if not more) than any other hot tech company. Why? Because we are still growing, so the perks feel super customized and high touch. There is plenty of pitching myself here because I wonder how I landed this gig. It's a dream.
cons:
It's honestly so fun and social that I sometimes worry about my non-Dropbox life and if I am giving it enough attention. By all means, it is my decision to stay for dinner, happy hours, and other social activities, and there is no pressure to do these things, but they have created such a great environment here that it is easy to get roped in and abandon other parts of your life. Disclaimer: Dropbox is NOT a place that does not support work/life balance. Everyone gets to choose how involved they become!
- Some growing pains. As we hire like crazy this year, we will (and are) experiencing slight growing pains like having the company split into different buildings (they are a 5 minute walk apart, but still changes the dynamic). Inevitable, though, at a company that is succeeding.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you are doing, and don't sell out to politics as we grow! Also, as we continue the push to make Dropbox an exceptionally diverse place to work, let's not forget this initiative and embed this in to our company values long-term.

review_title: I still can't see myself working somewhere else.
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time
pros: The founders (Drew and Arash) are very accessible and highly engaged in the day to day operations of the company - as someone else pointed out, they definitely "walk the walk". One of the biggest benefits i've experienced has been the people - you truly get to work with insanely smart, talented people who are genuinely fun to work with - and this is the result of an intense hiring process that screens out a lot of great candidates. Office perks in SF are fantastic (particularly the world class food) and they're getting better at the remote offices. (Side note about remote offices - they are treated with the same level of importance as the SF office, we get tons of visitors, and people in SF make a point of keeping us informed about what's going on.) Compensation is generally in line with similar positions in the market, depending on role. The company is growing quickly (but responsibly), so there is ample opportunity to grow as new teams are being formed regularly.
cons: The San Francisco office is a bit crowded right now due to rapid growth and the open seating plan; this can make it difficult (but not impossible) to focus on work. Although decisions at the founder level are very transparent to the whole company, some teams don't enjoy the same level of transparency from middle-management. Career path options haven't historically been very transparent, but that's been improving thanks to a massive recent push to improve learning and development.

review_title: Working with very smart and motivated people in a collaborative and impact-driven environment
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
There are so many opportunities to make immediate impact, I leave work feeling deeply satisfied and knowing that I made a difference 
Working alongside extremely talented people, I learn so much every day!
It's a really exciting time to be here -- there's nothing like working at a company with this much on the horizon
cons:
There's so much work to do that I often want to work late
I'm constantly forced to prioritize, since there are so many things I could be focused on

review_title: Dropbox is a great place to work!
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Dropbox tries hard to keep the organization flat and collaborative. It's been refreshing to be able to strategize with my manager vs. trying to please him/her all the time. It really feels like people across all levels want to do what's best for the company.
cons: When there are bad managers, some are afraid to point it out. Middle management management could use a bit of work but eventually these folks leave on their own.

review_title: Surrounded by the best talent you'll find
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time
pros: Amazing people, best in class perks, a company that's doing important things
cons: It's hard work, bc of the huge opportunities ahead of us

review_title: People care about your personal growth
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros: I've been blown away by the people here and the amount of focus they have on bringing the best of the best into this amazing company culture. It's awesome that they emphasize making an impact and keeping their employees happy by continually challenging them and giving them so much awesome stuff to work on.
cons: Since I've started at the company I haven't left work before 7 at night which isn't too late, but just makes me worry a little bit for how long i will start staying in the future when I get more ramped up.
advice_to_mgmt: I'm interested in how promotions will work here once that system is figured out. I'd love to know how this process will go and how transparent it will be.

review_title: Work with incredibly talented, humble, kind colleagues in a fast-paced, collaborative environment
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros: There's so much opportunity to follow your interests and set your own course. Project-based sprints allow you to get things done and acquire a diverse range of experience. The culture is really collaborative and non-hierarchical. Everyone works hard and cares so much about their work.
cons: The downside of so much freedom and independence is that sometimes you have to figure out processes as you go. It's an exciting environment if you're comfortable with change, but might not be best for someone who needs a lot of structure.

review_title: Grow alongside Dropbox and work with talented people.
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros: Opportunity to learn from your peers, challenge yourself, work on variety of projects, in a fun environment
cons: Need to be flexible and open to changes, some projects/goals lack organization

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
The company is growing really fast but not close to the size of Google/FB/Amazon/LinkedIn. That means the impact one can have is significantly larger than working at one of the elite tech titans. Additionally, the company has lots of cash, robust sales growth and a lot of upside so it's not nearly as risky as joining a small start up. There's still a lot of work to do to win the space, however.

Perks are unreal. Free food, free trips, lots of fun etc. Big emphasis on building an inclusive and laid back culture. People are super nice. Biggest pro is probably the people however. Some of the best and brightest engineering talent along with non-eng talent from Google/FB/Bain/i-banking etc. So far I've learned the most from my amazing co-workers!
cons: Because it's still a start-up the hours can be long. I think this is pretty typical of most start-ups however.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep on keeping on.

review_title: Dropbox is the best large software company to work for today
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
The culture is great. The people at Dropbox really care about doing right by their users, all the way to the very top, and it shows. You can sit down at a random table at lunch, introduce yourself, and meet some new people. And it's great that Dropbox's products make money by selling the product to the users -- it's not an advertising or data mining business model where there's a strong tension between what the users what and what the customers want. This means that while working at Dropbox, you can really focus on just making the best experience possible on products that are enormously popular.

While Dropbox isn't really a startup anymore, the office environment is pretty fun, and it feels like they've done an excellent job of scaling up the business while still keeping a great culture. 

This wasn't the case a couple years ago, but Dropbox today is very family-friendly, a huge supporter of women in engineering, and an all-around great place to work.
cons: Dropbox offers less vacation time than many of the other hot companies in the valley (though it offers more than the Oracles and Ciscos of the world).

review_title: Great company culture. Fast growth, tons of opportunity.
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox
pros: company trajectory, opportunity, culture, high caliber talent
cons: work-life balance could improve. People work tirelessly.

review_title: Being surrounded by the caliber of talent Dropbox has is exciting, motivating, and incredibly rewarding.
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
Talented colleagues that are passionate about what they do
Opportunities beyond your core role are ample
Very positive, healthy, supportive, and inclusive work culture
Great emphasis on transparency and making sure everyone's involved
Benefits as good as they get
Some of the best food you can eat in San Francisco
cons:
If you're not a go getter you can get left behind
Kiss your dietary goals goodbye

review_title: Rare chance to experience hyper-growth from inside
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
Experiencing what hyper-growth feels like from inside
- Seeing what it takes to turn a startup into the next big tech company. Fascinating.
- Being able to contribute to this transformation 
- Really really great culture, super flat, keeping an incredible level of transparency and trust even as we grow 
- Some incredible people (creators of Python, Like button, Shazam, etc - seriously?)
- Did not consider myself a foodie, but this IS the best food in SF tech ... or in SF?
cons:
Startup spirit encourages many people to "just go and do it" but that sometimes leads to duplication of efforts across the company 
- We have different versions of Dropbox future and mission (building a home for life, simplifying technology for people, creating a data layer that connects all your devices) - but we're still to agree on a common one
advice_to_mgmt: Keep focusing on preserving great culture. Clarify the bigger vision / mission

review_title: This is the best place to work in the Bay Area. Period.
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros: Great people, great management, great perks, great company vision. The best thing about Dropbox is that employees are empowered to make a genuine difference at the company, no matter the team. We are building the next great tech company together; Dropbox has built an amazing foundation of talented employees that are well rounded and easy to work with.
cons: The bar for hiring is set extremely high. While this a fantastic reputation to have in tech for both my career and the company, it is very tough to get friends hired.

review_title: Challenging work with the best people
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros: The company is growing quickly and so there are many opportunities to work on different challenging projects. Everyone around me is incredibly sharp and makes me want to bring my a-game every day. The perks are incredible and really make me feel like I'm valued here. Work/life balance is surprisingly good. I work really hard during the week with a team of people I actually like, but then am free to head home and leave the work behind at the end of the day.
cons: There are certain processes and tools that you may take for granted as "just being there" at a more established company. Dropbox is still at a pretty early stage as a business, so there are a lot of things that still need to be built out internally. It's cool to get to influence how these processes and systems are implemented, but it can also be a pain.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros: The caliber of the people at Dropbox is unreal. The most amazing combination of intelligence, hunger to win, and humility. They young employees are incredibly talented (much more talented than I was at their age), and the PhDs here are humble, excited and eager to teach and to share their expertise.
cons: Really none. Really. The only con is that sometimes I don't feel like I deserve to work here.

review_title: Great opportunity to learn and build out your skill set - especially considering the growth path of the company
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
The cofounders really care about the people here, and you see this on a daily basis. The decision making process at the exec level is really transparent, so you get to learn a lot on a broader company level (what our 3/6/12 month goals are, why they are that way, what we could of done better in the last year, etc.). There are times when I feel like part of my job is getting paid to go to business school, how awesome is that?

There are a lot of great people here to help teach you "stuff". (Sorry for the engineers reading this part, I'll let our eng gals and guys speak more to that sphere). You want to learn Photoshop? SQL, Hive, Python, how our infrastructure works? It is nice to know that you can never stop learning. 

Especially for those of us early in their career, a culture of learning and getting connected with the right people and teams is crucial. It is also nice to know that it is at a company that is not yet 3, 5, 10, or 30 thousand people... Lots of opportunities, lots of growth ahead, easier to navigate and learn from different parts of the business, etc. Not trying to say big corporations don't have great opportunities, just that they have different ones.

I could go on and on about perks. But I won't. Besides the Tuck Shop... their food is legendary. Also, +1 to the kickass office space... and the kickass office team! 

What else? Truthfully, some of my closest friends in San Francisco are dropboxers, in and outside of the office. It's also important to note that many of my professional mentors and leaders that I look up to are also here. It's nice to have that spectrum of choice :)

My leads ("managers") have all exposed me to different expertise and ways of thinking. I've reported to a cofounder of a startup we've acquired, a military vet with an MBA, a consultant that worked in London and Russia, and a former professional Drummer that played on stage at Lollapalooza.

I learn from sales people, I learn from engineers, I learn from designers, I learn from our COO, our CFO, our cofounders, and just about every other single person at this company. I wake up relatively stoked to come in to the office and feel satisfied enough to leave at a reasonable hour. I take vacations. Sometimes I leave at 4pm, sometimes 5 or 6, sometimes 9. I enjoy my weekends. I have built solid skills set entirely at work. I don't drink the Koolaid, it is just really hard not to be happy here when you work with fun, smart, and friendly people.

One of the best pieces of advice I received growing up was "surround yourself with people that are smarter than you". We have leaders in design, engineering, and business. My teammates and friends at Dropboxer never cease to impress me. Sometimes, I wish it was me that felt like Einstein, but for now I am completely content with feeling like Curious George. The efforts and outputs of my peers both push me and remind me that there is plenty more to learn, and PLENTY more to do.
cons:
Structure and career pathing isn't *yet* as defined as it would be at a Google or Facebook. But what do you expect? We are currently ~700 employees and last year at this time we were ~250 - of course there are going to be some growing pains. 

It is something currently being addressed at a company wide level and the leadership knows how important it is as we grow, so I don't imagine it being a bullet point in this section 6-12 months (max) from now.

review_title: Smart, humble, fun people. A protective and proud culture that strives to be different and actually succeeds.
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
The people are amazing, forget superficial coworker relationships...have made a ton of close friendships
- Extremely high hiring bar, not just smarts but culture/attitude/personality wise - keeping us "Dropboxy", which just means that you kick butt at your job, you help improve others around you, and you contribute to making the workplace a better experience for all
- The product is truly innovative, if you think its the same as competitors - try them for yourself and decide
- Best food in the valley. amazing office team, really care about employees and everyone has a voice
cons:
less structured career paths (it's a startup after all)
- working on improving training and development (resources are there but you have to be proactive)
- company is in a maturation phase, growing pains
advice_to_mgmt: You're on the right path...continue to empower your employees, build strong leaders within the teams (invest in them and their success). Keep making bets to make this company iconic.

review_title: Working at Dropbox makes me happy every day.
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
Dropbox is constantly changing, open to adapting to new good ideas and changing course to keep on a winning track. I've worked a lot of places where senior leaders want you to sit down, shut up, and do your job - that's exactly the opposite of things here. There are so many opportunities to step up and help make things better.

--I consistently find my co-workers to be unbelievably smart, incredibly driven, and entirely dedicated to company success over the long term. Everyone 'gets it' across the whole company, from sales to recruiting to engineering. It makes it fun to problem solve as a team.

--We're working on some incredibly tough, highly motivating problems. Few companies deal with the amount of data and global footprint we manage and seek to expand on a daily basis. It's an exciting, big challenge, and invigorating every day.

--The culture and company morale are outstanding, buoyed by a great team combined with delightful daily experiences like the Tuck Shop or awesome new Dropbox swag. It always feels like people are happy and excited to be here, and that sentiment is highly infectious.
cons:
The constant change can be unnerving for some people, especially the change on the constantly reorganizing business / sales side. I enjoy reconfiguring as needed so we can best tackle the challenges ahead, but this can also lead to many feeling we lack of stability in daily processes or job responsibilities. Some people find the change overwhelming at times.

--Dropbox is incredibly generous with benefits and equity, but a bit cheaper when it comes to annual salaries. It's still big-risk, big-reward over here, which does keep us all invested in winning big in the long term.
advice_to_mgmt: The senior leadership of Dropbox sent out an email to the whole company asking for our thoughts on company priorities a few weeks ago. I sent all my suggestions in then!

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros:
The people I work with are extraordinary – fun, humble, smart
- My leads, in particular, have gone above and beyond the "call of duty." Very interested in understanding whole picture – what do I want out of my role, my career, etc. 
- The office is unreal. I'm spoiled and never have to spend money outside of work. I have a gym, a 3-meal-a-day kitchen, a barista... 
- Coming to work is genuinely fun
cons: There isn't a clear career path, given that the company is growing and changing always. To me, this is awesome. To others, this might be stressful.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the awesome work.

review_title: Incredible company to work for - if you get an offer, take it!
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
Teammates are incredibly smart, motivated, mission-oriented and humble. It is a joy to come to work every day!
- Level of ownership over your work or projects is unparalleled, in my experience. I have had the opportunity to work on impactful projects within my own team as well as cross-functionally, and if you're on a project, you have a voice at the table - no matter how senior-level that table may be.
- Senior management is very transparent - open Q&A every week, board meeting reviews, company-wide updates, etc. I feel like I know what is going on with other teams and at a company level. Our exec team trusts us to the point of being able to share a lot of information (product development, financials, etc.) that might be kept confidential at other/larger companies.
- My lead gives me support and advice rather than micro-managing or delegating work to me... I essentially get to "be my own boss" on a day-to-day basis. That is partially a function of how my team is structured, but it also reflects our belief that you are going to be inherently driven to do your best work and don't need to be micro-managed.
- Tuck Shop (our cafe). Enough said. 
- Competitive compensation and great benefits (gym, cell phone, Caltrain, commuter benefit, shuttle in the city, 401k match, charitable donation match, etc.).
cons: We may have tripled in size in the past year and a half, but we are still a start-up in many respects. Things change fast, and your responsibilities are often a level or two higher than your role may indicate. That's a great opportunity to gain experience quickly, but a promotion that reflects how much you've taken on may lag behind a bit (and work-life balance may suffer in the near-term). That said, addressing these issues are something that our management team and People Ops is actively working on.
advice_to_mgmt: Recognize and reward your top performers and keep the company as transparent as it has been historically!

review_title: I love the people I work with
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
There are two things that define working at Dropbox: 1) the people 2) management
1) Everyone at Dropbox is incredibly smart and hard working. I love that every day I come in and get to work with incredible people who make me smarter and better at my job.
2) Dropbox really cares about employees. People Ops (our HR) approaches benefits in terms of how the benefit will impact the employee's life. Every benefit they have makes employees' lives easier so that we can all do our best work. It's really incredible to work at a place that cares this much about how productive I can be and takes care of me so that I can do my best work.
cons: The biggest thing Dropbox is looking to improve in the future is career paths. There isn't a clear roadmap for each employee right now, but management is working on it.

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros: amazing people, rewarding work, great perks
cons: no cons here - Dropbox is great
advice_to_mgmt: keep doing what you're doing

years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for more than a year
pros:
Most of the employees are really smart, kind, and care a lot about whether Dropbox succeeds.
 - With hundreds of millions of users and only around 700 employees, there's a huge opportunity for impact.
 - Working at a company that produces a product that so many people know, and appreciate is really rewarding.
 - Rapid growth means that a lot of new opportunities emerge, no matter the role you join
cons:
People here work really hard. Almost nobody is working a set 9-5 day unless they put their own boundaries around work because of other very important commitments.
 - You have to remain flexible. Depending on the situation, the role you're recruited for may be different that the role that's needed a couple weeks or months in.

review_title: Best company I've ever worked for.
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros: Great people with an awesome culture. Everyone I work with is extremely smart, capable and driven. Ownership comes with the territory, yet people don't get in the way of execution. Dropbox treats employees well and really provides a sense of meaningful work life/balance. It also doesn't hurt that the benefits are great and the food is amazing.
cons: Some lack of organizational structure makes it hard to understand who does what. That being said, this hasn't interfered with getting things done because everyone tends to "own it". The company is now grown to a size where we have different areas for different employees (ie 2 levels in China Basin) which makes it hard to get to know people that are in different areas.
advice_to_mgmt: Never lose sight of building an everlasting culture. It's in our DNA and I hope it never goes away no matter how big we get.

review_title: One of, if not the best place I've worked

Compensation seems fair and training is offered when needed, but there are plenty of capable and helpful people to help you in areas you may need improvement with.
cons: As with anywhere work/life balance can be difficult, but my manager frequently stresses to take off weekends. I've worked for several of the best startups, now public and Dropbox is competitive with all.

review_title: I love the company culture; you can sit down with anyone and have an amazing conversation.
years_at_company: I have been working at Dropbox full-time for less than a year
pros: Dropbox encourages people to pursue their passions, both within and outside of their core job responsibilities. For example, there is a music room in the office, so people who love playing music can jam. There is a gym, so people who love lifting weights or doing yoga can do that. Often times, the amazing amenities get incorporate into peoples' job functions; for example, I am a recruiter, and often I use music to connect with candidates and help share the joy of the office.
cons:
I think the biggest challenge is work/life balance. Because the office is a fun place to be, sometimes folks have a hard time leaving. I think it would actually help Dropbox if the work culture was slightly less insular. 

Also, being a fast-growing but still relatively small company, often times there is less structure within job functions; this can be a pro or a con, depending on what you're looking for in your career.
advice_to_mgmt: Sometimes work allocation is fairly uneven; there should be more clear ways to distribute work, and validate and reward those who put in extra effort.

years_at_company: I have been working at Amazon full-time
pros: Looks nice and it’s awful
cons: Nothing to be described

review_title: You Get What You Put In
years_at_company: I have been working at Amazon full-time
pros: Really smart people, a lot of opportunity for growth, always encouraged to be innovative, think big, and create something new. Competitive salary and benefits with other major tech companies. 100% self motivating work environment. No dress code and 4 legged friends are welcome.
cons: You have to be self motivated. NO ONE will hold your hand and tell you that you're doing a great job. If you need constant affirmations from management, this company isn't for you.
advice_to_mgmt: More on-boarding training before new employees are thrown in the fire. The first couple of weeks can be very confusing on where to find the information you need that pertains to your job.

years_at_company: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
Jeff Bezos and his "S-Team" are brilliant and continue to make great decisions for long-term growth. 

You work with smart people, you work on exciting projects, you are pushed to your limits...which can be rewarding when you accomplish great things. The diversity of the potential work and innovation can be very alluring. I've often called Amazon my "Sexy Mistress...she's emotionally abusive, but she's so sexy that I go back for more punishment."
cons: The management process is abusive, and I'm currently a manager. I've seen too much "behind the wall" and hate how our individual performers can be treated. You are forced to ride people and stack rank employees...I've been forced to give good employees bad overall ratings because of politics and stack ranking.
advice_to_mgmt: Don't pretend that the recent NY Times article was all about "isolated incidents". The culture IS abusive and it WILL backfire once stock value starts to drop. I'm an 8 year veteran and I no longer recommend former peers to interview with Amazon.

years_at_company: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros:
I've been at Amazon for a month now, and I've seen none of the horror stories being communicated to the public, although Amazon is a large enough company that I'm sure there are good pockets and bad pockets. Everyone here is really smart, and wants to succeed both personally, and as a company. People collaborate and help each other, focus on data, and truly focus on the customer. Every company I've ever worked for talks about how important the customer is, but on day 2, they're forgotten. Amazon seems to genuinely focus on what's best for the customer, and it's awesome to be in meetings where people actually bring that up, and make decisions focused on long-term customer satisfaction.

The opportunities to learn here are literally unlimited, and the opportunity to take on new responsibility is as well. I honestly believe you can be as awesome as you want here.
cons:
No cons, so far - seriously. Like I said, I'm sure Amazon has some bad pockets in it here and there, but this is an amazing job, an amazing opportunity, and the biggest thing I have to complain about is that it's a little chilly in our building. I can live with that.

Does Amazon demand high quality, measurable results? Yes! Is it hard work? Yes! Is it rewarding? Yes! So I'm not calling that a 'con'. Work/life balance seems comparable to other places I've worked - not worse.

review_title: Can be amazing for some people, horrible for others
years_at_company: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Amazon is doing lot's of cool stuff...but lots of boring stuff too. There are really well run teams...and very badly run teams. The experience for software managers and engineers is all over the board, from really run low operational load teams to teams where people burn out after a year.

 - Amazon is built, quite deliberately, to be Darwinian. You can generally expect that anyone who's been here for more than 2 years is competent and motivated or they wouldn't have survived. You can count on them as long as your priorities are aligned. There aren't many slackers here, and they don't survive long.
 - We work on so much stuff that there's always an opportunity to find amazing cool stuff to work on (note that it's an 'opportunity', one that you have to pursue)
 - A chance to make a huge difference
 - A place where you can learn a lot about all kinds of things, both technical and about yourself
 - Amazon encourages high mobility - even your manager can't prevent you from moving to another team within 6 weeks (normally, more than a few months under unusual conditions).
 - Your friends and family have actually heard of the place you work and have at least a vague notion of what Amazon does without you having to explain
cons:
You're responsible for your own career progression and finding the places and teams that are doing the stuff you want to do. No one is going to take you by the hand and help you with that.
- Amazon is built, quite deliberately, to be Darwinian. The strong survive and the weak perish (metaphorically speaking) and the 'bar' is constantly increasing. The level of performance that would have been acceptable five years ago will get you canned today. It's a kind of crucible that'll help you develop a harder edge, if you can survive, that can serve you well in your career and in life, but it's often not a pleasant experience.

I wouldn't recommend it as a place to work for just anyone.
advice_to_mgmt: Stack ranking is a horrible practice since it's rife with favoritism. It's also not Amazonian in that it's not data based (arbitrarily designating a certain percentage of employees that must be put on performance management isn't a data driven criterion) and it's not frugal (effectively forcing an individual out of the company in one division who would make the grade in another is either retaining someone who doesn't meet the bar or a waste of talent). The goal is to force managers to actually make the hard decisions about how their team members compare with each other (not everyone can be exceptional), but it has more defects than virtues. Replace it with a common comparison of each person against the bar for their position, based on data. The percentages that are assigned to each performance category will turn out how they turn out, but there will be an evaluation mechanism that's fair and frugal.

review_title: We are now in a world where we are condescended to by our inferiors
years_at_company: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros: This company gets A list performance from C list employees. The culture is quick and hard charging. You are always working in relevant and meaningful projects.
cons:
Maybe because the company recruits C listers who have neither merit (intelligence, strategic vision) nor pedigree (academic or professional accomplishments), most of those who become successful do so in treacherous, low cunning ways.

Imagine the Lannisters in Game of Thrones attacking the Starks in Game of Thrones; or Rawls and Burrell attacking McNulty and Daniels in The Wire; or Barrow and O'Brien attacking Mr Bates in Downton Abbey. This is every day leadership behavior at Amazon. The culture at Amazon is so infested with these middling talent weasels who have juked the stats and schemed their way to positions of power that new employees coming in actually start thinking that this behavior is normal and expected if you want to "manage people."

The work itself was stimulating and fulfilling, but the sneering condescension of the d bags that cheated and skated their way through high school and party colleges, then just converted their winky nod nod good 'ol boy shenanigans into a "ask no questions, have no introspection" company culture have made manifest some of the worst criticisms of capitalism. Any left leaning political aspirant would look at this business organism and immediately have content to lash out against the corruption that can come in free enterprise where hard work is not rewarded, and the connected, incestuous, privileged class lounge their way to wealth while treating their employees and customers like some kind of filth their shoe picked up on the street.
advice_to_mgmt:
Bezos you bought the Washington Post and hired Jay Carney to be your PR head. There is nothing I can write here that you would deign listen to, because you are a hack. You must be mad that Expedia beat you to the punch and hired Chelsea Clinton to serve on their board of directors.

For those grasping Weasels that have squirmed and back stabbed your way to success, you know who you are. You won't care what is written here because "You got yours, Eff them."

For those truly diligent and hard working employees that don't want to believe the story from NY times that called Amazon a "Snake Pit" because you don't want to think you actually are involved in such a dystopian landscape of anti-business ethics: "Always yell with the crowd. It is the only means to be safe."
