years_at_company: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 10 years
pros: You can make your career at Amazon whatever you want it to be. I started in Finance and although I was good at it, I did not enjoy it as much as I believed I should. I then pursued Program Management and later Product Management, where I found my passion. The great thing about Amazon is that internal transfers are not only expected, but encouraged. I personally move about every 3 years, but the duration one stays in a role greatly varies across the company. It's all about continuing to learn, feeling there is meaning in what you are doing, and finding things you are passionate about. Your time at Amazon will be what you make of it. I enjoy working with extremely intelligent people on a daily basis and the ability to take full ownership of my work. I should mention that I am a mother of two children and have great work-life balance.
cons: The Day 1 culture at Amazon means many things, but one of them is solving new industry problems. If you are not comfortable with ambiguity and solving problems that have never been encountered before (to your knowledge), you may not enjoy working at Amazon. Depending on your role, I have heard that work-life balance can be more challenging for those starting early in their careers and looking to move up the ladder quickly. However, if you set expectations with your manager with open conversations about your desired flexibility, you will likely find an arrangement that works for you. Work-life balance is something you create for yourself as a priority, it is not automatically handed to you.
advice_to_mgmt: I've been fortunate to always have a great manager at Amazon, but I've seen others that do not. Your relationship with your manager will be a major factor in your enjoyment at work. IE: micro-managing vs empowerment, etc. For this reason, I'd encourage management to be open to feedback and reflect on your management style. Sometimes what you mistake for a weakness in your team's ability to deliver results could actually reflect a weakness in your management style. If you see high turnover in your team, perhaps take some time to reflect on your own actions rather than assuming they were 'not a good fit for the role.'

review_title: Fast paced learning for those that want to learn

cons: In order to get a pay raise for a job you’re already doing, you still have to interview for it...you get taught new skills, and get licensed to operate different machines, but you still get entry level pay. Rather than get moved up based on your work ethic and knowledge of the position, you have to wait for a certain position to open and apply...even though you’ve been doing the job already without the pay. It’s frustrating.
advice_to_mgmt: I know the process for advancement is network wide at Amazon, but there are circumstances where an individual is trained and excels at certain tasks and is just overlooked because of the internal interview process. Promotions from within should be given to those that know the job and are already preforming the job.

review_title: Amazing place to learn for several years, hard to stay long-term
years_at_company: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Working at Amazon is like attending the most cutting-edge technology and business school you can imagine. The hiring bar is extremely high, so everyone is extremely talented. Amazon VP's are some of the smartest people you will ever meet. The whole company moves so quickly that every day you are working on a new major initiative. The leadership principles are literally used everyday - people quote them in meetings, and the company only focuses on customers, never on competitors. It's quite remarkable. If you get an offer to work at Amazon, take it.
cons: I stayed for over 6 years which put me above 98% of other Amazonians (there's a tool called "oldfart" that compares your tenure to other employees). Most people only last 2-3 years for several reasons. First, the pace is relentless which at first is exhilarating but becomes downright fatiguing. Second, Amazon doesn't really care about you as a person - only as a productive cog in the machine. Third, the RSU award program is ok, but total comp is really only great if the stock is climbing 30% a year. Finally, everyone wants to hire an ex-Amazonian right now. When you combine these, Amazon becomes an amazing training ground, but not a great place to stay long-term.
advice_to_mgmt: Amazon comp is decent, but many other top tier companies can match it with better benefits. PTO is weak and employee perks like discounts are non-existent. The 401(k) is limited and many other companies offer better stock vesting plans. Despite attempted reforms, end-of-year ratings are problematic and promotions are far too bureaucratic.

pros: I've been here for almost 6 years and I think the experience varies a lot from team to team. It can be very rewarding. It is fun to be able to work somewhere that people instantly recognize.
cons: This is by far the most frustrating place I have worked. Employees are pitted against each other. Every conversation is contentious and results in an argument, most of the time the loudest or most persistent employee wins without regard to the validity of their argument. You must learn how to navigate corporate politics well or you will not move up the ladder.
advice_to_mgmt: In my particular department, they need to more clearly communicate vision. It mostly feels like Amazon is a machine and it's hard to say if anybody has any real control over it.

review_title: Fine place to work if you like being physical and are looking for a part time job.
years_at_company: I worked at Amazon part-time for less than a year
pros: Easy (but physical) work and nice co-workers. $15 minimum wage was nice. There is a lot of room for moving up into management if the shift assistants/managers like you (or if you work there long enough).
cons: Management does not notice when people work hard; such a lack of appreciation. There were people who would stand around talking all day but management liked them more than hard workers (so much favoritism). Impossible to be full-time if you’re a level 1 associate. 90+ degrees in the summer and fall and not enough fans inside the warehouse. No communication between management of the front and back half of the week. Popularity contest when picking ambassadors.
advice_to_mgmt: Give credit to people who actually work hard.

review_title: A lot to learn, a challenging environment
years_at_company: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 5 years
pros: You have the opportunity to work on a scale that is only found in a handful of companies. Generally, the team has the flexibility to determine how they work as long as they get the job done. Amazon encourages mobility, giving you the ability to work in multiple teams, with different technical and/or business challenges.
cons: A culture that wants you to eat/drink and sleep Amazon in order to succeed. Your role becomes more and more political and there are more and more bureaucratic challenges as your scope grows. It is too easy to burn yourself out, from the TPM role it is too to be responsible for others burning themselves out - you need to own and drive what your healthy balance of ownership, energy is and need to know that yours may not always match what is expected from you to do your job.

years_at_company: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: The company will give you opportunities to do meaningful things every day. It's run like 1000s of little startup companies, with each two-pizza team owning a significant chunk of work. Decision making is pushed down to the lowest levels, and teams have a lot of autonomy to decide on what tools and technologies to use to get the job done.
cons: Staff turnover and rotation seems to be a constant, but I think that's pretty norm for our industry.

years_at_company: I have been working at Amazon full-time for less than a year
pros: Amazon base pay is $15 the hour with a .60 shift differential for working at night. That is for all workers regardless if seasonal or full time associate. However, once you are a full time associate, after 6 months you get an additional .25 and continues after 6 more months and so on until about $18.xx and I believe if you work the weekends you get an additional dollar. So if you work there for 3 years night time and weekends, you can potentially earn about $19.
cons: I dislike working at night but there is a lot more pros than cons.
advice_to_mgmt: Train many people in other areas than normal because gives a sense of value to workers.

review_title: Job Flexibility and easy-going job with fair pay
years_at_company: I have been working at Amazon part-time for more than a year
pros: I choose my own shifts, may can cancel any shift outside of a 24 hour window and only need to work one shift a month if I so desire. Once the responsibilities are job expectations are learned, the job is fun and easy. Pay is fair @ $15 an hour.
cons: Shifts are grabbed quickly (within a 1 minute window) as they ‘drop’ each evening. I have a second part-time job to help with some financial obligations, but because I enjoy my job and the flexibility I’m given, I’ve remained after being employed with Amazon after one year. Training is just one day and a bit dismantled seeming; one trainer for 10 new employees with little time to train efficiently. Just when you think you’re getting the hang of taking hours quickly, they’re hiring 10 new employees for your home-site.
advice_to_mgmt: Hire more Prime Now Managers; provide at least two training days; provide a bigger stagging area at the BDN store; hire managers with years of leadership experience or ‘life’ experience.

review_title: Good company but you won't get promoted.
years_at_company: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: My team is wonderful. There is a great work/life balance. Everyone is professional and smart. I feel constantly challenged by my managers and encouraged to explore all kinds of new ways to do our work more efficiently and to innovate.
cons: I am underemployed. I have a license in my profession that requires 7 years of advanced schooling before sitting for that license. In contrast, MBAs are hired at a higher level than me. The promotional process has looked for a "unicorn," which is a fantastic beast that does not exist. It was great to learn here, but there is no upwards trajectory. This has a disproportionate impact on women and people of color, who are consistently hired with the same credentials as people in a traditionally higher level role than the rest of us.
advice_to_mgmt:
Hire for the right level. Do not hire high functioning, licensed professionals for work that does not require that license, and then use the fact that the job description does not technically require said license as a reason for slower promotions. Do a deep dive on the numbers and how this breaks down by underrepresented minorities. Consider tailoring base compensation to the amount of time and education represented in those numbers. Presumably licensed professionals in non-license required jobs nevertheless have the same bills as other people with those licenses (e.g., student loans.)

I really like this company and want to help it succeed, but I also need to be mindful of my own career trajectory and right now this company = status quo for the foreseeable future.

review_title: Amazon Game Studios is a Mess
years_at_company: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: They pay top dollar and the benefits in terms of healthcare are excellent.
cons: The game studios division is a giant mess and over time it is getting worse not better. I moved my entire family more than once to work on projects. There was always a big rush to get me in position. Only when I got there I find that the project has no proper production discipline, blind management, and a firm belief that if you just put a plan to paper it will happen. We went through an exhaustive effort to create a better publishing structure with milestones and gates, only to have it ignored 2 months after we started. After a few years here I felt drained of energy. The organization is so complex, getting anything approved or let alone finding who is in charge of a certain project is a tremendous task. And then when it all went south they hit the LAYOFF button. Laid off 200+ people...everyone except the management who actual made the awful decisions. We let go of some amazing talent that had long advocated against the decisions management was making. To add insult to injury I had to try and go around a beg for another job in the company - re-interviewing just like a new employee. Only thing is the terrible reputation of the games division inside the company is like the kiss of death with other teams.
advice_to_mgmt:
Re-think how you approach the "Hire and develop the best" leadership principle.
Take a deep dive into how other game devs and their use of Associate Producers and EPs to keep a dev team on task. 
Don't just hire older game devs because of what they did in the past. Look for new talent dying to prove themselves. 
Actually trust the market research you are collecting instead of your own gut. Doing the latter has gotten you nowhere.
Someone needs to put the big boy pants on and combine Amazon and Twitch orgs so that they are on the same page. Both are going to lose out on the gaming opportunity if they stay divided.

review_title: Interesting projects and great domain movability
years_at_company: I have been working at Amazon full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Amazon has a lot of interesting projects and is very product focused as a company. Amazon likes engineer to have ownership, meaning that a developer takes responsibility and has freedom to design and implement his/her product features. It's easy to transfer to another projects to gain different domain of knowledge. Because of the ownership mentality, the company also has many hands-on volunteer programs for career development, i.e. interview bar raiser, security certifier, SDE bootcamp trainer, API reviewer, etc. Even though ambiguity exists in every projects, the product goal is clearly guided by the company leadership principles. The company is very good at commercializing technology for its customers so the chance of SDE's contribution making to the end user stage is very high. As in the tech industry, there are some crunch time when major holiday season approaches, but the company as a whole cares about work-life balance. Flexible hour and working from home are commonly seen among teams.
cons:
For external hire, Amazon has higher bar in terms of experience. i.e. x number of years in y company is not equivalent to x number of years in Amazon.

The research effort is proportionally small comparing to other mega tech companies. Research projects have limited resource and can be cancelled quickly if not meeting deadline. 

Contribution to engineering community is relatively small comparing to other tech companies.
advice_to_mgmt:
Contribute more back to the engineering community. 

Employee benefit is above average, but still not as good as other big tech companies. Considering increasing the benefit to retain talents.

review_title: Warehouse associate, full time for over two years
years_at_company: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros: Great starting pay and the ability to get raises very quickly. Full training in all areas are offered and if your willing to work hard and sweat everyday for 10 hours a day, 4 days a week, then this is the job for you. The 4 day weeks go by quick, it can be exhausting so proper rest and a healthy lifestyle will help you stay strong within this company. Beat benefits as well once you are a hired on as a full time employee.
cons: After 3 years of working with the company you "cap out" at $15.75, meaning you can no longer make any more money than that as a tier 1 associate. Your expected to want to move up in the company and that is the only way to make a better hourly wage, by advancing into management and operations management positions if there are any openings.

years_at_company: I worked at Amazon full-time for more than a year
pros:
great for introverts
- 3 day weekend, work 4 ten hour shifts. More time for yourself!
- easy but just a lot of work to do, BUT that makes the day go by faster 
- the higher up’s are always so friendly and helpful. Loved every one of my AM’s and PA’s. OP’s were wonderful too
- For your first four weeks, you attend a class once a week hosted by HR where you can ask and talk about pretty much anything. This is awesome for newcomers
- HR also throws you “birthday parties.” 
- learned how to properly lift and use box cutter, which is extremely useful in real life
- you can use your time off anytime you want and they won’t question you about it.
- You have sick time, unpaid time, paid time off, and vacation time 
- set schedule
- benefits are great 
- perks are great! I got free tickets to a local water park and I believe you get discount for Verizon or some phone company too. They have discounts for pretty much everything. You just have to look it up. 
- they accept pretty much anyone. Didn’t go through an interview. 
- pay is good. $15 all around the nation is not bad. If you live near a big city, you get paid more. Got paid $15.70 since Seattle was next to us. 
- great career opportunities. Within working for a few months, they asked me if I wanted to be a learning ambassador, which is great start if you want to work your way up. Know a guy who became PA within just a few months as well

Honestly not a bad company. Worked here for a year. Left because my husband got stationed in Hawaii and there’s no amazon here unfortunately. That would’ve been awesome though
cons:
long hours of heavy lifting back to back
- super sore coming home from every shift. Would not recover until two days into my weekend
- long hours. Show up to work when it’s still dark outside. By the end of your shift, it’s still dark. Come home, can’t really eat a big dinner or spend time with family because you need to go to bed right when you get home. Feels like your day is already wasted. 
- you gain 10 hours of paid time off once you work 350 hours. That’s very little for all that time you worked

review_title: Great place to work that values quality of life and family
years_at_company: I worked at VMware full-time for more than 8 years
pros: VMware is a big company but in many ways had a startup vibe. That was great because the resources and infrastructure of a big company were there, but it gave most people I worked with freedom to work on many projects, influence, move around, and contribute in many ways. Plus, many things moved faster than they might at other companies of the same size. Perks were really great including bonuses, events on the campus, opportunities, etc.
cons: The biggest con is the annual layoff. During most of the years I was there, we were growing like crazy, beating expectations, gaining in stock price, etc. It was always positive and upward. However, every single January, it was known that there would be a round of layoffs, even when all numbers were looking great as they almost always were. Management called it restructuring. But, over the years, some really good people were let go for no apparent reason. Then to add insult to injury, a week or two later, there would be a company quarterly meeting discussing how VMware was doing so well and is still hiring, but they had to make some changes. It always felt dishonest and the sympathy for those let go came across as disingenuous.
advice_to_mgmt: January was always a nerve racking month and it completely destroyed any sense of loyalty to the company. I know a few people that completely changed their perception of VMware after a colleague of theirs was let go with no apparent rhyme or reason. Many people left shortly after as a result of losing loyalty to the company or for just being stressed out about themselves getting cut the next year.

review_title: Best place I have ever worked
years_at_company: I worked at VMware full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
VMware is a much loved brand, with a massive community following in the industry. The premises (see what I did there) at Palo Alto HQ is a joyful place to work. There are several restaurants onsite, with coffee, ice cream, and every building has at least one kitchen stocked with soda, espresso machines, healthy and unhealthy snacks, peanut butter, bread, fruit, you name it. Over the years I have brought my family here to see the turtles, watch seasonal events that they throw, and even feed the turtles.

As for the technology, VMware have there staple diet of vSphere, but don't be fooled into thinking this is still just a virtualization company. With acquisitions such as Nicera that made NSX possible, and features such as vSAN, their staple diet is strong. Over recent years they have brought in some amazing talent, and the technical leadership is second to none. I'm talking about Chris Wolf, Joe Baguley, Bruce Davie, Christos Karamanolis, and Kit Colbert just to name a few.

What makes VMware successful today isn't just their core vSphere platform, but their ability to run it successfully in the public cloud (AWS, Google, Azure) and now bring in containers. I should also mention that in my day to day interactions with customers, other lesser known products such as vRealize Operations, Automation, Orchestrator, vCloud Director and Log Insight mean this is truly a world-class enterprise solution.

I know that many of you will be thinking I am talking like a 'fan boi', well maybe, but you must realize (pun intended) that this is the heart of what VMware is about. There is a real passion, especially among the technical engineering BUs, including the field (PSO, SE), for what VMware is about.

Pat Gelsinger was voted #1 CEO, and during my time there I had personally received emails from him in response to feedback I gave. There are not many other companies with over 22,000 employees that get this level of attention. He is also extremely committed to the community I was talking about. At VMworld this year (2019) he was at two community events in person, talking with both employees and customers.

During my time at VMware I worked in two countries, across 3 different business units, and what a ride.
cons:
Like any company there are some bad people, however I still hope this is the minority at VMware.

Unfortunately it was the actions of one particular individual which led me to leave the company. My successful trajectory came to a sudden stop due to this person. My manager.
advice_to_mgmt:
Read my cons above. I actually took this particular issue to senior (VP level) leadership. While I felt supported and was offered an alternative team to work with, no action was taken on this person. Nothing at all. I didn't even know if (or how) there was a process to report this to HR without logging an internal ticket, and I feared he would see it.

Please look after your most talented staff, and watch for bad management. Remember, people don't leave companies, they leave managers.

years_at_company: I have been working at VMware full-time for less than a year
pros:
My team is composed of very smart and very kind people who work well together. We get stuff done! I've only been here a few months, but they are very understanding of my career change and are helping me learn the ropes and the company as time goes by (even though they were very busy when I first started with many things going on, so I appreciate their help!). 

I get to work from home as much as I want and have yet to take any PTO, but the unlimited PTO option is pretty cool and I look forward to utilizing that in the future when I need to. Orientation was AWESOME, and I learned so many soft skills I didn't even realize I was lacking. This company really seems to care about culture and treating employees with respect. I look forward to using the skills they taught me to help the company in keeping to their high standards. 

It seems from other reviews that managers can make or break your time here. So far my managers and teammates have been nothing less than stellar and just so cool, so I feel my time here will continue to be a 5 star rating. I'm excited to keep learning and honing my skills and giving the best work possible.

The interview process for my position was grueling but honestly I feel in hindsight it was a pro. It really helped to encourage me that my skills were up to par with what they were looking for.
cons: Orientation didn't happen until 3 months after I was hired. Felt very lost as to who and what VMware was exactly, and still am not entirely sure what the different softwares I'm working on are about (I don't come from a tech background). I've been told a few times but there's so many different ones, and new features constantly being added, and they can sound so complicated that it's hard to keep it all straight. I'm sure with time this will get easier though.
advice_to_mgmt: I feel there could definitely be a better on-boarding process for newbies. Maybe a packet that goes over everything more in depth that's related to that specific role? Orientation should probably be within the first month of being hired to help us understand the company values and our place in it better.

review_title: Your manager determines your success at VMware
years_at_company: I have been working at VMware full-time for more than a year
pros:
Your career journey/success at VMware will be defined by your manager. Work/Life Balance, Upward Mobility, Cross Training or any career advancement is only existent if you have a manager and leadership team that will advocate on behalf of you and celebrate your accomplishments. Advocating on behalf of yourself only goes so far when BU management has their favorites.

EPIC Values is a joke and no one is actually held accountable to them. Vmware doesn't have a formal review process which is problematic because your manager is not obligated to communicate in a constructive way room for improvement/celebrate achievements. 

VMware has a LOT of work to do to actually give the representation they strive for outsiders to perceive. Lots of senior leaders that only employ people brought over from their previous companies with aged experience which ultimately stunts innovation and creativity. 

Younger employees are perceived as inexperienced and lacking knowledge. Someone has to either die or leave the company for you to be promoted. Sad because there are actual employees that are invested in the organization but don't have to the opportunity to innovate and make a change. And internal transfers are a joke - an external hire will be given the opportunity first, every time. 

So much for a "career journey" within the company. This is contributed to the fact that 90% of the recruiters at VMware are contractors and are not invested in the company and could care less about the candidate recruiting experience, even with an employee referral. 


Pros: 
Unlimited PTO
Generous Paternity Leave
Professional Development Opportunities
Lots of company/family-friendly events for Palo Alto employees
Exposure to a variety of technologies
cons:
Lackluster and Mediocre Leadership
No Upward Mobility unless you're a management "favorite"
Terrible HR and Recruiting for External and Internal Candidates
advice_to_mgmt: Start looking at the attrition rate and get to the root cause. Actually analyze all the employee relations complaints and I am sure you will find a common denominator and actually take action. What you accept is what you promote. Perception is everything.

review_title: Great as long as you don't mess up the EPIC values!
years_at_company: I worked at VMware full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Great benefits! Great people! Great pay!
cons: Management has lost their way. Everything is so politically correct, that if you say something that can be interpreted incorrectly by almost anyone, they fire you. I was fired for something I didn't do, but was reported by a partner sales person, that wasn't even in the room. A good friend said something negative about a competing product, but because there was someone in the room that took offense, they fired him. So whatever you do, don't open your mouth, state your opinion, or be anywhere near non politically correct.
advice_to_mgmt: Start trusting your people, not your aggressive HR investigators. I was with VMware for over 5 years, had great reviews, just been promoted, and yet, the investigator didn't believe a word I said, and had me fired. Give people a chance, put them on a plan, something. But firing someone for an off-hand comment, or being in the middle of some people that were talking about things that could cause offense? That's just wrong..

review_title: Accept offers with caution. Excellent CEO, bad middle management.
years_at_company: I worked at VMware full-time for more than a year
pros:
Excellent growth .
Excellent product portfolio.
Excellent CEO.

 Pat Gelsinger the CEO has done an awesome job of taking over the reigns of the company a few years ago and completely turning it around. The stock price has more than quadrupled under his leadership. He has acquired many startups and successfully integrated them into the VMWare product portfolio and eco system. Hats off to him for creating wealth for the employees, for the owners (EMC and now DELL) and for the investors. One of the finest CEO in the Silicon Valley.
cons:
Along with these product acquisitions, this company has also acquired managers and middle management who have no idea of what management is. There is no one culture at VMWare. There are as many cultures as the number of startups acquired and the managers of these startups are free to treat their teams as they want. HR is very weak in this company and they are not for you. They are for the managers ... dont rely on them. 

I had a short stint at one of these acquired startups called Velocloud. Incompetent management, very high attrition rate. Lot of senior engineers leaving the group. Those who stick around are there to vest their stocks. The founders thinks of themselves to be semi god who will punish you if you decide to leave their kingdom. Their technology stack will teach you nothing. Accept their offer if you cannot find a job somewhere else.

Most of these startup managers lack sympathy and empathy and will not hesitate to show you their powers and make you feel that you are a POS compared to them.

Dont be fooled by the "100 Best Companies to Work" or "Top paying company" marketing or the campus. It is actually an average paying and a very weak middle management company. Shop around, I am confident you will get a much better offer and a lot better culture, work environment and work life balance. I know people who were offered twice the package they were making at VMWare.
advice_to_mgmt: Pat: VMWare is doing an awesome job and will continue to do so under your excellent leadership. Fix the culture and HR of this company. Let HR be for the engineers also and not just for the managers.

review_title: Difficult place to work, with excellent pay and benefits.
years_at_company: I have been working at VMware full-time for more than a year
pros:
There are many excellent workers here, with great attitudes. VMware is consistently on the leading edge of technology, and is always improving its products and has rightly earned the position of being the de facto standard in IT infrastructure virtualization. 

Pay and benefits are top notch.
cons:
The rate of organizational change is overwhelming. I'm on my fifth boss in less than three years. The one who hired me was simply excellent, and was one of the best bosses I ever had. Sadly, the last three were among the bottom 10% of all my bosses. 

My current boss does not respond to phone calls or emails, and no one is able to schedule meetings with her on a timely basis. When she does finally meet with us, she does 90% of the talking, most of which is merely a re-hash of what she knows about the situation but with no new insight or leadership provided. Essentially, she is all talk, and has developed a reputation among other executives as being uncooperative and just doing things on her own.

Finally, there is too much internal competition and politics where there should be teamwork and cooperation. People view it as a badge of honor if they do someone else's job, causing total chaos. There are routine "land grabs" by various directors and VPs, and of course, from people at Dell who seem to have nothing better to do. Sadly, this seems to be the norm at VMware.
advice_to_mgmt: VMware would benefit tremendously if there was more emphasis on multiplying the effectiveness of its employees.

employee_status: Account Manager Latin America in Austin, TX
years_at_company: I worked at VMware for more than a year
pros: Innovative company, good training opportunities, dynamic pace
cons: Toxic environment, LATAM team is “lead” by an unqualified manager and absentee and unethical director. Gossips, fights, name calling, lies, deceiving...mix it all. The manager lies as he breaths. No sense of professionalism whatsoever. Very little focus on the job and way too much time dealing with office drama that HR didn’t seem capable or interested in dealing with. The toxic environment is created mostly by an insecure manager who mostly employees friends and make of the workplace unhealthy, dysfunctional, and less than productive
advice_to_mgmt:
Number one: hire and promote based on qualifications not friendship. That should be a must in any company, specially a company like VMWare (troubling)
Number two: ask for academic and professional qualification and experience. Shameful that “friends” hired can barely communicate on their own language and show little to no understand about professionalism in the workplace 
Create a culture of productivity and reward based on performance. My observation was that the managers friends would be given time off, flexible schedule, long vacations abroad (talking about 2 to 3 months) using the company time because the manager, while others were not allowed to even use sick time. Manager is extremely insecure and needs constant reassurance, which would not be as much a problem if he didn’t like to humiliate employees and gaslighting (he lies as he breaths) 
Get managers into mandatory ethical training, professionalism in the workplace, and talk about the importance of having any level of communication in English. Manager ONLy speaks with employees in Spanish and refuses to communicate in English with non Spanish speakers employees. 
Manager is unethical and abusive. HR is oblivious and inept
Realize that culture is toxic and money is being wasted with so much unnecessary unprofessional and toxic behaviors by manager .

pros: Excellent pay, benefits and flexible with schedule
cons: Contractors are treated much differently than regular employees. That should not be. In the office, your employees and contractors should be treated the same. You are doing the same work. Regular employees are not recognized for contributions, which doesn’t make people want to stay.
advice_to_mgmt: Upper management needs to really pay attention to the surveys they send out asking employees about their managers, directors and VPs. These are the people that represent your company as a whole and support your staff on many capacities. Sometimes, this is the only way for upper management to be aware of what is going on and open their eyes to issues they may not normally be aware of if not for these surveys. Listen to your people. People stay when they are treated well and have and feel their work is appreciated and ideas considered.

Company has new initiatives frequently so your work is discounted the moment you've completed it
No specific criteria for advancement; not always given based on merit
Complacency plagues productivity
advice_to_mgmt: Inspect what you expect

review_title: Worth doing some time here, but you’ll be busy!
years_at_company: I worked at VMware full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Good company rating, nice pets, competitive salary. Growing, Collaboration rules the culture. Lots of smart and talented coworkers who are happy to share information you will learn a lot in a short amount of time but are expected to contribute. Slackers need not apply. If you’re a slacker you won’t survive the high stress and fast pace.
cons: Starting to become a corporate clone environment. Sad when this happens. Culture is slowly changing and writing is on the wall. It’s coming. Benefits declining as the company grows and focus shifts to stockholders rather than employees. For example insurance shifted from Aetna to UHC. Saves the company money, but at expense of employees who now pay more for coverage. If you’re in support, you are always on the phone. If not taking calls you’re making them. There’s no such thing as downtime here unless the power goes out. High call volume means you’re always busy. High burnout and high turnover equals high stress. You’ll be asked to help your peers a lot. Your hard work and efficiency is rewarded with more work!. Haha. Unless you’re good with support you won’t last. If you can’t hack it, don’t apply!
advice_to_mgmt:
HIRE MORE STAFF AND TAKE MEASURES TO RETAIN THEM!!! There is way too much emphasis on “metrics”, which only serves to encourage and motivate employees to do just enough on the job to “hit the mark” and get by. Metrics are NOT a measurement of success —they are a minimum goal employees must meet to avoid getting fired! Stop the beam counting and focus on retaining existing talent and recruiting people who will want to STAY. More staff means less time on phones and lower burnout. The current support environment frankly 
has a revolving door and the support team is essentially a perpetual training facility for other companies. Try following Richard Branson’s advice: “Take care of the employees, and they will take care of the customer.”

review_title: Your mileage will depend on which Business Unit you are working at
years_at_company: I worked at VMware full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Great WLB. Parking lots are empty at 4:30 or 5:00 PM. and folks come in to work not before 10:00 AM in the morning.

Industry leading salaries and bonus (but very poor RSUs). The company moves at a reasonable pace and is very family friendly. 

The office location and campus for the HQ is awesome. 

The benefits and perks are also very good. 

The CEO and his team look to be very competent and genuinely nice people. 

The company has a compelling story with VMC on AWS. Hopefully it delivers on that vision or else the company is in for some real tough times.
cons:
On-prem enterprise software is not a cool technology sector to be in. 

Because of this perception the company does not attract the best talent anymore. Most of the A level players have left from the engineering ranks to startups or the FANG companies. So co-workers are mediocre at best.

Also the company moves at a glacial pace, compared to all the companies working in the cloud - releases in VMware take months to a year. 

 Its anachronistic in this day and age to have a monolithic technology stack. But with such a large installed base it will be near impossible for the company to pivot. 

Due to all of the above constraints it is hard to get excited about the technology in the company. 

A lot of the upper management are from the traditional old companies like Cisco, HP and IBM. This does not inspire confidence in the middle management.

The company pays well on the salary and bonus front but the RSU's are significantly lower than what FANG pays. 

Bottom line VMware is no longer a premium destination for employees. Its more in the same league as a Cisco or Oracle. A tier 3 company at best.

Go there if you are looking for a stable company and great WLB.
advice_to_mgmt: Deliver on the promise of AWS on VMC so that the halo effect from that can help the new initiatives like NSX succeed.

years_at_company: I worked at VMware full-time for more than a year
pros: Amazing perks and benefits. You can tell the company really cares about its employees. There is clear communication and a lot of transparency. From top to bottom, you really feel aligned and connected with the company at large. It's no wonder people dedicate a good chunk of their careers at this company -- upwards of 10, 15, and 20 years, you'll find some veterans here that don't get jaded. Rather, they keep the energy alive. It's a great training ground for those just starting their career. Succeed here, take advantage of resources, find a mentor, and you'll be set to achieve wherever you end up.
cons: Can be high pressure at times, but the work culture and environment make it worth it, and even inspire you to push yourself because you know you'll feel good in the end...and the company will recognize the work you put in.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep it up!

years_at_company: I have been working at VMware full-time for less than a year
pros: Culture: Collaborative, values-based, friendly, respectful. Shared passion for what we do and excitement about our future. Shared purpose and mission. Great perks and work environment. Promotes and supports remote work arrangements very well.
cons: Can sometimes over complicate solutions to problems. Need to emphasize simple, elegant solutions wherever possible. Flexible work environment can come at a cost in terms of collaboration and camaraderie. TA tools are cumbersome to use.
advice_to_mgmt: Listen to your people and give them better tools and less complicated processes to work with.

review_title: Great place to work - amazing people and great technology!
years_at_company: I have been working at VMware full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Customers love our technology - and therefore us!
Great team-mates and corporate culture
Strong pay packages
Flexible time off
cons: It's getting big enough of a company now that it sometimes takes a bit of time to make changes
advice_to_mgmt: Focus on customer experience - technology is important, but our customers have to be able to successfully use it to be great.

years_at_company: I have been working at VMware full-time for more than a year
pros:
VMware uses its hypervisor moat to continuously expand its technology reach in the face of continuing threats. It continues to expand its hypervisor technology to work with cloud players, and invest in new areas it has targeted for virtualization, such as storage and networking. Subsidized cafes, regular afternoon beer and snack parties, R&D get togethers are some other benefits. Lots of swag!
Compensation is generally in line with other companies in the area.
Beautiful campus and local links to public transportation, vanpools and carpools.
SW opportunities abound in many areas, and if you are enterprising, VMware encourages side projects and has regular hackathons to help engineers develop their ideas. Lot of hiring of fresh graduates and interns but you see a lot of senior engineers too.
cons: Nothing atypical for large companies in the bay area.
advice_to_mgmt: Nothing to add.

years_at_company: I worked at VMware full-time for more than 5 years

cons: The company is so large that it is easy to get lost, and feel like just another piece of capacity.
advice_to_mgmt: Agile means more than a constantly shifting focus without any priority on delivery.

years_at_company: I have been working at VMware full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Overall a great learning environment with great people whom encourage & support success. Gelsinger is a true leader with compassion for innovation without losing touch with the importance of community involvement.
cons: With the Dell/EMC merger and acquisitions, VMware has changed mid-level leadership many times creating disruption amongst the specialists Sales Teams. Over scrutiny of each AE across performance metrics has now become the standard while creating a sense of uncertainty and uneasiness as of late. This is worrisome.
advice_to_mgmt: Focus on encouraging, coaching, and molding your sales teams into successful people. Metrics are important to drive revenue towards a company goal, however they become less important when employees are managed as just another producer. Losing focus in this area will drive high performing producers away quickly.

years_at_company: I worked at VMware full-time
pros:
I worked at VMware before the Dell Acquisition of EMC. It was absolutely great working at VMware. The highlights were:
- Solid product
- Amazing and Green campus
cons:
This is based on 2012-2016 environment.
Certain areas that needed strengthening and improvement were:
- Teamwork & collaboration among mid & senior leaders
- Inculcating a mindset based on innovation and lateral thinking to drive more metrics-driven operations as opposed to opinion/emotion based approach

years_at_company: I worked at VMware full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Fantastic campus, beer bashes every couple of weeks, really talented people, a product that just works and great customer success with our products. 

The VMware RADIO (engineering innovation) is outstanding as is the internal MooseCon (security) conference.
cons: Enclaves. Silos. If you are in one of the BUs that are making money, you're going to be busy and do great. If you aren't, well, the axe could fall DESPITE having excellent reviews by your manager year after year.
advice_to_mgmt:
Change the layoff policies to actually keep talented people instead of making it more attractive to leave. 

Create a more collaborative environment for code/people/ideas to be shared among the BU and even outside the BU. 

Somehow fix being able to be an entrepreneur at VMware. The current program just doesn't work. 

Keep up the VMware RADIO and MooseCon. These are excellent .

advice_to_mgmt: More cross pollination between teams and departments. Open lines of communication and collaboration between different teams for the same goals.

review_title: Not the company it used to be. Rife with toxic politics and favoritism. Truly a shame.

cons: Parts of the company have become of one culture. Unfortunately it a culture that leans to misogyny. The Health insurance was ravaged for cost; when I started I couldn’t believe how good it was. When I left I couldn’t believe how bad. Way too much offshoring for cost reasons; Costco model of buying engineers by the pallet.
advice_to_mgmt: Get some real diversity and stand by the values you profess. Talk is one thing; walking it is another thing

years_at_company: I have been working at Qualcomm full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Flex-time off policy and some smart engineers
cons:
Talent isn’t appreciated in this company at all. It’s a very political place, with a lot of political power given to directors of groups. So if your director is good, you can get better salary, better bonuses and timely promotions.
If your director isn’t good, good luck getting promoted even to senior engineer (btw promotion = 10k salary increase, which is way too small).

If you are in remote site (not in SD that is), good luck with finding opportunities for career growth within the company. Utterly disgraceful management, with loads of VPs reporting each other, who do nothing valuable for growth of this company. Upper management doesn’t really care for even basic needs of engineers (like monumental pay increase, creating work-friendly environment). Review system is biased and managers don’t really care about third party opinions (why even take them, if you don’t care about them?)

There are better companies out there. Avoid like plague.
advice_to_mgmt: Value your employees. Typically engineers. They are the ones who fill your pockets and make you filthy rich. Pay them well. Assist them in their personality development and career growth (typically at remote sites) and most importantly, stop making the place a political ground.

review_title: Work is good but a very Toxic culture
years_at_company: I worked at Qualcomm full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Work is good, Lot to learn, people are dedicated and hardworking
- you get a lot of material to help you 
- Tuition reimburse
- Lot of training to choose from
- ESPP program and bonus at year end
cons:
Politics Politics Politics !!
- Toxic work culture [not generic][specific to the org I was working ]
- Totally Biased towards certain groups/factions 
- Most of the times, work is randomly assigned and deadlines are given to unnecessarily pressurize you, while it is clearly not relevant .. There will be pressure almost every week, but at the end of the year .. you will ask yourself why the hell, what did I achieve ? 
- No transparency , Low morale 
- work life balance is not encouraged 
- No-one cares, you feel merely a number 
- Low Base pay, but probably something is being addressed ,
advice_to_mgmt: None !! A lot of Climate surveys were given .. Nothing changes so best is to move on

years_at_company: I have been working at Qualcomm full-time for more than a year
pros: Great work-life balance at entry-level. You get to work with the best of the best when it comes to IC design. Work hours are reasonable, and I rarely see anyone being too stressed about work hours at least in IC design team.
cons:
As you become more senior and lead a project, you need to have meetings with other parts of the world and often times, this means meeting at 10 pm. Also, the amount of meetings that managers have is often quite a lot which led many senior staff level engineers to quit and move to other companies.

Also, total compensation package is not very competitive compared to the competitors. This also often causes staff and senior staff engineers to quit and seek for better compensation.

Overall, a great company to learn the trade then move onto the better paying company.
advice_to_mgmt: Pay your employees better. Otherwise, they all leave and you're only left with people that have no other options.

review_title: A strong Technology company, but of the past

cons:
Lost the Engineering edge, no more R&D. 
Upper Management is not quite as strong. They are still riding on the coat tails of previous success from 20yrs ago. WWAN modem remains to be the only unique strength of the Company.
Employee rewards has fostered only the Average Technical contributions. Definition of Strong Technical Contributions has been replaced by Large volumes of mundane work.
advice_to_mgmt: In my opinion Upper Management in the C-lvl required some shake up. A fresh air is needed to do a bit of over-haul in the Engineering Vision.

cons: Leadership has a terrible time making decisions. Our CEO changes his mind on a daily basis and is proud of the fact that he's never had any leadership training (it shows). Execs are also extremely out of touch and have lost any focus on employees which used to be the source of our great culture.
advice_to_mgmt: Listen, really listen, to employees about their experiences working here. Don't just listen to the same people you surround yourself with who tell you what you want to hear. Keep leaders accountable for treating employees well and being good managers. You lead by example and set the tone from the top so not much will change if you don't.

review_title: Not bad, but not as good as it used to be
years_at_company: I have been working at Qualcomm full-time for more than 10 years
pros: It's a pleasure to work with some of the smartest people I've ever met. In general, I have access to the tools I need to do my job, and to resources to keep my skills up to date. Management is sort of trying again to make it a good place to work.
cons:
Communication and Vision from senior leadership in the engineering organization is severely lacking.
The tools and processes engineers must deal with on a daily basis are a source of frustration.
Legal woes have been a constant overhang on employee morale (and compensation) for the last several years... and it seems it's still not finished.
Management is clumsily re-learning how to show their appreciation for employees by inviting thousands of employees to a launch party on one of the campuses where we get to wait in horribly long lines just to get a free taco and a beer. Employee appreciation is nothing like what it used to be.
HR keeps fiddling with the performance review process and rating system, yet at the end of it all the rating system and forced curve-fitting ends up destroying employee morale even further.
advice_to_mgmt: Demand vision and leadership from your senior leaders. Seek fresh new leadership with vision from outside the company if needed.

years_at_company: I worked at Qualcomm full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Works on some of the most advanced programs and technologies in the industry. Very positive attitude and engineering driven.

review_title: Product driven company with significant blind spots
years_at_company: I worked at Qualcomm full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Excellent pay, very smart people, good benefits.
cons: Extremely limited opportunities for promotion and advancement in marketing.
advice_to_mgmt: Management treats marketing as a disposable asset. Product management has the ability to directly comment and influence the careers of everyone in marketing yet marketing is given no ability to provide similar feedback on product management individuals in the review cycle. There is also very limited upward mobility in marketing, making working there a constant pressure cooker environment. That plus having to deal with a perpetual budgeting process makes marketing at Qualcomm a high-stress, low rewarding job. Because Qualcomm pays extremely well, it becomes extremely hard for anyone in marketing to challenge product management or take real control of the marketing process, which becomes dictated to marketing by product management. Marketing is, in effect, treated as a second class citizen within the org, and this is highlighted by the fact that the company has had a dozen different people managing marketing over the last decade. It's like the company doesn't really know what to do with the department which impacts the moral and enthusiasm of many of the people working there.

Bonuses were 12%+, past 5 years about 6%
Stock same price as 11 years ago. 
All internal tools are now horrible cause they either fired the teams that made them or fired everyone but one or two people to support the defunct tools.
Any promotion above Senior Staff requires "Business Need"
They usually require 3 years in a position before promotion
Any slight rating drop in a performance review can push your promotion out a few years. Don't wait just get a new job and come back for a promotion.
If your tech manager is good you're fine. If they're horrible you're screwed get a new one immediately.
Check if your team has counterparts in India. Most teams do. If yours does that means you will have 9am meeting and much more often meetings/debug sessions between 9pm and midnight.
advice_to_mgmt:
Announce layoffs before they happen.
Stop spending massive amounts of money on new revenue streams and then cutting all funding and teams just before they make a product.
Create a voting and non-voting class of stock so you can GIVE RSU!!!!

review_title: Traditional environment, Good people, Interesting work
years_at_company: I worked at Qualcomm full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Qualcomm invests in creating new things, so there are lots of opportunities to create. The environment is what I would call "traditional corporate". You don't have free lunches or on-site massage like the dot coms, but you do have private offices with doors that can close!
cons: The drawback is that Qualcomm best understands radio, and the modem-side of the house gets all the love. If you're on another technology and thongs are going well then you'll be supported. However, when tightening hits it will be your project on the block because the radio is where it's at.
advice_to_mgmt: You have great people in many locations and in many technologies. But you have to give them the chance to create. It may be that management can't handle the pressure of quarterly results and that Paul Jacob's idea of taking the Company private might make the most sense.

review_title: Used to be great. On the downward slope.
years_at_company: I have been working at Qualcomm full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Benefits and Compensation are decent compared to others in Michigan.
cons: Micro managing. Leftover project tasks.
advice_to_mgmt:
This is specific to Auburn Hills, MI location. At one point this used to be a great office to work at, but then there was acquisition and consolidation of groups. With that whats left on the development side is extremely poor projects( leftover tasks by other groups) along with Micro management from local managers. It is not helpful when the three layers of management within this small team DO NOT COMMUNICATE with each other or with their employees. Its no fun when everyone has their own viewpoints of the projects and no unified direction. 

Advice to management.
-Loosen up your control. 
-Listen to what your employees have to say. Trust your employees.
- Communicate better, at least within yourself.

cons: The company took a different direction that no longer valued it's employees (if you're not part of the legal or engineering department, I was in finance). The finance department was built from a group of friends that recruited one another. Whether you were a good employee or not, did not matter to management. They stood by who could kiss butt and who their friends were.
advice_to_mgmt: Upper management should be more involved in controlling the politics within each department. Poor performers are somehow kept while those who are super stars are over looked. If I were a business owner I would put more effort in cultivating skills of those who focuses on productivity and results than those who say they work long hours but have no actual accomplishments to show for it.

years_at_company: I worked at Qualcomm full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Brilliant people drive themselves to win, and the company won big over decades. Priceless experience you can't get elsewhere. Launching technology around the world, and changing the world in a big way.
cons: Unfortunately morale has gone down over the past couple years. Quite a bit in 2018, after some significant layoffs. You will work long hours, but it's been that way for decades. Expect that in any tech company these days. All this "work life balance" stuff you see is not true - anywhere. Tech advances more rapidly year over year. If you are excited about the work and fruits of the company's labor, you don't think so much about the balance. That's the way it was until a couple years ago. Now it's more thinking about the balance and if you really want to continue working there. Ratings in all categories below would be higher if rated 2+ years ago.
advice_to_mgmt: Everyone knows that being a public company is difficult. Institutional Investors and activists can drive leadership to make changes that hurt long term value. Big layoffs kill morale, and kill the people who remain and are then more overworked. Staff the programs realistically, or the remaining good people will leave. Ask for advice and ranking from anyone in your department that has direct reports when reducing staff.

review_title: Better than other places but sliding downhill
years_at_company: I have been working at Qualcomm full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Working with some of the most talented people in the industry raises the bar and challenges you to be the best you can be. So much to learn working here. Salaries are generally competitive (but changing). Depending on your manager, you can have flexibility in your work hours. On-site health care is convenient and high quality.
cons:
Benefits shrinking rapidly — no more accrued vacation time. Also, with repeated layoffs and understaffed departments, it’s near Impossible to find a time “convenient to the business” to take any time off. Headcount is cut in half in some areas while workload only grows, and there is no concern for employee welfare and how to resolve tired over-worked employees having unrealistic workload to manage. New merit review system removes manager ability to individually reward high performers (it is all decided by compensation team). High performers are given minuscule salary increases below cost of living increase; how does this
motivate anyone? No end in sight to mountains of work growing with no plans to add resources, only more reductions.
advice_to_mgmt: Stop killing your staff with unrealistic amounts of work with little reward. If you don’t take care of people they will keep leaving. Make people take mandatory vacation time for their own mental health, it is shown to increase productivity. Also give bigger raises and bonuses to keep them— it is cheaper than what you lose when they quit and you need to find, hire, and train new people.

Management may be making poor decisions due to misaligned interests. Litigation with major customer has been very costly for company.

review_title: Boise Site (TSheets) - Great place to be
years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
I was here before the acquisition and got to see the company change from a little Eagle ID startup to part of an 8,000+ employee corporation. Here are some thoughts from a software dev's perspective:

- The benefits got a lot better, you probably won't find any other jobs in Boise area that beat the benefits at Intuit. (Insurance, stock, bonus, etc,.)
- People you work with on a day to day are very smart.
- Intuit has some cool tech they're promoting internally for use across products.
- You get personal dev days at the end of each sprint and engineering days twice a year, which you can use to work on basically whatever you want, as long as you're improving yourself or the company in some way. (personal dev I usually spend learning new technologies I'm interested in by working on fun side projects.) If it weren't for personal dev I would've left the company years ago, it gives devs the ability to hone new skills instead of staying in their bubble.
cons:
TSheets lacks someone in the architect role so different development projects don't always come together nicely. Other intuit orgs have architect(s) who take on the job of forming a broader vision of how the codebase / architecture should work. 
 Seems like devs are always writing a lot of hacky stuff to make things work because of a lack of someone who has a bigger vision.
- Codebase will leave you wanting. I guess with a 12+ year old php monolith what are you going to do.. I will say it's getting better though.
- Management could prioritize code improvements more. Our feature teams don't have as high velocity as they could because of handicaps in our codebase.
advice_to_mgmt:
Put someone in the architect role. Make that someone's full time job, it's seriously needed.

A while back there was talk about "development sprints".. or whatever we were calling it - a special sprint several times a year where devs could focus on cleaning up unused code, useful refactors, etc,. rather than feature work. That was talked about by the top dog JD at sprint retro and sounded official, then sort of never got spoken of again. From talking to devs around the org, those would seriously be useful even if it's just some teams here and there so please think about doing that.

review_title: Toxic culture in software development team in Los Angeles
years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Benefits are great
Work is interesting and challenging
cons: Manager/ Director is too dependent on leads and only manages up. Keeps skipping 1 on 1's. Work life balance is missing. Some of the leads and Senior engineers who have been working at that office for a while feel like they own the place and bully the new employees. Bro culture. Lot of engineers have left for the same reason.
advice_to_mgmt: Management from Mountain view should hold skip level meetings with employees. Provide emotional intelligence training.

review_title: Prosperity focused rocket ship, solving interesting problems

review_title: Doing what I love to do with a company that aligns to my values!
years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Work / Life Balance 
- Clearly defined Roles and Responsibilities
- Benefits 
- Did i mention benefits? (you may think you know them all but i find new ones all the time!!!
- I work on whats most important
- I have fun! 
- Community Involvement 
- Competitive matching 401k / Employee Stock Purchase / Employee Stock grants (i know - also in the benefits bucket)
- Campus life is AWESOME!
cons:
Season Peaks do add stress - but never more than I can handle. 
- Seems to be annual layoffs with either reorgs or fiscal year changes. I have not been impacted as a solid performer but thats always a scary time of the year.
advice_to_mgmt:
Keep it up! I have been here for 5 years and even through our challenges your leadership is so important to ensure we continue to win in the market! 

Keep valuing your employees and i would rather see a slow in hiring/promotion than face layoffs each year.

review_title: Intuit is an industry standard setter

review_title: Best Days in the Rearview mirror
years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Early years, good work enviroment & adaquate staff. Was once a Good US Company
cons:
Work.life balance, Benefits timeoff: Vacation, Sick time (actual)
Fair & Equitable review based on multiple positions 
Consolidation of multiple jobs - Hired for one job, years later performing 3 or 4. 
 Management /favortism / preselected candidates promotion
advice_to_mgmt:
Current Brand "Powering "Prosperity around the World" translates to outsourcing & contractors. 
Respect your staff, be truthful, accept your mistakes, take responsiability for customer issues . Management pay & bonuses based on bottomline. (out sourcing cuts cost better bottomline) Staff pay based on VOC, includes customer dissatisfaction with staffing, lack of adaquate support, program.

years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit for more than 5 years
pros:
A truly values-driven culture of constant reinvention and reimagining with a bold mission to power prosperity around the world.

Outstanding pay and benefits. Thoughtful management focused on leading with data to solve important customer problems.

Friendly, caring, supportive culture of respect where ensuring a sense of belonging is paramount. It’s easy to feel proud of what we do for people.
cons:
Constant change can lead to fatigue. We’re getting better, but we need to avoid strategy whiplash. Deliver more wins before making major changes.

Collaboration and results are slower at HQ than in smaller sites. Big sites may be getting to big to succeed.

Can get too ambitious. Many longtime leaders need to improve time management. Reduce spinning in circles until every detail is ready.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep listening. Share more of what you hear. Remember pushing for 110% isn’t sustainable. Get better at saying no.

review_title: Great company with amazing culture and excellent benefits!
years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 8 years

Awesome Culture - genuine, caring people from top-to-bottom
Excellent employee benefits including great healthcare, well-being reimbursement, stock purchase program, donation matching, and much more.

advice_to_mgmt: Our new big bets are very clear and exciting to tackle, but we need to figure out the right balance for status updates & priority reviews. There seems to be a lot of overlap of meetings between big bets & BU updates.

years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 5 years
pros: I love that Intuit supports diversity and inclusion through out the company. We have many different employee resource groups that are for everyone. We support the LGBTQ+ community with the Pride ERG, also we have a Special needs and Abilities Network for supporting the disabled. We also have 7 other networks for employees to join and participate in. It is amazing to me to see how much Intuit values their employees and the community. One of our Values is 'We Care and Give Back' which allows employees to volunteer within the community in whichever way they feel most inspires them.
cons: New people are constantly coming in, but there isn't a way to meet them. It would be nice to have an email or maybe a meet and greet once a month for all of the new people coming in.
advice_to_mgmt: Just keep being available and keep listening to the employees!

review_title: Intuit is the best kept secret in The Valley
years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
The culture at Intuit is second to none. Not all companies show the level of respect and care for employees that Intuit does. 

Benefits are attractive as well and include RSUs and a Wellness Benefit that includes reimbursement for having your house cleaned (for example). As in all companies, there are good managers and some managers where you will wonder why or how they are in their role, but most leaders try to do the right thing and work as a team, which is great here. 

Our new CEO, Sasan, is challenging us to move faster in order to do amazing things. Sasan is very inspiring and makes me believe that Intuit's best days are in front of us. I feel very fortunate to be an Intuit employee.
cons:
Great collaboration but the flip side is it can slow things down a bit. 
We have opportunities to move faster and remove some levels of decision makers but it is in the spirit of ensuring we move together and have alignment for long-term success.

review_title: Great place to work, good benefits and culture
years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time
pros: Great benefits, great culture, exciting work

review_title: Amazing opportunity to make a difference
years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 3 years
pros: The people -- who you get to work with and the customers we serve is one of the best parts of working at Intuit. The customers are every day people who are trying to succeed and need some help. The things we do for them can make a huge difference for them. I know it sounds like kool-aid but everyone is very driven to do the right thing for our customers and make a difference in their lives so as a result you get colleagues who are willing to dive and help you achieve amazing results.
cons: The highly collaborative and empowered culture can make it hard at times to know who gets to make the final decision.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to inspire your teams and help managers unleash the amazing talent.

employee_title: Vice President Intuit Global Brand Strategy
review_title: Culture at the heart of a tech driven company
years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for less than a year
pros: The people are incredibly caring and all proud to work at a mission driven company. They also are quick to support "self disruption" if it means that the company has a better chance for long term success.
cons: At times, people are hesitant to give constructive feedback at risk of hurting the incredibly positive culture
advice_to_mgmt: Keep focus on pace and speed to market

review_title: Incredible place to grow your career
years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Intuit has many strengths, from its inspiring mission of Powering Prosperity Around the World, to its culture of customer obsession that is studied by many tech peers, to its history of self-disruption over 35 years. But one major strength that is often overlooked is Intuit's focus on developing people through coaching and feedback. Intuit provides both the opportunities and the coaching to develop your career, whether it's for leadership positions or growth as an individual contributor. It's no surprise that the current CEO and many of the most senior leaders rose through the ranks based on the culture of career development here.
cons: High degree of collaboration can slow down decision making at times. We have opportunities to move faster to deliver for customers by empowering teams and removing friction.
advice_to_mgmt: Intuit is one of the best kept secrets in tech. Let's get the secret out so the best talent in the world knows where to come work!

review_title: Great place to grow your career
years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Excellent mobility opportunities, leadership development, employee and customer centric culture
cons: Can focus on moving with greater speed and involving fewer people in the decision making.

years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Constantly learn and stretch my capabilities; I work with different challenges everyday and get to challenge myself and my colleagues to deliver amazing experiences internally and externally!
cons: My commute is challenging but I do get to work flex hours and have the tools to join meetings when on business travel.
advice_to_mgmt: Space is a challenge; we grow faster than our real estate.

years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 3 years
pros: I have been working as a full time employee for the pat 3 years and I love my experience so far. The company really understands what it means to have work-life balance. I'm able to work remotely which is very helpful because I have a young child. Additionally the company recognizes good talent and will help nurture it which allows for opportunities outside of the team. Finally the benefits are pretty awesome.
cons: Lots of internal tools (legacy & new), constantly having to keep up to date or get up to speed on new technology. How well you do in the company is also based on your network. If you don't have a good network, it's hard to do you job well and grow into other opportunities.
advice_to_mgmt: Break down barriers for the individual contributors and help make the process to learn, grow and develop professionally as easy as possible. It feels like there's a lot information & support for upper management but it's not clear for contributors.

review_title: Great people and opportunity for growth
years_at_company: I worked at Intuit full-time for more than a year

cons: Some managers complicate and not open - lucky if no such encounters
