years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for less than a year
pros: They treat their employee's well.
cons: wish they had an office space here in Arizona
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the good work

review_title: Does not get any better than this.....
years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Excellent work life balance. Amazing coworkers who know how to get it done. Excellent product.
cons: Too many hands in the cookie jar at times.

years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than a year
pros: Build skills, learn a lot, great benefits
cons: Big company poltitcs, no room for growing

years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Intuit genuinely cares about their employees and they're very conscious of work-life balance. They provide amazing benefits and try to ensure the benefits are molded to the employee wants and needs. I have a positive work environment and still enjoy coming to work everyday because it has great people and the work I do makes me feel like I've made an impact so it's rewarding.
cons:
It seems in the last year or so Intuit has been utilizing outsourcing agencies for our customer care. Although the intention is to provide jobs in areas that are struggling economically, it has hindered the amazing service we once provided and has caused a divide between Intuit agents and outsourced agents. These outsourced agents are not given the benefits and care that Intuit agents are given so they're not going to provide the amazing care that a happy employee would.

Internal jobs or career growth is not quite what it was. When I first started, Intuit was all about internal career opportunities and now it seems they look more externally. Career moves are not quite what they used to be. If a position is considered an entry level position then Intuit shouldn't be looking for someone who is more qualified. More opportunity should be given to agents that have dedicated their time to the business first rather than seeking externally.
advice_to_mgmt:
Bring our care back in-house because happy employees means happy customers and in the long run that's more revenue for Intuit. Or work with the outsourced agencies to make sure our values are truly aligned and make sure their employees are truly happy. This is not insight that will be given right away, these outsourced agents need to feel like they can trust our people are there for them.

-Take care of your current employee's career growth before hiring outside. Entry level should be entry level. An 'Entry Level' Accountant position shouldn't have a "preferred" of a CPA certification. To become a CPA you have to have hands on experience under a CPA first. Bypassing employees that do not have this certification makes the job posting misleading and discouraging for future roles that may open up. CPA preferred shouldn't be on anything that is listed as entry level for a standard Accountant role.

years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Innovation , Flexibility and supportive leadership
cons: Getting ownership of meatier projects and programs that seem to be driven out of California.
advice_to_mgmt: There is a reason why tech companies like Salesforce , Uber and Google are coming to the DFW area and making this a second HQ. increase investment in the Plano site for the long haul.

years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than a year
pros: The culture is inclusive and empowering. 20 years in the technology field and I have never worked at a company that helps women feel empowered, respected and confident. I love my job, my team and the work we do. Educational opportunities are available and the mangers activly help develop their individual work employees.
cons: The only grip I have is the drive, but unfortunately that is my choice due to family circumstances.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the great work.

review_title: Best place to work in Silicon Valley!!
years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Incredible culture with great people
- Amazing perks (125% match of 401k, employee stock purchase program, year-end cash and stock bonuses, yearly fitness stipend, affordable and solid health, dental and vision benefits, etc.)
- Great work/life balance
- Flexible working hours 
- For a big tech company not a ton of politics. Everyone’s opinion is heard and valued. 
- Company puts employees first, then customers and then shareholders 
- Great company values of “integrity without compromise” and “we care and give back” that Intuit holds itself accountable to
cons: Highly matrixed organization with fairly complex products which can lead to slow delivery times on projects

review_title: Do the best work of your life
years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Surrounded by highly capable and motivated individuals at all levels (above and below)
- Flexibility in hours, ability to work from home helps to support work/life/family
- Benefits are extensive, from medical/dental/eye to wellness to emotional well-being
- Autonomy provided to allow you to pursue your career goals
- Company culture and value system is strong and encompasses more than day to day work; support for volunteering and giving back to the community
cons:
Long hours during peak season
- Constant change could be a con for some; others find it energizing/motivating
advice_to_mgmt: Keep the open lines of communication which provide for the ability for the company to continue to grow. Grow the transparency of career pathways, and allow for more career movement across products/groups in the organization.

review_title: The Best Company I Have Ever Known, where is the 6 Star option.
years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for less than a year
pros:
There are too many here to list, but I will try!

First, the way they regard their employees is amazing. Having been in a sales role in several industries over my career, I have never seen a company so humble and interested in their employees. They genuinely care that you not only succeed, but work towards a goal that will make you happy.

Second, I know it’s cheesy but they let you be you. You are not molded into the model that they want in their company. They let you bring your strengths and your passions into work and direct you to use those for the good of company. 

They love innovation. I have had the opportunity within my first year to question processes and long held practices. With the support of my manager and director, I was supported the whole time. Never once was I made to feel that I should get in line, like many other companies. My ideas were judged on their merits and they welcomed the disruption to their practices. 

Finally, the benefits and opportunities to help your community are amazing. I have zero worries that whatever life throws at my family, Intuit will be standing behind me the entire time with all their resources. 

The list really does go on and on, but if it sounds too good to be true, it isn’t at Intuit.
cons: The workload is A LOT. The company is constantly innovating. So you have to be dedicated and flexible.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the good work, stay aligned with your staff and as a management team. It’s only going to get better!

years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Amazing company culture and values that the company really stands behind
- Great comp and benefits package. Insurance benefits are exceptional
- Great work life balance
- Impactful work and smart people
cons:
Not working in MTV can hinder your career development
- Big changes in company SLT means transparency/visibility to change isn't always clear
- Vacation packages are still a bit low compared to other companies
- Big company trying to move fast can create a lot of headaches in workstreams
- New focus on accountability adds risk to company culture
advice_to_mgmt: You've built an incredible culture that makes this place really, really special and enables really smart people to do the best work of their lives. More accountability at the company is definitely needed, but letting the pendulum swing too far the other direction could ruin what makes this place so unique and wonderful to work for.

years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Intuit is a fantastic place to work, with probably the best work life balance, benefits and pay you will encounter. Yes we work hard, we try to work smart and leverage technology to help our customers, and we are driven to hit our goals. Intuit is such that if a planned sales goal turns out to be unreasonable to hit, they get adjusted, so we aim high, but if the best projections are unreasonable, they are adjusted back. This company is always evolving to better serve its customers and employees, and communities we live in. We update our offerings and software and support resources to better help our customers, we discover and fix if there are any problems. Our Intuit has a built in gym, game room, cafeteria, free coffee and beverages, and snacks to keep you going, we have even remodeled to have updated styles, and sit down / stand up desks. Another example we even have ergonomic specialists to make sure you are comfortable in your settings at your desk. Intuit even gives you 40 hours a year to donate and work at your favorite charity, and will pay you your regular work wage and give you that time off, I don't know of too many that do that. The company is environmentally conscious also in its desire to not be wasteful with resources it uses. This will be my 17th year here, and time has gone by so fast. Intuit constantly looks to improve its ways as well, management styles, have also changed over the years as well, also to encourage your own personal development, and career development as well.
cons: Not sure this is a con, but Intuit hires really well on people who fill the jobs they request, so if you are not the right fit for a position, or have the skill set, do what you need to develop your talents to get in. However once you are in, there are many free clinics / classes and resources to partner with you to develop your talents to the next level or position you may want to go into. Intuit even has college tuition reimbursement.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep growing, and knowing how the market is changing with many other entries to the small business software market, keep on your game, keep developing and innovating to stay the best small business software, we can't assume we will keep that title without innovating.

years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for less than a year
pros: Work-life Balance; Location; Friendly people around
cons: Some teams are doing things not quite interesting

review_title: World-class company with world class business plan
years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for less than a year
pros:
Strong and meaningful values; company lives its values on a daily basis
Company truly cares about its employees
Inclusive, and focused on becoming more so
Excellent benefits package, competitive pay and equity structure
Very interesting time to be at Intuit with a new CEO (January 2019) with big plans for growth
Highly skilled and experienced executive suite
Strong on communication throughout the org
cons:
Can be slow to make decisions due to consensus-based culture, but this is shifting into better balance due to the need to move fast to achieve growth.
Company needs to increase manager capability to lead dispersed teams; there is too much focus on keeping everyone in one place, which is not sustainable in supporting growth.

years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 10 years
pros: The culture, the mission/vision, the people, the focus on customers, walking the walk, not just talking the talk, management team and stock price!
cons: Can be complex to navigate the organization. But for those who are willing to build relationships and want to work in a team-based environment - it's worth it!

years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 3 years

years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Intuit has a clear set of Values that ensure we are leading by example, recognize the importance of team work and diversity and ensure we are good stewards in our community by giving back and building a better future. I have worked here for over 15 years and continue to be inspired, challenged and thankful to be a part of this great company.
cons: Not necessarily a con, but important to accept that change is inevitable and need to be able to embrace change so that we can grow with speed. It is not boring.

review_title: I look forward to driving to work everyday

pros: Inspiring company mission, smart people

advice_to_mgmt: You need to be a self starter and manage your own career. There isn't a set career path or agenda. You can choose to stay in the same area or to pursue mobility opportunities, but it's up to the employee to navigate. Personally, I prefer this way. I do recognize, however, that it can be overwhelming for some to navigate mobility.

years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Values are rock solid starting with Scott Cook founding back in 1983 through today. Intuit gives everyone the training, resources, support, and room to paint their masterpiece, for those who want to push themselves further than they ever thought they were capable while working with awesome people and customers, this is the place. Sets a high bar and raises it every year while paying for performance, if you like that, you'll love Intuit, if you're looking for a place to coast then Intuit is definitely not the right place.
cons: Faster decision making, better collaboration and prioritization as we operate differently against our company-wide big bets.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to stay close to employees at all levels as our change velocity increases so we can quickly learn and pivot on any missteps.

review_title: Perfect job for an EA/CPA/Tax Attorney

pros:

Intuit genuinely cares about me. Management is fair and fun. We laugh here and have fun contests and competitions. 

You get to keep your own Tax Practice while working here. 

Working remotely...
cons: I am not aware of any cons. Intuit is really good to its employees.

review_title: intuit is everything I ever dreamed of in a job and a whole lot more
years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 3 years
pros: From day one, I have been encouraged and supported to build a better work world. I have never been told "no, you can't" to any reasonable idea. The culture of customer obsession, respect and affection between employees and the drive to make the world a better place is a powerful combination.
cons: There are always things that could be better at any company. Intuit is proactive at identifying any issues and working on them - and Leadership truly listens to employees. I can't really think of anything consider a con.
advice_to_mgmt: It's amazing to see Sasan Goodarzi own his new role as CEO. Brad Smith is truly missed, but Sasan is The One to lead our next chapter. My advice is to continue to build on the strong cultural foundation created by Scott Cook and to continue to disrupt ourselves.

years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than a year
pros: At Intuit, the executive leadership team ensures that employees are the first point of focus because they recognize that the employees are who deliver results for customers and shareholders. Intuit practices the values that they've set before us, delivering on integrity without compromise and giving back to the community. Failure isn't viewed as a reason to be dismissed, but rather an opportunity to learn and...
cons: There are frequent re-ogranizations that interrupt priority work progress. These can be extremely frustrating because the inevitable and unavoidable delays do not seem to be accounted for in terms of the expected timelines for delivery of the work being performed. This leads to extremely stressful times for the team members performing the work.
advice_to_mgmt: Allow room for adjustment when re-orgs are announced. The pressure to ensure everyone keeps moving at the same pace regardles of huge changes is difficult to manage. This definitely feels driven from the top down, and is a huge area of opportunity.

review_title: Employee friendly culture but no real innovation plus gnarly political red tape
years_at_company: I worked at Intuit full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Stock has done well and frontline workers generally seem happy. New CEO wants to drive change and fuel growth. More focus on getting stuff done. Strong customer focus. They care about their customers for sure.
cons: They really just have two products - Quickbooks and TurboTax that you can only milk for so long. They’re continually increasing prices on customers absent real innovation. The new strategic priorities aren’t really taking off. Top talent is leaving the company and new talent rarely stays past the first year or two because of no product direction and red tape that makes it impossible to execute. Obsolete technology stack means recruiting engineering talent is difficult - can’t really compete with the googles and facebooks for engineers. AI/ML hasn’t proved out and won’t until product experiences are fixed. It feels like a slow moving semi-tech company that’s living on lack of competitive pressure. It will catchup with them unless they act.
advice_to_mgmt: Reduce reliance on institutional knowledge, be more decisive and maybe less cult like. Fix your execution challenges.

review_title: Employee-friendly, customer-obsessed company that delivers on its business objectives
years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Amazing environment for employees focuses on respect, diversity and inclusion, teamwork, constructive feedback and coaching, with strong pay, incentives, and benefits. Values are real, tangible - show up everywhere from corporate responsibility strategy all the way to how employees provide guidance to one another.

Customer-focused company frames the work we do in terms of our customers' biggest problems. Invests in research, experimentation, failing forward and doing right by our customers end-to-end.

Business has performed at or above guidance nearly every quarter of the five + years I've been here. Stockholders make money because the company acquires great talent and treats its employees well -- and because those employees obsess over delivering experiences that matter for our customers.
cons: Speed, especially as business units re-orient around an ecosystem strategy. Turnover - because intuit is known for great talent, it's also the target of a ton of poaching.
advice_to_mgmt: New C-Team is nailing it. We're with you!

review_title: Corporation with a Conscience, Amazing Benefits

pros: Stellar benefits package, great amenities, support for employees in a myriad of surprising and delightful ways, and business ethics you can really get behind.
cons: Mountain View is clearly the central focus (which I guess isn't a con if you work on the Mountain View campus), it can be difficult and take a long time to transition from contract work to full-time status for lack of open FTE positions, as a contractor you do not get access to many benefits and amenities that make Intuit a truly remarkable place to work.
advice_to_mgmt: Convert more contract employees to FTE by opening more positions, more communication surrounding policy changes

review_title: Seriously the best place I have ever worked
years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than a year
pros: Competitive compensation, amazing benefits, focus on work-life balance, investment in employee growth and development, great work environment, and company mission and values you can get behind.
cons: The recent frequency of leadership changes, while not necessarily a bad thing, have slowed things down a little and caused momentary confusion surrounding priorities.

review_title: THE place to do grow and perform
years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than a year
pros:
Intuit really supports its employees in growing their skills and stretching their wings. It's also very good about supporting small businesses and communities and gives back.

I came here from a decade at the biggest name in tech, and Intuit beats them in every way for being a better place to work. The salaries are higher, the managers far more supportive and engaged in your growth, and you have the reigns in your hands as an IC to solve problems much more readily. It's an innovative place to work with a genuine culture of solving problems together to help our customers and communities. 

In addition to being a supportive and empowering place, Intuit is also very diverse in terms of gender, ethnicity, and even work experience. In my first week, I met people who had come from every company I admire, and every part of the globe. It's really a place to make a difference and make great connections.
cons: Work-life balance is up to you to carve out for yourself... expectations are high. It's also a place that relies on relationships and partnering more than strict process and authority. So that can take a bit of getting used to if you've been conditioned to totally owning your own space. But it opens the doors to great work when you build partnerships and trust.
advice_to_mgmt:
A bit more vacation time for 1-3 year tenure employees would be amazing. 

The commute is insane... can we leverage more WFH capabilities? Is there a way we could have a formal program for folks who want to try it out more? Being in MTV is amazing, and I wouldn't want to miss all the great interactions there. But I'd love to WFH anytime I don't have a ton of meetings or events to go to.

years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 10 years
pros: This company really cares about your experience as an employee - what is on your mind, what's in your way, what changes can be made to make it better. With an inspiring vision, a recession-proof product, transparent leadership and AMAZING benefits, who wouldn't want to work here?
cons: Even when we focus there are just too many priorities.
advice_to_mgmt: Know your headcount needed to run-the-business and understand the root cause for why.

years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Flexible work schedule if needed.
Good benefits and perks.
Positive attitude on problem solving.
Healthy business.
cons:
Lack of structure, process and strategic planning in business units.
Extreme focus on tactical matters, with rewards tied to those.
Impossible to do a good job in supporting roles (e.g. Sales Ops) due to lack of process and structure.
Employees tend to play the company values card to cover inefficiencies in their work. 
Ratings are based on feedback, which is good, except feedback is often tied to how happy an internal customer is vs. how effective one is in their job.
Large % of employees have been around for over 10 years, making change hard.

years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 10 years

cons: It's easy to burnout. Change is constant and staying on top of your game in a constantly changing environment can be stressful. You define your own work life balance and if you start heavy on the work balance, it's hard to break the cycle. There's a renewed pressure to deliver outcomes. Individuals are moving fast to deliver and not always bringing everyone along on the journey or thinking about the long term implications of their work.

advice_to_mgmt: Align with your leadership teams across BUs and be sure everyone is cascading the decisions to the working teams to reduce churn. When our leaders have clarity, we can move faster. Along those lines: commit to no more than 2 Approvers on a project. Give working teams a clear path of escalation to decision making that ensure work can ship.

review_title: I've been at Intuit for 27 years and there are plenty of reasons why
years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
Intuit has a set of values that it makes every effort to live by. Sure, people are imperfect and they don't always meet the high bar, but the expectation is that they'll do the work to get there. One unifying theme at Intuit is customer obsession -- all employees are highly focused on helping customers solve their financial problems (our company's mission is to Power Prosperity Around the World). It's easy to relate to our customers because we're all consumers with money concerns. We also cater to small businesses and the self-employed (a growing market because of the gig economy). Small businesses are the backbone of the economy, and I'm proud that although I work for a 9,000-person corporation, our focus is on the little guy. I never feel like I'm "working for the man." In fact, there's a larger than average number of women in leadership positions here. And we have a thriving program called "Tech Women @ Intuit," with a team of four full-time employees who ensure that we attract, retain and promote technical women. Because of this and our family-friendly benefits and culture, I think Intuit is a top choice for technical women.

Another part of Intuit that resonates me is our "We Care & Give Back" program, which has shaped my approach to charitable giving. The company matches up to $5,000/year of employee donations, so my giving has double the impact. On top of that, Intuit pays for the annual gift I need to make because I sit on the board of a nonprofit. All employees get 32 hours of paid time to do charitable work. And what's most exciting is that the company has started creating "Prosperity Hubs" in economically struggling parts of the U.S., like in W. Virginia, where we train hundreds of people and give them jobs in the tech industry -- breaking their dependency on environmentally disastrous and dying industries like coal.

Lastly, the company recognizes the good work I do and pays me well. Over the years, my salary has paid for my daughter's college tuition (she has no student loan debt) and her wedding. I like the work I do, I've improved the lives of our employees, our customers and those in need, I've met great people and have made some lifelong friends, and my financial needs are covered. What more could you want from a company?
cons: We have some challenges with internal tools, like our intranet. The food in our Mountain View cafeteria isn't great for vegetarians.

years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for less than a year
pros: Great mission, great people...a place that truly cares for its employees and believes that everyone has the opportunity to prosper
cons: Keep up terrific culture while working to move faster

review_title: Good for San Diego, but could be better
years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
San Diego is very laid back
- Decent work life balance
- Campus remodel
- Convenient location
- Opportunities for advancement, if you know how to navigate politics
- Lots of events of all types (social, meetups, "tech conferences")
cons:
Lower pay than other tech companies (and proud about it)
- Campus remodel to open office plans
- Even with the new engineer promotion process, promotions are not based on skill but more on "did your project do well"
- The amount of legacy engineers that are resting and vesting is astounding
- Too involved in politics (internal and external)
- Attempts at tech conferences and engineering days are more show than substance (but at least they're trying)
advice_to_mgmt:
You will struggle to become a top tier company until you shake up your most senior engineers which are holding you back by being poor talent evaluators themselves, and poor performers compared to their industry peers
- Offer market rate compensation instead of 75th percentile, or create an incentive program that truly pays for performance of the individual's contributions
- My peers won't consider Intuit when I tell them about opportunities for the fact that compensation is not competitive enough

Company moves fast, which is not a bad thing, but doesn’t take time to celebrate a win before expecting everyone to jump back into the race 
Promotion process is not clear and consistent and can be difficult to get promoted.
advice_to_mgmt: The best managers are those who focus on growing their employees and who have strong people skills. Don’t have someone be a people manager just because they are skilled at what they do.

review_title: Best Place I have ever Worked

My health insurance premiums are the lowest I have ever had. We don't have free meals but food is provided at many meetings and we have an extensive snack room. years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for less than a year

Intuit also cares about the world, and gives generously to communities and people in need in a variety of ways (including an employee matching program). In general, people here are incredibly nice, smart, and capable. In addition, the salary, benefits, stock, and other employee rewards and offerings are excellent. review_title: If you’re not a white male - keep moving
years_at_company: I worked at Intuit full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Colleagues with good hearts, amazing skills and best of intentions
cons: Corrupt leadership, trying their hardest to hide all the accusations of sexual harassment and gender discrimination - more specifically females who are underrepresented minorities. Unfair pay - regardless of employee type.
advice_to_mgmt: Clean house - especially in TA. But that would mean management needs to leave as well - about 80% of them.

years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 8 years
pros: The benefits are good and one of the better companies in the San Diego area. Opportunities to interact with many different leaders across the company. Fast paced work and ability to learn many different aspects of the business and products.
cons:
There is little to no direction coming from the execs, and what little direction we are given will constantly change. You are measured against an invisible moving target and expected to get on board or get out. 
If you're trying to get hired, be prepared to get ghosted by the recruiters. You will need to be persistent and make an effort to follow up with them to get updates. Do not expect them to call you.
advice_to_mgmt:
The recruiters need to be on top of staying with incoming talent. I have seen too many exceptional candidates walk away and take other offers because the recruiting team does not call back, send emails, or even have voicemail space on their phones. It's embarrassing when people I've recommended call me to ask why they haven't heard anything and can't leave a voicemail because the recruiters voicemail is full, and they aren't responding to emails. 

Top talent is being pushed out due to lack of vision, direction, and leader support. I've been Game Changer for 2 years in a row and am actively looking for employment outside of Intuit. My leadership team's actions speak louder than words and they have shown me, my career development, work / lift balance, and passions are not important to them. Leaders talk about listening to employees and being open to feedback, but treat it as a box to check.

years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Deep customer empathy, design thinking, benefits, work life balance, team collaboration, autonomy, global approach, community involvement
cons: Politics get in the way, segmented products, outdated technology

years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than a year
pros: The company is well managed. The remote nature of the job and the flexible schedule provides a lot of autonomy.
cons: I could not think of any

years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time
pros: Benefits. Location. Work Culture. Pay. Smart coworkers
cons:
Can get political at times
-Tricky promotion process

review_title: A company which is particular about maintaining its brand and good image
years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Good salary, bonus and stock options
Cool office and respected brand name
Industry leading products
cons:
Very high employee attrition. Most employees cannot stay for more that 2-3 years. Either one has to be working on a successful project or belong to a clique to stick around. 
Every year spring a musical chair of who will stay and who will let go happen, an ugly blame game will follow breaking people's spirit and sense of personal dignity, one could witness adult men crying. 
Once all the dirty business is taken care, company will have a song and dance summer party where the CEO will crack jokes in his southern folksy accent and CFO will talk about how all accounting books are looking great (with reduced financial liability).
Come summer, they will hire younger, cheaper and fresher faces who will continue to fuel its innovation engine.
Afterall, people are disposable.
advice_to_mgmt:
Break the hidden inner tribes and cliques
Question whether such high attrition results in gained productivity

years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Really live their values, high on integrity and doing right by customers & employees first. Great culture with people who really want to make a difference. Benefits outside of cash compensation are great. Innovation and bold leaps are encouraged, celebrated
cons: Middle management too protected and empowered. Taking in world class talent at the bottom and best of the best make it to the top, but the middle if full of org structures that can be their own toxic pits. One bad leader and your comp, career outlook, and day to day life sucks...Pretend to care about employee opinion/feedback, but no serious changes are made to fix known issues. Also lots of legacy technology and thinking, manual processes live for decades.
advice_to_mgmt: Stop affording middle management the protection and total benefit of the doubt. Empower individual contributing employees to be the difference and get things done, take their opinions over that of directors when entire group is sending consistent message of issues.

review_title: Great Company, great leadership in key positions, and bright future
years_at_company: I worked at Intuit full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Intuit offers a great total compensation package. Leaders across the organization are taking training to drive strong leadership capabilities across the company, diversity and inclusion is on the right path and becoming apart of the DNA, and the company will only continue to grow with the onslaught of big data and AI.
cons: Long term employees can be underpaid versus the market for the same position.
advice_to_mgmt: Sasan is a great CEO...but he is an even better person. Continue to improve daily!

review_title: Full time is awesome but contractors have the cards stacked against them
years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
* Excellent and competitive pay for full time and contractors.
* Great Culture and professionalism.
* Medical and health benefits by far exceed everywhere else.
* A lot of social events throughout the year including supplied alcohol.
* Depending on team the work life balance is flexible.
* Insane amount of maternity and paternity leave.
cons:
* Contractors are second class citizens.
* Converting to full time from contractor is extremely difficult and rare because of the companies college hiring program being the number one priority next to diversity.
* Intuit is an echo chamber of new college grads with no practical experience.
* Managers tend to be more engineer types than diplomats with a spine.
* Really needs scrum masters because product manager and dev managers are horrible at this function.
* Promotion process is completely arbitrary and treated like new hire interviews and judged by people who have not directly worked with you or have seen your work, growth or performance.
* Shaming of bugs company wide.
advice_to_mgmt:
* Give your contractors more respect and if they have proven themselves you need to start making offers. Why the heck would you have someone for 18 months and invite them back after a 3 month go away just to invite them back. If they are worthy to come back then they should become full time employees because you just had an 18 month trial with someone proven and not an unknown entity straight out of college.
* Your recruiters need to not focus on metrics about diversity. First go for the most qualified. I've had recruiters practically tell assessors to make yes decisions because of diversity candidates.

years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 10 years
pros: I love working at Intuit for three reasons: I'm making an impact, I'm learning and growing my career, and I feel connected to my colleagues. We Power Prosperity Around the World, and we're transforming the financial lives of our customers. Intuit is driven by customer empathy and caring for our team members.
cons: We're working hard to share the Intuit story more broadly in industry. We need to continue to invest in our brand.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep being bold! I love the transformation under way!

Never have I worked at a place where integrity is so highly valued, which I love.

review_title: Absolutely no control over upper management
years_at_company: I worked at Intuit
pros: Benefits, thats it these days.
cons: Terrible upper management, very little movement upward or vertically, outside of the product department there is no coaching (which is promised as a long term plan by intuit), unrealistic goals set-forth by a company who does not participate in helping with the goal numbers set by corporate
advice_to_mgmt: Fire the upper management for both sales and customer support, and hire people who actually care about the people who work for them. If you are looking at goals, making sure they accurately looking at corporate participation. The fact that corporate won’t touch people in upper management is a huge factor in employees leave. There are people at the Boise office who do not care for those that work for them, and they are not held accountable for their actions whatsoever - HOLD THEM ACCOUNTABLE. There are people in upper management who belittle people - HOLD THEM ACCOUNTABLE

years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 3 years
pros: I work seasonally for Intuit. My title is Senior Tax Expert and I work from my own home. Everyone from my manager down to my co-workers are so supportive and they want you to succeed to the highest of your abilities. If you get into trouble, you can ask for help and get it quickly and everyone is willing to help you. The training is is good and you need to be fast, fast,fast.
cons: There should be more training regarding the metrics because Turbotax uses the metrics to make their decisions about the employees. I can be too slow to ask for help, so my suggestion is when you realize your metrics are staying too low, ask you manager to help you. When you succeed, your manager succeeds.
advice_to_mgmt: The training needs to cover not just the software but also be more up front about the metrics. Another bit of advice is to let the agents know how to handle the irate customer who screams. Let us know we do not have to put up with such demeaning behavior.

review_title: Annual layoffs with great benefits for Full Time Employees
years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Great benefits, cafeteria, exposure to lots of different software tools, company name looks good on resume. Working as a contractor is best for expectations on future at the company.
cons: Annual layoffs, open crowded office space to do work, glass rooms for important employee meetings, low technical, can be a depressing and over-worked environment.
advice_to_mgmt: Going back to the former 'annual layoff' culture is not a good turn for the new Intuit leadership. For employees remaining after layoffs each year it's way too depressing, plus there is now more work with less people. Also, moving US Intuit jobs to India should be unheard of in record profit times at Intuit. It's hard to explain to outsiders and make the company attractive to smart employees.

years_at_company: I worked at Intuit full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Great place to work. True to their values. Amazing team of employees

review_title: Good place to work, only if you are in the sweet spot
years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Employee friendly policies and culture
- Good WLB
- Strong, inspiring exec leaderships, takes right big bet calls
- Executive push for strong SWE culture, related investments in developer tooling
- Ethical , fair , and considerate immigration support
- Lot of goodwill for flagship products, real tangible impact to people's financial lives. You can take pride that you are making a difference
cons:
Senior/Middle management sucks, very territorial
- Cross boundary, inter -disciplinary work difficult, even though senior exec support. Thats because territorial point above. Cross collaboration attempts perceived as threats rather than opportunity, even though the official spin is other way around
- Too much effort in planning, less on executing. Every year there is new buzzword. There seems to be new 3 year plan every 6 months.
- too much emphasis on "wow effect", "shiny objects" in SWE outputs. Rigorous engineering, real scientific investigations are not acknowledged/rewarded , even internally my management, unless there is some external (to team) wow event.
advice_to_mgmt:
Leaders seem always busy "planning", not connected to engineers on ground. Many VPs may not even know their engineers by face.
- Even though we adopted Agile, senior leadership though process is still "waterfall". There is fear of failure , risk taking is not encouraged, only big milestones are worth celebrating.
- There are some really good talented people around, but their energies are not effectively utilized or even recognized. Keep your "talent acquisition" hat open even internally.
- Decentralize decision making more, cut down on layers and wrapper SDKs, be flexible when prescribing generic tooling
- Keep up the good work with Big Bet grooming, they make sense, and help relate SWE work to real customer work

review_title: If you've heard anything positive about this company, don't believe it.
years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Nothing good at all here.
cons:
Product quality and customer satisfaction are not prioritized. It's all about making as much money as possible, even if it takes forcing customers into things they don't want or need. Desperate money-grubbing, not delivering good products.

No work-life balance. Be available 24/7 or else. 

Worst management ever, only the worst people are made managers. People who shouldn't even have junior level roles, who think the sun shines out of their butts. They never listen to the people who actually do the real work, especially the creepy CEO.

If you're decent at your job, don't expect anyone to ever acknowledge it. Doing your job properly may annoy the people who can't do their own, and don't be surprised when they do what they can to stab you in the back and try to get you fired for doing your job well.
advice_to_mgmt: Fire everyone and burn this place to the ground.

cons: Rotating managers -- I averaged a new manager every 5 months. Nobody really cares about "career path" as you may be asked to move to a job that is not anything close to what your job title or specialty may be in the organization.
advice_to_mgmt: Provide some stability to folks and they will want to stay. Hire people and allow them to specialize in something rather than a "one size fits all" model of career building.

review_title: Great place to work, but could be better
years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than a year
pros: I've been at Intuit for a little under a year an half now, and all in all, I like the company. Some bullet points are: Great benefits, invested in improving their employees, company culture isn't an afterthought. They're also actively working to bring modern tools and technology into the development stack allowing us to do some pretty cools things
cons:
Sadly while the culture is great, and the public facing technology is what you would expect from a modern SaaS company, the immediate tools they allow you to work with are not. It's fairly obvious the their IT organisation is pretty old school. While offering both Macs and PC's, the PC's are behemoths and not fun to carry around. They're so loaded with security software trying compensate for Window's poor security that you're lucky if the batteries last an hour sometimes. Sadly the Mac's aren't much better. Using a modern Linux distro isn't even allowed so you're stuck with 2 poor options for development environments. I often feel like the policies and infrastructure their IT org has put in place is actively trying to prevent me from getting my work done. 

Oh, I almost forgot to mention they've also installed keyloggers on their laptops. Nothing says you don't quite trust your employees like key loggers, ehh?
advice_to_mgmt: Intuit does everything else so well. It may seem small but I spend my entire day working on my laptop. These IT policies are put in place in a vacuum with no input from the people they are impacting day to day. Your employees can't do their best work because we often can't use the tools that are best for the job, or they're hampered by an outdated and/or restrictive environment.

review_title: Good company...but. Lack of Career Growth - Very Hierarchical - Excessive Micromanagement
years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time
pros: Good benefits. Cutting edge - Innovative culture. Not satisfied with the status-quo but constantly striving to get better and better. They do walk the talk - “Integrity without Compromise”. Talented, driven people.
cons:
Internal opportunities are stagnant. In the years I have been with this company, I have seen time and time again where leadership would rather hire from outside the company than develop or cultivate development opportunities for internal employees. Because of this consistent behavior, upward mobility is very scarce within this company. To be certain, sometimes you need to bring in external talent to move things forward and address gaps, however, you also need to set your current employees up for success with targeted opportunities for development and a career path. The scale is tipped much further to the external hiring side at this company. Promotions to a director position are as rare as a Bigfoot sighting. You would have a better chance to get ahead (statistically) at this company by leaving, landing a higher position at a different company, and then trying to get hired back at Intuit at that same acquired level or higher. Seriously, if you do get hired here, plan to stay right where you are for a long, long time.

A very hierarchical culture by comparison to other companies I have worked for. Way too many hierarchical “roadblocks”. It seems childish (and it really is), but team managers and directors do not exactly like or encourage managers to communicate directly with executives if they are not involved directly with the communication. They want to be seen and heard when execs are involved. Very common for emails or presentations to be scrutinized many, many times over before being “allowed” to be sent or presented. Slows the communication process WAY down and creates a lot of extra work just to get communications out. No…this is not just “coaching” employees on effective executive communication. This behavior is prevalent and falls way outside of simple “coaching”. It’s sad, but the behavior shows a real lack of trust and results in a lot of wasted time due to excessive, un-needed micromanaging. I think if the executives could track the amount of time and effort that gets expended just to get communications to them from the “troops” they would immediately put a stop to this “roadblocking” behavior. It is no exaggeration to say that this bureaucratic back and forth consumes hours out of mine and my colleagues work week on a very regular basis. 

No doubt about it…Intuit goes through a very careful and extensive process to recruit and hire just the right candidates. They thoroughly vet candidates and form "Assess for Awesome" teams to ensure all candidates are very carefully reviewed and then selected. They pour a lot of time and effort into this process and then turn right around and micromanage the hell out of their people. It sounds ridiculous…and it really is. Intuit goes to great lengths to attract and bring in top talent…and then they simply don’t trust them to do the job they thoroughly vetted and hired them to do in the first place. I am constantly amazed at the amount of time directors and team leaders must have to be able to micromanage their staff all day. Long story short - lack of trust is a VERY big issue at Intuit. It is worse in some areas than others…but it exists throughout. It has gotten worse in the years I have been here.
advice_to_mgmt:
Create more opportunities / upward mobility for the employees you currently have. Every time you hire for a senior position outside the company, ask yourselves why this candidate had to be external and what could we have done better to ensure the internal employees were being developed to grow into that position. 

You have a really solid hiring process…learn to trust the process and then learn to trust the people you hired to do their job. Lack of trust is felt throughout the “troops” and has created a lot of frustration. People here really feel devalued when they are not allowed to do the job you hired them to do without all of the “shoulder-surfing”. Employees here have some impressive credentials from the colleges they attended to the previous jobs they held. They worked hard to get here...and getting hired here at Intuit is not easy. Get out of their way and allow them to do what you hired them to do. The fact is, you may actually learn from your team if you provide them the opportunity to work with their own creativity and their own experience rather than constantly pushing them to ensure things get done in exactly the manner you would do it. Stick to establishing the high-level direction and goals with your teams and then stay out of weeds unless specifically asked. Your team members will feel more empowered in their jobs and have a better sense of job satisfaction when they know they are being relied on and trusted to drive their specific area.

Stop the childish behavior of creating hierarchical roadblocks. Allow your teams to be seen and heard by execs without all of the constant and time-consuming micromanaging. Your people will never develop the skills of solid, thoughtful, effective executive communication if you are always the one communicating for them. 
One of your main responsibilities as a team leader is to provide your people with the tools and experiences they will need to grow and succeed. Don't lose sight of how important this aspect of being a team leader is. Put your team first - it is not all about you. Trust in the fact that the success and overall happiness of the team will reflect on you and your abilities to lead. No doubt, a team that feels dejected and devalued will reflect on you and your abilities as well.

review_title: Solid financials and "employee first" mentality are strong points, hazy org and comp structure lacking, politics galore
years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than a year
pros:
Been working at Intuit just over a year now (in the QuickBooks org), and I'm fairly happy here. The vibe is positive overall in most areas, and they have all the perks a well off company should be providing in the valley: on-site gym, generous 401k match, ESPP, snacks, and well maintained campus. It's no Google, but it's solid in this regard.

There are engaging events for engineers from time to time, such as tech talks and "engineering days", where you focus on something unrelated to your work that you're passionate about. It's refreshing to have the chance to develop your skillset while improving the product.

For the most part, very approachable and down to earth management hierarchy. Transparency is one of the things I like the most and greatly appreciate knowing how the team/business is doing and what things we do well and what needs to be improved on.

Opportunity for advancement is certainly available as long as you can navigate the politics well, which I suppose leads me into the "Cons" section...
cons:
This place reeks of tenured employees that stifle innovation and resist change for the sake of simplicity every chance they get. Big egos with subpar engineering backgrounds pollute the codebase with terrible architectural patterns that get replicated by fledgling developers. This also causes issues with team dynamics, as the louder voices in the room tend to hinder a productive work environment. The resulting toxic culture (and rampancy of politics) is unfortunately my biggest issue with working here.

Organizational structure rotates regularly, so often times your "mission" or role is unclear. I've had 3 managers already in my time here, and is sad to spend all that time developing rapport only to have to start over again. 

Mobile is definitely an afterthought but trending in the right direction. A lot of architectural patterns and organizational projects skew toward a more web/backend focused effort. 
 
Compensation is also a frustration point, specifically RSU grants. Quite frankly, they're pathetic given how well the company is doing, and far under what major tech players are paying. If you want your company to be respected in the tech industry, you have to pay your talented engineers well. 
There's also a large disparity between the rating system and comp -- two staff engineers with an identical rating could have RSU amounts that differ wildly enough to bring suspicion of favoritism to the table. I've heard they're working on this though.
advice_to_mgmt: De-power the "problem children" that are stifling both product innovation and personal growth of the team. Stop changing team structure every 3 months. Reward the employees that are a positive influence on the team. Remove favoritism on the tech stack.

years_at_company: I have been working at Intuit full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Great benefits. Compensation is pretty good. Flexible hours.
cons:
Intuit is a very politically driven company. Tax DIY is a dying business since many competitors are offering DIY tax prep software for free. Though Intuit tries hard to be a software company, it is not entirely a software company. There are more people in the functional space than in the engineering department. 
The quality of engineers is pretty bad because good engineers usually cannot survive the politics here. The company hires a lot of contractors, so that causes a lot of churn.
advice_to_mgmt:
Honesty and integrity is key to retaining top talent. Try hard to remove politics. Have a zero tolerance policy for leaders who cover their mistakes and reward leaders who admit mistakes and who are open enough to share their learnings. Reward employees who operate in a boundaryless manner. 
Recognize that company transformation at the expense of hurting existing employees has a cost associated with the future of the company. Balance is key to successfully transforming the company to the point where the gains that are made is durable and lasting. 
Continuous re-organization indicates poor decision-making skills. 
Without retaining the top talent the company's future is as at risk.

review_title: Sad Deterioration of a Once-Promising News Outfit
years_at_company: I worked at Bloomberg L.P. full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Competitive pay (although they're whittling it down fast), decent health care, 401(k), free snacks and coffee.
cons:
What little journalistic talent remains at Bloomberg News is no match for the mass of mediocrity that has risen up there. In the past five years, the standard of quality has gone from excruciatingly high to preposterously low. 

While political correctness and identity politics run rampant, gender discrimination is still quite prevalent, despite all the internal corporate propaganda stating otherwise. And nobody, man nor woman, should feel comfortable growing old there. Experience has become a liability as the company is clearly focused on lowering the average age (and salary) of non-management employees through attrition, targeted layoffs and firings.

You shouldn’t consider Bloomberg News as a mid-career journalist. If you’re age 40 or older, don’t even bother applying. You probably won't even land an interview, let alone get hired. They have been actively recruiting minorities and LGBTQ people, though. So there might be some exceptions if you fit any of those categories. It does seem like a good fit for a kid just out of college looking to get some experience and then move on to something better. Sadly, it’s become that kind of place.
advice_to_mgmt: No advice because it all appears to be going according to their plan.

review_title: Role Growth, but no Career Growth
years_at_company: I worked at Bloomberg L.P. full-time for less than a year
pros:
Medical Benefits
Lateral movement
Free Food

cons:
You can progress your role into manager and even higher but if you plan to have a career in finance or quantitative analytics, it might be a challenge or will take a long time. Your role can progress but your career will be stagnant and be stuck in customer service.

Admin/Customer Service disguised as "Analyst" Job.

Claim to be a tech company but relies heavily on Excel. If Microsoft takes out Excel, Bloomberg will shut down along with the world market that relies on Bloomberg data.

Not a finance job but a financial product ambassador; people do modelling and financial analysis but it is just to make "clients" have ease of use and show more functionality for the terminal. Analyst/Analytics here is synonymous to knowing what the client/customer needs and not necessarily include any quantitative analysis. Might be less than 5% that quantitative analysis will be required for an Analyst job.
advice_to_mgmt: Check your people's qualifications. For such a selective hiring process, the job/role placement is disappointing. Technical people are placed on admin roles while non-technical are placed in technical roles.

review_title: Toxic environment and extreme micro management
years_at_company: I have been working at Bloomberg L.P. full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Large organization with a global presence, benefits and snacks are generous.
cons:
You'll notice that all the 4 and 5 star reviews are from junior employees with less than 2 years at the firm or from H1B's glad to have a job, they're enamored by the free snacks and sponsorship. I've been with them for over a decade and have gotten to see this company get worse over the years. It used to be a great company that looked after its employees, but over last 2 years they have been looking to get rid of anyone with a decent salary and tenure. Have been replacing with kids out of college at a fraction of the salary and zero experience then working them to death, turnover is staggering with very high numbers of new recruits leaving within the first 2 years. Sales managers have almost no experience of selling and are promoted only for their micro management prowess. 

Sales targets are ridiculous and they count net performance, that means that salesperson takes a hit for any removals, but gets NO credit for renewals. Sales is blamed for every removal even though product teams have not developed a decent product in almost a decade, and are obsessed with growing revenue even though there is no new product/service to help in the growth. So their strategy has been to double/triple/quadruple prices for existing services which makes it extremely difficult to have any new sales discussion with this clients, then blame is laid upon the sales force for not hitting ridiculous targets.
advice_to_mgmt: Come down from your ivory towers and experience a day in the life of your employees or better yet speak to one of your customers before you reach your ridiculous business decisions.

years_at_company: I have been working at Bloomberg L.P. full-time

years_at_company: I have been working at Bloomberg L.P. full-time for less than a year
pros: The analytics training program provides employees with an excellent foundation in market concepts. I found their Fixed Income training the best a recent grad can acquire. Additionally, there are excellent exit opportunities from what I've heard from past employees.
cons:
First, let's get the job description straight. If you choose to join the analytics program you will be a customer service representative where you will be "on queue". Quite literally called "The Help Desk" you will be treated as if you work at Comcast and will solve client inqurires (usually 3 at a time). Questions could include but are not limited too:
"CALL ME"
"My launchpad is broken"
"Can you confirm the IPO date 943819 US Equity was on 9/8/2017?"

However, it's truly the management that lack of empathy that creates an environment that makes the desk an inky black hole where every molecule of light/joy cannot escape. A few examples include:
-Time off has to be asked 120 days in advance no matter the situation during the holidays/summer
-No breaks (including the bathroom) are to be given if the queue is busy
-Genuine disregard for the emotions, aspirations, and general well being of employees.

Ever read 1984?
advice_to_mgmt: Wipe the slate clean. The TLs are good people. But SF needs another head of analytics from NY. It's a classic case of Reganomics - negative energy trickles down from the top and I'm sure you can guess the rest.

review_title: Toxic, abusive environment with poor management and little diversity
years_at_company: I worked at Bloomberg L.P. full-time for more than a year
pros: Great benefits, great pay, ability to provide feedback on managers
cons:
Horrible management- "tech leads" or managers - in Engineering - are promoted to their positions based solely on tenure not on ability or acumen
People don't know how to manage other people
Little diversity in engineering - witnessed 2 women get let go in a department of about 40 men, leaving only 1 woman on the team
No work life balance - long hours expected, working from home frowned upon unless you are your manager's 'favorite'
Financial Products office team is verbally abusive, witnessed cursing, yelling/screaming, unprofessional rants many times, in person and over calls, was hung up on by a colleague because he was "not happy"
Lack of training and adequate ramp up time to learn the Bloomberg Terminal
So many people working there are long timers - been there since they graduated college...so it's hard to find people who are open minded or well rounded, they only know the Bloomberg way and they are unwilling or unable to change or embrace new ideas even though they push 'innovation' down your throat 24/7
Departments are immature and unwilling to consider changes to process, also unwilling to use any tools outside of the Bloomberg Terminal or that are not proprietary to the company
Management forces use of outdated process and software and does not embrace using the best tools out there or use even best practices
They would rather you fit their style of work and not bring new ideas to the table
Developers are mollycoddled incessantly and bad habits are enabled, not disciplined
advice_to_mgmt: Act on the feedback you solicit from your direct reports

years_at_company: I worked at Bloomberg L.P. full-time for more than 3 years

cons: Poor management. Lack of growth. Egocentric. False hope. Though you get title changes, hard to get promotion with Salary. High turnover. Always remanagement/restructuring. Company not doing well financially. Majority of higher ups are white males. Sexist. Issue with harassment. And lack of diversity especially in management positions

years_at_company: I worked at Bloomberg L.P. full-time for less than a year
pros:
Nice office with good views
-Pretty good work life balance
-Decent pay
cons:
No clear track for success/moving up the ladder. 
-Performance reviews/promotions seem to be very subjective and not very quantifiable.
-Much of the leadership is ancient and has been at the company for decade(s) so not much room for growth and no true desire to innovate.
-Very outdated and proprietary tech stack.
-Using internal tools and the terminal daily is a pain.

advice_to_mgmt: Make your performance evaluation criteria less arbitrary/subjective and more transparent and quantifiable.

years_at_company: I have been working at Bloomberg L.P. full-time for more than 5 years
pros: I had some wonderful colleagues who deserved much better treatment than they received at Bloomberg.
cons: Bloomberg is more of a cult than a company. You'll be expected to dedicate yourself and your life to Michael Bloomberg and his philanthropic ventures. There's no such thing as work-life balance at Bloomberg, just work-work. While you may be scheduled to work 9 hour days (don't even think about taking a lunch break) it's more likely you'll be working 10 hour days and 11 and 12 hour days are not uncommon. For all that hard work and effort you'll be rewarded with zero job security. Loyalty is very much a one-way street at Bloomberg and layoffs are routine. Your future is solely dependent on your manager, and they change often. My first 6 reviews at Bloomberg were written by 6 different bosses. If you get one that takes a dislike to you, regardless of your performance, you're toast. I've seen hard-working, talented employees get the boot while workers who literally spend the day on their Facebook page, texting and take 2 hour lunches keep their jobs. Additionally, if you're over 50 your days are numbered. Yes, the company that prides itself on its philanthropic initiatives routinely practices age discrimination.

years_at_company: I have been working at Bloomberg L.P. full-time for less than a year

advice_to_mgmt: Be more clear about what the job entails, cause the title is extremely misleading.

review_title: Above average brand. High pay. Slightly below average culture.
years_at_company: I worked at Bloomberg L.P. full-time for more than a year
pros: High pay. Especially high base salary. Good benefits.
cons:
The culture at Bloomberg is very mixed. There is a segment of the company that is genuinely interested in leveraging cutting edge technology and making an impact. However, there is an equally large segment of the company that is reluctant to relinquish the practices they’ve been using since the mid 90s. For example, many teams use relatively modern python; but there were times where I encountered teams with no interest with updating their Linux incompatible C++93. The company has largely stagnated between these opposing factions.

There’s also a mediocre to at times hostile work environment for engineers belonging to underrepresented groups. The workforce is largely male and there are almost no engineers from ethnically underrepresented groups. This can create a lonely environment as the undiverse management doesn’t seem interested in going beyond lip service.
advice_to_mgmt: Hire more diverse managers and make an actionable commitment to improving the workplace, technically and otherwise.

years_at_company: I have been working at Bloomberg L.P. full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Benefits, Salary, Employment Stability, Good Travel Policy
cons: Micro-managerial Culture, no remote work, CRM is internally developed and cumbersome
advice_to_mgmt: Management needs to adopt traditional Saas lexicon and sales proceedures

years_at_company: I have been working at Bloomberg L.P. full-time for more than 3 years

years_at_company: I have been working at Bloomberg L.P. full-time for more than a year

review_title: Bloomberg News.....The Gilead of the media world..
years_at_company: I worked at Bloomberg L.P. full-time for more than 8 years
pros: The quiet editors deemed unfashionable whose ability to take copy that is akin to scribble and turn it into something legible are the unsung heroes of that place. Sadly the scribblers tend to be promoted.
cons:
* Micromanagement on steroids. Cameras everywhere, key strokes monitored and the time you are in the office is also measured. Make no mistake if you are one minute late expect to get an email.

* BULLYING CULTURE....it is sad to watch people who are elevated to management embrace the culture and start sending emails to people who were once friends about Bloomberg standards (which are Gilead like), social media responsibility (apply self censorship muzzle here) and writing news stories that resemble bullet points so as to keep your metrics up.

* On social media, the transgressions from personal twitter accounts were so trivial that most either stopped using social media or found alternate employment.

* SHOUTING AT STAFF IS GOOD...APPARENTLY? !!!!! Any organisation where screaming at subordinates is considered standard is one that will result in the victim seeking some form of medication, treatment, and having their self worth destroyed.....or they embrace the same behavior. Bloomberg is full of bullying managers who cannot leave their staff alone to do their jobs....constant hectoring and poor processes only compound the problem.

* POLITICAL CORRECTNESS AT A LEVEL APPROACHING MADNESS - Mike Bloomberg's weird personal views on workplace loyalty, climate change and a decent society is where the organization shaped in his likeness reaches rank hypocrisy. Despite the wacky obsession about sugary drinks in New York, the wall of sugar at the company's hideous neon offices are a reminder to never leave and drink soda for 12 hours (sorry, 14 hours a day).

* Bloomberg LP has been sued many times for being hostile to women, especially pregnant women. Despite the PR about how the company has embraced flexibility, such pieces are complete fiction and do not tell the real story of what happens when many women return from maternity leave. Feel free to read the NY Times to get the company view on females who dare to have a baby. 'Mayor Shows His Testy Side in Deposition for a Lawsuit' on April 14, 2011.'

* CLIMATE CHANGE HYPOCRISY - Bloomberg LP relies on terminal sales to many industries and takes money from BHP, Rio Tinto, Glencore, Whitehaven Coal....wait! yes coal companies whom Mike Bloomberg wants to shut down. (Mike is annoyed that people are apathetic about the approaching apocalypse but like children who rebel against religious parents it is simply a case of normal folk rebelling against having an issue shoved down their throat by billionaires. Nothing gets a Bloomberg editor giddy around the loins like the image of Hollywood stars flying in private jets to exclusive resorts to give lectures on climate and consumerism. It is amazing the air time given to people who wear spandex and pose in front of green screens for a living. 

* Like Gilead, Bloomberg has an army of Editors at Large (commanders)......this is code for former Team Leaders and Bureau Chiefs who have been kept on to write 2000 word op-eds no one reads and to hold forth in strategy sessions about what politics mean for a given country. The Sydney bureau is blessed with several Commanders in these roles as its leadership wrestles with the most gripping issue facing the island nation........Australia's misogyny problem. Month after month, the Sydney bureau's self-flagellation results in snore fests of how to get women into management positions......forget the economy, this is where the real new stories are at! (it was amazing to learn that outside the Bloomberg offices, there are men walking down the road holding their wife or girlfriend's hand.......there is hope for Australia yet).

* Not to be outdone, the London bureau have a cool social club....the LGBTQI_Women_Climate_Change_More_Women_in_Leadership_Diversity Social Club.....sadly I didn't get to join this social club.....

* Vacation is all but in name only....
advice_to_mgmt: None....you guys are bonkers.

review_title: Amazing company where you can learn a lot
years_at_company: I worked at Bloomberg L.P. full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Mike Bloomberg is a visionary

Top notch benefits and paid time off

Exceptional focus on philanthropy if you want to participate

Incredible headquarters building

A truly disruptive technology that changed the way information is disseminated in the financial markets

Team environment

If you are selling at Bloomberg you will never have to work a weekend
cons:
Very limited opportunities to move up - management is mostly made up of entrenched "lifers"

Unusual compensation structure for sales - if you are used to doubling your salary with your commission, you will probably take a pay cut.

The flagship product has so saturated the market that the company now relies on growth through the selling of "ancillary" products. Some of those products are successful but if you are trying to sell one that isn't, it's an uphill climb. That said, there are lots of opportunities to move to other products within Bloomberg.
advice_to_mgmt: It's hard to give advice to such an incredibly successful company.

review_title: Great pay but legacy software systems
years_at_company: I have been working at Bloomberg L.P. full-time for more than a year
pros: great pay. Bloomberg pays for top quality employees. The benefits are great. If your manager likes you, you have a lot of resources to accomplish your goal. And Bloomberg would spend lot of resources to accomplish its goals.
cons: The computer engineers do not work that hard. If your manager does not like you, it is tough to get the resources to effectively finish your project. My primary manager was replaced due to my manager's performance issues. The new manager did not like the team so he was a little bit hostile.
advice_to_mgmt: Make it easier to move to another department if company and division strategy changes.

years_at_company: I have been working at Bloomberg L.P. full-time for more than a year

cons:
Your experience varies from manager to manager.

advice_to_mgmt: Make it more transparent for employees to address issues with direct management.

years_at_company: I worked at Bloomberg L.P. full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Dedicated people. Good work life balance.
cons: You will learn a lot about Bloomberg's legacy technologies - knowledge that won't be very useful anywhere else you go. The management lets people they deem to be useful get away with a lot of bullying they shouldn't be allowed to do. It's hard to advance.

years_at_company: I have been working at Bloomberg L.P. full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Bloomberg is a legit and well respected company. The CEO is amazing and some awesome colleagues. Plenty of young colleagues (if you're younger and starting out). Volunteering activities are great. Company is serious about philanthropy.
cons: Global Data is a joke and a revolving door for college grads. They make you go through a fairly lengthy interview process, but the full-time role is a joke. Trust me when I say that you're not doing anything finance related. You're in a back-office role doing manual data entry which can be automated at any time. In fact, Bloomberg is pushing for automation so I wouldn't be surprised to see Global Data dissolved. Also it really matters which team you land on. No matter what, STAY AWAY from fixed income. Specifically the mortgages team and to some extent bonds. You'll be going through all the same issues as everyone else in Global Data but with A LOT more work than your non-fixed income colleagues. Besides Global Data being a joke, be prepared to face A LOT of politics. There's politics all over the place. Since there's so many fresh college grads, it feels like college with college drama. "Senior leaders" are outdated. Some have been with the company for several decades simply because of their connections. In fact, since there's so many people for so few TL spots, the only way to move up is to be friends with management. You get "unlimited sick days" but no one takes them because there's a stigma. If you do end up taking one, if it's Friday or Monday, be ready to face judgement when you're back. Work from home is also so so hard to get. It's pretty basic these for companies to offer this, but the company doesn't want to set a standard of working from home daily. Thus, managers are encouraged to not let their teams work from home. As for career prospects after, there's very little. Poor at best. Think about it, you're not doing finance so no banks want you. Since you're doing data entry all day, you're not developing technical or finance skills. Also you're working with Bloomberg systems which isn't applicable to other companies. If you were working with SAP, Qlik, Tableau then that would actually be useful but you're not. Lastly, the location sucks. You're not in Princeton, you're in freaking- Skillman, New Jersey. Never heard of it? Exactly.
advice_to_mgmt: Get new middle management (all Skillman Product Managers and most TLs)

review_title: Fantastic place to work with a very high ceiling!
years_at_company: I have been working at Bloomberg L.P. full-time for more than a year
pros: The people, culture, benefits, work hours, access to training, and more. The product we sell and the clients we serve covers a wide array of the financial sector and financial products, with solutions as specific to analyzing very complicated securities all the way to front-to-middle-to-back enterprise offerings. Working with those tools and the clients who use them provides access and insights to the markets inner workings that would be hard to find anywhere else.
cons: Hiring could always be better to recruit better/more talent. There are challenges with very young/inexperienced groups in some departments, with higher churn rates and constant training - as a result those business units with more inexperienced staff may move slower than the speed at which managers want to drive the company. That's not a unique problem in a tight labor market though.
advice_to_mgmt: Trim some of the fat, and use that to promote and higher more aggressive talent to grow a mature company. Continue to push harder in enterprise offerings, but potentially as well in niche product areas ripe for disruption. Focus more on increasing morale (it's good but can be better) and openly encourage (more than it already is) unfiltered honesty.
