cons: Leadership needs more organization and structure.

review_title: Solid place to work in the Bay Area
years_at_company: I have been working at Walmart eCommerce full-time for less than a year
pros: Good office location (right off the freeway, quick shuttle to BART and close to S.F.). Pleasant office environment and good benefits.
cons: Very political. Some departments/teams are saddled with bad managers. There's a reason most job postings don't list a department/category. Also, it's a big company, so things move at a glacial pace.

review_title: Do you not work for this company
years_at_company: I have been working at Walmart eCommerce full-time for more than 8 years
pros: This company tries to compete with other tech companies in the bay area. They will make you promises and will never deliver.
cons: This company does not support anyone over the age of 35, they allow managers to make their own rules and not adhere to company policies. I would never recommend anyone to work for this company, unless you want to lose your soul. They are incredibly top-heavy with senior directors with no direct reports, it is a joke. Their health insurance is disgusting and incomplete. They claim to have flex PTO but managers can decide to not adhere to it. The company is too large to manage its managers and the managers know that. And they can do whatever they want.

years_at_company: I worked at Walmart eCommerce full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Lots of opportunity to grow because everyone around you is learning as well. They love hiring recent college grads from the top schools and there's a different promotion track for this group. As such, the culture feels like a college social setting. Free sodas, shuttles from different parts of the Bay Area and free parking in the garage.
cons: Spent over 10 years in the San Bruno office and remember leadership having empathy for work/life balance. Within the last 2 years, this has eroded. It's typical to work through lunch and have lunch meetings especially during the top of the week and during Q4. Because business direction usually comes out of the Jet offices in Hoboken NJ, the East Coast work mentality is very strong. Lack of diversity (female/people of color) in upper management. There are no free lunches or snacks.

review_title: Highs and Lows, Varies by category
years_at_company: I have been working at Walmart eCommerce full-time for less than a year
pros: Analytical aspects of the role are interesting. Some days you can leave at 4:30. Different categories tend to have different focuses in terms of how much time you spend on site merchandising, forecasting, negotiating with vendors, etc.
cons: Some weeks you can be required to stay in the office until 8pm. In some categories you spend as much time forecasting units and estimating financials as you do driving business. Seems like you're just being the Financial Planner's assistant. Bc of the variance in categories, some people get very easy categories to run while others are given a huge workload.

review_title: Good place to start your career

pros: Work with big-name vendors -Gain skills in buying, merchandising, pricing, negotiating
cons: Slow progression -Little say in what category you manage -Salary isn't competitive with other San Francisco positions

years_at_company: I have been working at Walmart eCommerce full-time

years_at_company: I have been working at Walmart eCommerce full-time for less than a year
pros: Free gym, Unlimited PTO (at your manager’s discretion)
cons: When I started here, there was a severe lack of training. We were just thrown into the job and expected to perform. I appreciated the autonomy, but really had no sense of direction. To be honest, most of what you do makes a marginal difference. What really drives your performance is the category you’re given. Some things sell, others don’t. Another issue I had was with my manager. Putting down your employees and being passive aggressive isn’t the best way to build a team or any type of camaraderie. If someone is actually struggling, make an authentic effort to help him/ her. Don’t belittle them for not knowing something, instead teach them. That way they can go on and teach others who may be confused. If there’s one positive thing I can take from this experience, its taught me how to deal with bad management and how to be professional about it. If it weren’t for some of the great friends I’ve made, this job would’ve been a horrible experience.

years_at_company: I worked at Walmart eCommerce full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Company will every now and then sponsor fun events to boost morale. High-focus on the customer. At-cost snacks sold in cafeteria.
cons: Acceptance of bullying and rampant discriminatory actions by management with HR unwilling to acknowledge issue or provide help to target/victims (I saw this happen disproportionately to many colleagues who were from historically disadvantaged backgrounds such as women, Asians, non-US citizens). Culture of "white is right". Lack of training opportunities and career path for growth.

years_at_company: I have been working at Walmart eCommerce full-time for more than a year
pros: Unlimited PTO Google Shuttles Some of the people I work with are really great.
cons: Politics. Toxic Review System. Tough Culture. High Turnover. The employee review process fosters a negative environment where sucking up is rewarded and employees have to campaign to grow. Reviews are not based on actual performance but based on who leaders are pushing forward for promotion each review round. All leaders discuss the candidates up for promotion and have to fight to get their associates promoted. This creates the suck up environment because associates campaign to get promoted with their leaders peers. This deters and takes away from the work. Great work and talent is not rewarded. Leaders say growth is owned by the associate. No accountability for fostering and building talent. This means there are no growth opportunities and leadership gives employees a "figure it out yourself" mentality. Being a "yes man" is rewarded, critical thinking and actually caring about the work and the end customer is completely disregarded. Top talent leaves because of this. Pay is not comparable to the tech industry at all. High turnover in leadership. Every 6 months the strategy changes due to new leaders. This isn't for innovation this is chaotic and all progress is set back because a new leader wants to prove themselves instead of evolving and building upon the successes that have been established. Leadership tries to say they operate like a startup, which is an excuse for a chaos and disorganization. This is Walmart, this is a well established brand with incredible brand DNA. STOP trying to sell it like it is something else and sell it for what it is, which is the longest standing, largest retailer in the world. Be proud of that. Managers are treated like entry level associates and are not given resources to elevate their work and continue to grow individually while impacting business and the customer experience to the most potential. Leadership continues to use budget to layer directly under themselves - Creating top heavy orgs. Bottom line everyone is so eager for their own growth they are failing to lift up and grow talent from the bottom up. Leaders don't actually want to manage people or do the work. Leaders will take credit for work and not give appropriate credit. Bait & Switch for level hiring - promised one thing and hired in at a lower level, stinting career growth and putting employees below market value for compensation.

review_title: Good for recent grads. Not good as a career choice.
years_at_company: I worked at Walmart eCommerce full-time for more than a year
pros: Adequate training, ability to learn many useful and marketable tools -Some very nice, intelligent co-workers to work with and learn from -Competitive pay, benefits for employees -On-site cafeteria and fitness center -Ability to work from home when needed
cons: Too many in-house systems clog up workflow, resulting in useless/mundane tasks -Upper management lacks leadership or the ability to pass objectives down, sometimes act downright disrespectful. -Office politics, atmosphere of in-crowds, overt hostility between top managers -Little opportunities for advancement, company does not know how to recognize or retain talent. -Lack of structure and accountability, many projects are shelved mid-stream -Company is trying too hard to be tech, straying from core values and alienating workers in the process. -Benefits lacking for contractors, false promises to hire contractors on FT. -Holidays can be hectic

review_title: Category management could learn some people skills
years_at_company: I have been working at Walmart eCommerce full-time for less than a year
pros: Great starting point from colege, there are many tools you can learn from and the coworkers are super friendl and helpful. The company has a lot of resources and is trying to grow in many different directions.
cons: I'm not sure if the open desk concept is sometimes forgotten by upper management when you can overhearing them talking negatively about the people they manage. This makes me believe there is a misunderstanding in how to properly communicate with one another. Really hoping Wal-Mart can correct this issue as having effective, respectful, integrity for one another is a prerequisite to being successful. The company has high potential but lets remember this isn't a high school.

review_title: Largely underestimated because of the surrounding big tech companies
years_at_company: I have been working at Walmart eCommerce full-time for more than 3 years
pros: The rumors that everyone is happy at Walmart Labs is true - Impactful work, helping store associates, streamlining the customer's experiences, the app, etc - All my managers are always smiling, genuinely - No one has a huge ego, unlike the rest of the Bay Area tech scene - Managers care to see how you feel about the overall team/company - Remote friendly - Everyone is autonomous (slackers beware) - Career opportunities are there, like most corporate companies
cons: Lots of CEOs, it's a bit confusing what they all do - Parking is limited - Path to get hired seems to be to come in as a contractor first - No apprenticeship programs for people starting their careers - Process-heavy interviews in the name of "removing bias" but involves more biased managers therefore denying candidates more often. - No Diversity & Inclusion programs (if they exist, they don't actually do anything) - No Unconscious Bias assessment and training. - No inclusive internships (exclusive to college kids for 2-3 months of the year) - For being the largest employer in the world, they don't hire very many Junior/Associate-level/recent grads. - Not very diverse (you have better chances if you're white, Asian, Indian, or a man) - No outreach for those with alternate career paths (self-taught people & freelancers will have a hard time getting hired) - Apparently lots of candidates take offers from neighboring companies because Walmart salaries don't compare. The reason is "we're not a tech company". - You have to be a self-starter to get things going - Holiday season is a busy season - Few holidays

review_title: Good place to work with some riders
years_at_company: I have been working at Walmart eCommerce full-time for more than 3 years
pros: 1. Great opportunities to learn, especially for fresh graduates beginning their careers. 2. Flexible hours and work schedules...depending on the group. 3. Decent perks, salary, and overall comp. 4. Diversity is great and aggressively promoted.
cons: 1. Nepotism in hiring. 2. Lack of transparency in a lot of things. 3. Reporting structure is lopsided..as a data scientist your scope to grow might be limited unless you are heavily IT focused. 4. Because of the above reasons, possible to find yourself reporting to someone not competent enough.

years_at_company: I have been working at Walmart eCommerce full-time for less than a year
pros: It's still Fortune 1. Also, the work can be highly visible. And if you have the patience to deal with condescending behavior and a top-down culture, you might be able to introduce new technology, or at least be able to use it yourself.
cons: The company micro-manages and uses tools that only they have heard of, which makes remaining marketable challenging. Additionally, the micro-managing removes any desire to grow, which is what all the studies show, but Walmart is too big and too profitable to care. I've had a boss look over my shoulder since day one, micro-manage my work my first week to the point where he was correcting my grammar (which is what I have pretty much studied my entire life, and "corrected" it to something that was so wrong it made me cringe). He's also infantilized me through both actions and words, and when I dare think, he says the same thing, but a different way because after all, that is how we manage in 2018 like it's the 1960s. In stereotypical/clichéd fashion, there are too many 20-something males running around with stunted maturity and inflated egos. Misogyny and narcissism come to mind.

years_at_company: I have been working at Walmart eCommerce full-time
pros: Reasonable pay and work environment
cons: 1) Company is super political. Expect some people to be catty, some people to be territorial, and be prepared to be mentally tough. Don't let management fool you into thinking that people are easygoing - they're not. Full of Jerks in the management, if you are not playing their games, you will be forced out. 2) The workload is huge. Burned-out is inevitable and no one cares. 3) Promotions are predictable due to being based on favoritism and nepotism, which put non-experienced, non-human jerks in management team, a joke for an established company. 4) Lack of diversity, especially at WalmartLabs. Group thinking and covering-up for being unproductive. "Respect each other" is not part of culture now. 5) Preferential hire put a lot of unqualified people on their positions.

cons: This place can hardly be called a tech company, outdated technologies, unstable infrastructures, very limited cloud resources, lack of expertise in its own cloud infra team, low efficient cross team communications. Managers tend to avoid making key decisions and are good at playing a long term doing-nothing game. Undocumented hiring criteria and poorly adopted annual review (now it's biannual) put a lot of people into unqualified positions. If you're looking for a place to grow as IC, don't waste your time here.

years_at_company: I worked at Walmart eCommerce full-time for more than a year
pros: *Pays better than many other companies. *Udemy courses online are free ( not all but most) which is the only learning opportunity within the company
cons: * No parking * horrible food * unassigned seating, have to hunt for a desk every morning, chargers, headphones ,chairs and other accessories get stolen if left unattended at desk, specially if left overnight. *Extremely political, extremely tight coupling between teams which is totally unnecessary, forcing collaborative work. With collaborative work, it’s not always clear who has done what, which leaves the door open for a colleague or your manager to take undue credit for your work. * People expect to be spoon-fed in the name of collaborating and get promoted regardless. * Allegiance is held in higher regard than actual performance. *Open communication is held against you. *Nepotism is prevalent. *No on-boarding *No goal setting * HR seems to be non-existent, its well known that HR is meant to safe guard the company's interests in every company, but still, in other places they do have some tools to keep managers in check from abusing their power so blatantly. We are expected to give our manager's 360 feedback in a simple email that goes to our director. There is no forum to keep the feedback confidential. Anyone who raises concerns becomes the system's target. * positions are falsely advertised. When you actually join the job, job description may not match the actual work you are given. *1 on 1 / 1:1 are formalities, its mostly a one directional conversation, no matter what you have to say, its never acknowledged by your manager or HR. Even if you show solid evidence, they will game the system to set you up for failure for next time. * Health insurance is not that great. * Unlimited PTO creates a competition to take lesser time off in the team. You have to have leverage with your manager to negotiate for PTO, this often comes at the cost of long unpaid extra hours on weekends and after hours, or some other kind of favor. At the manager's whim, even a preplanned PTO can be expected to be cancelled at last moment, with serious repercussions if the employee resists. The system is very unfair.

years_at_company: I have been working at Walmart eCommerce part-time

years_at_company: I worked at Walmart eCommerce full-time for less than a year

years_at_company: I have been working at Walmart eCommerce full-time for more than 3 years
pros: For the outside world the name is the only thing that carries some weight in that organization. From the inside it's a different story.
cons: Extremely political, nepotism all around, quality is overlooked if you don't bow to your manager or director. Allegiance is held in higher regard than critical thinking. Open communication is frowned upon. Credentials, qualifications and experience are irrelevant as long as you're friend with the unit leaders or other cronies / puppets / minions. No development methodology, agile is a foreign concept, daily stand-ups are only ceremonial. The real work and progress relies on a few engineers on visa's, most product and program managers are accessories, almost ornamental. Systems to track features and stories are obsolete, no real sprint planning, no real sizing of features, no capacity planning, no real prioritization, no roadmaps, the pipeline is an abstract construct that is loosely defined, a black box. User and market research are completely unstructured , discussion or feedback is never welcome, very little tolerance to ponder new ideas other than those already set. Go to market is disorganized, no real strategy, no real plan, they wing it as they go. Bring many third parties to get stuff done in an incoherent manner but expecting stellar results. No budget or planning. Good luck trying to innovate and create amazing experiences, coming in and trying to look into customer loyalty you'll find literally walls when you talk to business stakeholders and executive level leaders, they'll throw around the EDLP or every day low prices company motto as gospel and you'll never get anywhere, you'll actually get blocked for the blasphemy. Mentality is entrenched in an old model that used to work 50 years ago but now prevents the company to evolve and compete with Amazon. Take for example the rudimentary breakdown of groceries and general merchandise that they currently have in their website, you can't put lettuce, eggs, and a toaster in your cart at the same time. Please ! Is this the way they're trying to "integrate" expensive brands like bonobos into the experience? Personalization is non-existent and the team is largely inexperienced, omni-channel is nothing but a mirage, order online and pickup in store is all they have and all there is. Analytics are underutilized, managers and directors couldn't care less about kpi's there's little understanding and even disregard of product data specially if it goes against one of the leaders in your team. No on-boarding for new team members, no goals setting by month or quarter, no retrospectives by sprint or quarter, no team goals alignment. Each team runs it's own way. Still you're expected to please your superior but if you don't you'll be shown the door, saw many instances of that, no reason, no discussion, just let people go, full timers and contractors alike.

years_at_company: I worked at Walmart eCommerce full-time for more than a year
pros: —It pays the bills (and the high california taxes, barely) —Free soda and snacks (on occasion) —Close to the airport
cons: Walmart relatively recently embarked on a program to hire “category specialists” from top schools around the country, promising “full ownership of a category” and a job filled with business negotiations and entrepreneurship-type experiences. What they didn’t mention is that in reality, all the decisions are made by people higher up in the company, who often graduated from bottom tier schools like the University of Phoenix. The day to day of a category specialist can be summed up with one phrase: digital shelf stocking. It is literally like stocking shelves in a Walmart store, except online. You set up new items online by filling out extensive forms (tickets), remove items from the site, change out photos, and categorize items. It is as boring as it gets. To top it all off, many teams are very understaffed, with one category specialist doing the work of 10 category specialists. Despite all this heavy lifting, management is very hesitant to give out “exceeds expectations” reviews. I know many people who work hard and long hours and only “meet expectations” on their evaluations. Most importantly, there is virtually no structured training for the job. They give you a mere two weeks of training, where literally none of the dozens of outdated systems are taught to the new hires. Category specialists are thrown head first into the work environment, in which most low level managers don’t even know how to use the systems. New hires are expected to learn quickly from fellow employees, who often themselves don’t know what to do and are drowning in work.

pros: If you claim to have built a solution that can scale heights, this is one place to confirm that claim. lots of data (stores, ecommerce, dcs etc). very big company (so lots of opportunities internally), good bonus. Will find really smart people at various levels. Lot of cultural changes after Jet acquisition (in a good way). unlimited PTO, friday lunch(not the best though), happy hours etc...
cons: Adoption of new technologies takes significant time compared to other companies nearby due to their large scale and production impacts, hence learning/hands on gets impacted. Company wants to move at a greater pace but fails to realize that several underlying homegrown solutions/frameworks can't even scale.

years_at_company: I worked at Walmart eCommerce
pros: * If you are in a good team with a good boss, it can be a decent place to work. You've got to be very careful with that "if" though - not all teams or bosses there are created equal. * It's still possible to have work-life balance there, especially if you are not in one of the teams supporting customer-facing apps.
cons: * Way too much consensus decision making. It takes forever for decisions to be made there. * Politically charged culture. It's all smiles and friendly handshakes on the surface, but if you're not on guard, they will run a bayonet through you at the least expected moment. * Contractors here are generally treated as second-class citizens. * If you are stuck with a bad boss or bad team, start looking. When I was brought on board, I discovered that the boss wanted me to use "process" to micromanage his team for him while he played Walmart politics. Meanwhile, his team was telling me how much they hated process. This was a situation that was set up to fail, and made worse when my boss started micromanaging me. I put up with a lot of guff from him, including numerous times when he would belittle me in front of his team, before he summarily dumped me by way of my agency. He was too much of a jerk to have that final "we're done here" meeting with me.

review_title: Category Specialist Role is great...with a few caveats.
years_at_company: I have been working at Walmart eCommerce full-time for more than a year
pros: Benefits of WM/CS Role: -work with amazingly talented and smart people who know the ins and outs of retail strategy -manage a business with the ability to take risks (b/c you're backed by the largest company in the world -literally get to change how people shop -be part of a team who is similar in age and life experience as you -close to San Francisco -free transportation to work--super huge perk! -AWESOME work life balance -free gym and classes
cons: Downsides to WM/ CS role: -it's a new program so there is uncertainty with career trajectory -culture dynamics are somewhat awkward between WM and acquisition companies -my team is kind and fun and friendly but it's like any other job where it really depends on the type of people you're with, which manager you're placed with, and the team dynamic (for me this is a huge plus but I can see if I didn't have the team I did, it could be a con) -no free food :( -increased pay year over year is not structured to incentive you to stay (i.e. someone who has 1 more year of experience coming into WM will have a larger base pay than someone who gained a year of experience at WM) -Saturation in positions above CS without promotions--no where for CSs to move long-term

review_title: Infighting at its worst; Fear-based decision making; Insecure Leaders
years_at_company: I have been working at Walmart eCommerce full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Walmart eCommerce has some smart and very talented individuals. However, the mantra in Bentonville is 'go along to get along" - antithetical to innovation and what tends to attract (and keep) tech talent.
cons: Walmart doesn't know what it wants to be when it grows up. On paper, they are doing the right things - buying companies, making partnerships, hiring smart people. However, it all falls down in the execution as the leaders in Bentonville don't REALLY want or accept the new, diverse, disruptive thinking that all brings. Instead, they just want the revenue and the smart people they've hired or acquired to keep their mouths shut and to smile and nod and to be grateful they part of Walmart. This is made very clear when we are told to "behave ourselves" or when the new talent is excluded entirely from business-critical meetings.

years_at_company: I worked at Walmart eCommerce full-time for more than 5 years
pros: + Compensation is competitive + Decent growth and acceleration if you move between teams and not stay in the same team + Comparable to other companies, you can phone it in / work at a constant 70% and still do well. + Looks good on the resume depending on the department + Campus is decent + Attractive people, seems like physical attractiveness is preferred on the business side + Decently diverse, LGBTQ+, race, gender, and etc... actually surprising. More so then their parent company (ISD / Brick and Mortar / Bentonville)
cons: Pay is good but benefits are lacking (no snacks, free food, unlimited PTO is just for show etc...) - No alcohol or cussing only applies for Directors and lower, if you're Sr. Dir and up they don't care - 1 on 1 / 1:1 are formalities, associates in other department say the same thing. - Parking is a joke still even after a massive lay off, if you find a parking spot you'll most likely get a dent or scratch - Company and Department goals are a giant moving target, changing almost every 6 months - Bonus isn't fair, Sr. Directors and up are basically guaranteed bonuses and RSU no matter how badly the company does - No culture, and even joking about culture gets reprimanded and when recruiters poach they mention they pay competitive since WM Culture is lacking. - CEO has stated numerous times that he has no faith in the teams before joining - Highly political, very. Saving face is more important than actual work performance. - 60+ hrs from Oct - Feb with no compensation - Massive lay offs every year in the dotcom side, and maybe every 6 mo for overall company (ISD / brick and mortar) - Really high turnover naturally

review_title: Great place to work, mission out on some key benefits though.
years_at_company: I have been working at Walmart eCommerce full-time for less than a year
pros: Outside of holiday season there I a great work life balance. As long as you get your job done managers are happy. I have been with the company for just over 6 months and really love the culture at the office. I am given a lot of freedoms to figure things out and make my own decisions. The company is rapidly changing so it is a great place to think outside the box. I also like the fact I have access to my manager and other managers everyday day.
cons: Two big cons. I was hired as a category specialist. Walmart has been hiring tons of category specialist and will continue to. The problem is there is no clear answer about what the path of the category specialist is. The company really needs to figure what they are going to do with category specialist soon. Another major problem is that category specialist are being hired for the same job but different category specialist are paid (starting salaries) at different levels even though we all do the same job. Just know that you can being the same job as someone else with the same title and being paid less. Also big con is that it seems like Walmart is having a hard time hiring as many category specialist as they want so new hires are being paid more than those category specialist with almost a year of Walmart experience. Basically new hires could be making more than someone with a year on the job which is a joke.

review_title: If you're talented, driven, and want to be challenged/developed -- GO ELSEWHERE.
years_at_company: I have been working at Walmart eCommerce full-time for less than a year
pros: The only positive quality of working at this company is that you know its going to be around for the next several years, so basically job security.
cons: I've been working at Walmart eCommerce for almost a year as a Category Specialist. When I was first hired, I was truly excited for the direction the company was going in to compete with Amazon. Aside from a smooth, yet misleading interview process, my entire experience thus far has been very unsatisfactory and has me looking to get out ASAP. Pay & Benefits-- For starters, if you apply to a Category Management role in the SF Bay Area, you will not be compensated for your market worth and will definitely be underpaid. The recruiters make it seem like the 10k bonus (or rather 6k bonus, after taxes) is a selling point-- don't let that fool you. In addition, you would think the benefits would help offset the lower salary, but that is definitely not the case. I know this may sound arrogant and a bit entitled, but when you're a company that makes millions in hours and you're also competing for top talent with Amazon, let alone in the Bay Area, you've got to step your game up. Culture-- Aside from mediocre pay and benefits, the office culture reeks of bureaucracy, politics, rigidness, and saps one of any energy and drive. It seems like most people are content and just going through the motions, while others are trying to turn Walmart into something its not-- an actually innovative and forward thinking company. Walmart's biggest selling point is that you get the experience of both a start up and big company-- but from my experience, any attempt at innovating, challenging the status quo, or simply lobbying to get projects worked on (because everything has to be approved by a director, director's director, VP, and so forth) makes it extremely difficult "to move with speed", "agility", or "change the way we work"-- nothing but fictional words and phrases used to create the allure of a company that wants to be considered in the same league as its competitors. Management- During my time with the company, I've reported to 3 different managers- some better than others, but for the most part, management seems to lack the emotional intelligence/people skills required to develop and retain employees. I've never been in such a hierarchical-based company. At other companies I've worked for, even directors and leaders that your manager reports to would make time to hear your perspective and develop you. At Walmart, your manager is the only person who really gets to communicate to leadership about your progress, thus if you don't agree with everything your manager says, you are seen as being defiant or "not performing well".

years_at_company: I have been working at Walmart eCommerce full-time
pros: Benefits - Work life balance - Casual dress code - Free parking on site - Real experience in managing a product category - Company as a whole is going the right direction in terms of growth and brand equity - A lot of exciting activity going on in the ecommerce space, and Walmart seems to be pivoting and innovating accordingly
cons: Mediocre training and resources to learn and develop as an employee - A lot of politics - Very restricted room for growth in this position, seeing as hundreds of people are being hired, the company will want CSs to stay in their role for as long as possible. - You will eventually be doing work that is well above your role in the hierarchy, yet not be fairly compensated/ promoted for the work. Meritocracy is nonexistant. - Very inefficient processes, lack of communication, lack of collaboration, and most employees are simply complacent. Not the place to work if you are driven.

years_at_company: I have been working at Walmart eCommerce full-time

review_title: Not a good company to work for
years_at_company: I have been working at Walmart eCommerce full-time for more than a year
pros: If you like solving complex problems in a fast paced environment, this is a great place to be. You get to solve interesting problems at scale.
cons: The new leadership team continues to mismanage their talent. They do not promote diversity in the work force, and they openly talk about wanting to hire younger candidates, which is a concern for those associates who are more experienced or have families. There is no respect for the individual, and work/life balance is not supported. This leadership team has created an almost hostile work environment and unfortunately, few people are willing to give feedback for fear of retaliation. Despite the fact that I believe in Walmart and the business that Sam Walton created, I would NOT recommend Walmart eCommerce as a place to work because they clearly have divested themselves from the values that Mr Walton believed in.

review_title: If you are considering a job here, think again - not recommended!
years_at_company: I have been working at Walmart eCommerce full-time
pros: It's exciting to work in the e-commerce industry, especially with a company that has a lot of potential and interesting things going on.
cons: It depends on the team, but what I personally saw were multiple rounds of layoffs, and a very cut throat environment. There is no job stability. No work life balance. You are not welcome if you have are older and have a family or kids - the majority of employees and those that are most valued are in their early-mid 20's, young, and willing to work 24/7. New management has killed the company. Their goal is to get rid of everyone at Walmart and replace them with teams from Jet; anyone at Walmart will always be inferior. They don't care about people, whether it is in retention or development. You are easily replaced if you are not a super smart young Harvard educated analytics type person. Let's just say that I had high hopes for working at Walmart eCommerce and although it was once a great place to work it has turned into a night mare and I am left traumatized by the number of extremely experienced, admirable people that I have seen suddenly walked out by security and laid off for no reason.

years_at_company: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than a year
pros:
Endless career paths you can pursue within one company (imagine not having to enroll in new benefits again!). 
- Everyone has personal accountability and are trusted to get work done (read: no micromanagement). 
- Work/Life balance is practiced, not just preached (I'm WFH as I write this review).
- I'm encouraged to bring my whole self to work each and every day.
cons:
Company is so large and complex it's hard to get your arms around it.
- Office environment is a little lacking (/uninspiring) if you're not at a strategic location (Binney Street > Rogers Street in Cambridge, MA)
- Benefits are not competitive with others in this space (bonuses are unreliable, if non-existent; no RSUs, etc.).

years_at_company: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
pros: The employees are the best and most collaborative people I've ever worked with and have extensive experience and knowledge and are willing to share it.
cons: No cons at this time

review_title: I love my job and I'm treated well
years_at_company: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Internal mobility - I've had several different roles and I got to choose them.
Great people - I've worked with many people at all levels of the organization, and 99% of them have been a joy to work with.
Important work - The work I do matters to IBM and I can clearly see how I contribute to IBM's strategic goals.
Diversity - It's not just a buzz word and lip service, Diversity is part of IBM's DNA. We are constantly trained on reducing internal bias and removing barriers to inclusion.
cons: It's big, and you won't always know what other teams are doing, or how you could get involved, but if you continue to build your network and stay up to date with internal news, opportunities will present themselves.
advice_to_mgmt: Over the last 2 years, our execs have really stepped up in terms of communication to employees. I'd say keep that up - continue to clarify and reinforce our priorities and continue to celebrate successes. And if you're one of the rare execs who doesn't have frequent, regular communications - text or video blog, etc., you should start. We need to hear from you! The only bad news...is no news.

review_title: Get some great experience then leverage that for other opportunities...
years_at_company: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
(1) IBM has some great training programs and developmental opportunities. 
(2) Your Team will be experienced, professional and dedicated to customer success
(3) Depth of resources... You can reach out to >400,000 people in IBM and most will be willing to help you out
(4) Good compensation and benefits
cons:
(1) Leadership has struggled with "Strategic Initiatives" and what it wants to be in the next transformation. Every part of the business needs to look over their shoulder - where might the axe fall next?
(2) Weak Manager Skills - I've been in many organizations and by far managers in IBM are not trained or prepared for the roles. They need improvement in managing their piece of the business and they need improvement on people management skills. 
(3) While they are good at acquiring software solutions - everyone of them seems to have withered on the vine and never achieved greater success than what was initially procured. Will Red Hat be different?
advice_to_mgmt:
Going into the Corp HQ you see a museum of "Business Machines". Meat Slicers, Scales, Typewriters, Computers, Printers.... That's when the penny dropped for me. 

IBM should be strategically focused on Business Machines. Quantum Computing, Servers, PCs? They build great PCs now Lenovo - low margins, They build good printers - Now Lexmark.... Business Solution Software that helps organizations run their day to day business was a good idea - the lists of solutions that brought in good revenue is almost endless! But why do they seldom thrive? Services are high quality - but spendy.

years_at_company: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
Huge company, so a ton of positions and various jobs/responsibilities
Lots of training material, but it's all Web-based (they cut actual classroom, onsite education years ago.)
Lot's of good, smart people to work around and learn from.
Name still carries some clout, but not like it did in the past.
cons:
They no longer care about their most valuable assets - people.
Leadership only concerned with stock price.
When I was laid off (2016), I had 20 yrs with them and got ONE MONTH severance.
They are shooting for 75% support staff to come from overseas.
Slow to move and keep up with more agile competitors.
Benefits keep getting cut and are worse now than 5 or 10 yrs ago.
advice_to_mgmt:
Change compensation from Stock Options to more "Customer Sat" based. Your favorite TLA (three letter acronym) can't be CTO - Cost Take Out.... becuase that's all that is heard starting beginning of 4th Qtr.
Learn to sell the "Standard Package" to SMB clients... not every customer needs the "Premium Extra Platinum Package" and SMB clients can't afford it anyway!

review_title: Great If You Can Get In, But No Job Security
years_at_company: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
pros: As with anyplace, it is the team you end up on that determines the real work environment. Every single individual I worked with was supportive and lovely The benefits are good. Health insurance is not so good unless you get promoted enough to afford the more exoensive offerings.
cons: There is little to no job security, you are pretty much a disposable cog in a giant machine and your redundancy is inevitable. In such a rapidly changing industry, IBM sheds the employees of the companies they merge with every year, as soon as whatever agreement to keep the staff employed for expires. They view people as the most expendable and renewable resource and will throw yu away as soon as your sector starts to hint an losing profit.
advice_to_mgmt: Learn about your teams strongest individual attributes and develop the careers of those people in a direction that makes the best use for their skills and passions. When their inevitable termination comes, offer transfer opportunities to your best workers in time for them to transfer to another team and recommend them to your peers that might have an opening for them.

advice_to_mgmt: Start focusing on treating employees well and improving products instead of bleeding the last bit of profit on both until they are gone.

years_at_company: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Work life balance is great. More than average flexibility to work from home whenever needed. Several teams only work in office twice a week.
cons: Management is still operating under the former company, good Ole boy system. If you're not white and or a male, you don't stand a chance of promotion, unless your manag(er/ement) is from the traditional IBM. Otherwise, all of HIS people will get the promotions and or pay increases.
advice_to_mgmt: From the GM level and up - take a step back and ask "at what point do I accept that it's not working"? There are a lot of talented people that have YEARS of experience who are ready to leave the company because you have disconnected yourself. Don't ask for the solution to a problem if you won't implement it. Stop being "bosses" and start being "leaders".

pros: Name recognition. People will be impressed when you tell them you work for IBM. It's best to work there a couple years for the experience and move on.
cons:
IBM doesn't understand the concept of Human Capital. It's all about the bottom line. Senior employees are regularly let go because they earn too much $$ and vacation. New Grads are hired for less and IBM pockets the difference.
It's an us and them feeling between management. I always felt the managers were up to something the workers shouldn't now about.
advice_to_mgmt: Be more transparent.

review_title: Depends on how lucky you yet. Minimal managerial support.
years_at_company: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than a year
pros:
There are some very cool projects that are actually useful to the government - FDA records classification, simplifying searching through HHS database. As IBM is really banking on AI to pull itself into the future, you will be exposed lots of AI techologies like NLP, computer vision, some element of creating models for classification and prediction.

The DC office is on F and 14th so very conveniently located one...
cons:
The mentorship opportunities are little to none. Everyone who has the technical competence to be a mentor is overworked and overstressed, and you can only really get them to spend time with you if you happen to be on the same project. I have been on several projects where I, with less than one year of experience, have been the lead on a project simply because everyone else is too expensive or unavailable.

While you...
advice_to_mgmt: Make sure each entry level consultant has a mentor. Staff them on projects that they want to work on.

years_at_company: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 5 years
pros: None that I can think of.
cons: IBM retaliated against me for taking FMLA leave, beware!! The moment I returned from FMLA leave due to a disability, I was retaliated against by a VP. I contacted HR on two different occasions, and they did nothing. I ended up having to contact the EEOC and they have given me permission to sue IBM due to them retaliating against me for taking FMLA leave. If you have a disability, don’t expect this company to honor protected FMLA leave even though it’s against the law if they treat you the same way they did me!
advice_to_mgmt: Follow the law when it comes to protected FMLA leave.

years_at_company: I worked at IBM full-time for less than a year
pros:
If you’re recently hired at the director+ level they pay well because no one from outside the company wants to work there.
Director+ gets you and administrative assistant which is exceedingly outdated but it’s nice not to have to do your own expenses
cons: It’s hard to describe just how sad it is to work at this company. It’s collapsing under the weight of overly complicated, inflexible business processes. There are two types of people here: people that actually do some work and walk around looking traumatized and people that fire out emails all day, clogging up everyone’s inbox or sit on 30 person conference calls and produce nothing. It’s pure lunacy. The co-location thing they did was one of the stupidest moves anyone has ever seen in business. In fact it was downright abusive and heartbreaking to watch people struggle with that decision. Directors and above spend most of their day inspecting or being inspected using these Byzantine metrics reports.Everyone is constantly worrying when they get laid off too. Within two days of working here I had decided to pull the plug and walked away from a huge paycheck. Seriously I don’t know how anyone works at this company it’s miserable.
advice_to_mgmt: Break up the company. It’s too big.

review_title: Company lacks organization and strategic direction
years_at_company: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
pros: You'll learn a lot about how to successfully play your role and operate within a huge company. You have the freedom to move to other roles quite easily. As with any large company, you have resources at your disposal. Good benefits and work-life balance.
cons: It is hard to find a role at IBM for people who would like to work 'hard'. There seems to be a lack of higher level strategic direction of the organization and ithe uncertainty is sensed by the sales reps and marketing teams. I do not think the company does a good job managing early career talent either. I experienced very little direction given since I was first hired or presentation of common options for progression. Sales, if anything, does this development somewhat better than other roles I've experienced through their training program. Workplace demographic is split. A lot of older workers and a lot of brand new employees out of college. Not much presence in the middle, illustrating the lack of opportunities for advancement from entry ranks.

review_title: Not a good company to work
years_at_company: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 5 years
pros: You have a job...that is
cons:
Tons of issues. I have been with IBM Watson for more than 4 years. Joining IBM is the worst decision I made in my career. I thought Watson might not be the same as the other parts of IBM. But I am wrong... Most of new people I lead or work with left within 2 years. I have trying all the effort I can to deliver solid foundation for Watson...but I failed...not because of me or my team. We are hard working people...because of the IBM leaders. They are the worst leaders I ever work with for my 20 years career. 

Working in IBM, you have two choice. One is to leave the company and the other is to become the people playing political against your colleagues.
advice_to_mgmt: Do not pretend you know everything and please do NOT step into those things you don't have any idea at all.

years_at_company: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Got to work mostly from home for 10 years... til they tossed me aside for cheaper offshore replacements.
cons:
As a consultant, you are required to work 106% or more of billable hours in a year, and you have to make up any vacation time that reduces that percentage.
They offer lots of training but a lot of it is garbage, and you are required to take a LOT of mandatory training that isn't even in your area of expertise.
Mgt offers help to get your job done but when push comes to shove they cannot really help at all and all they tell you is "well, we just need to get it done!"
Horrible raises! Might get 1-2% in the "good" years, zero in others even when you get a good review.
When they terminated me they said they didn't have any more jobs for me yet when I look on their career website they have 15 open jobs... offshore...
advice_to_mgmt: Stop offshoring all of our American jobs!!! It ain't right, and one day it'll be yours...

years_at_company: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 5 years
pros: As many other reviews have pointed out, the company has been going through many reorgs and transformations in the past few years, some of which were quite painful. However, the fruits of this hard work are really starting to show. The company now is almost unrecognizable compared to where it was just 5 years ago. Bureaucracy has significantly reduced. Many teams, even those in legacy business units such as Systems, have already fully adopted the most advanced industry best practices such as Agile, CI/CD, Design Thinking, etc. to great effect. Since IBM touches almost every technology that currently exists and employs people of almost every skill set, the opportunities are endless. Work-life balance is also extremely good. Most teams are very flexible with working from home or working from another IBM office.
cons: There are still great disparities between different teams, even between those within the same business unit. Many teams, especially those that have been around for a long time, have developed their own culture as well as very idiosyncratic ways of doing things. While this is not necessarily a bad thing in of itself, it does create confusion at times and present a learning curve for new hires.
advice_to_mgmt: More volunteer/social impact opportunities for employees.

cons: Too much overhead with overlapping roles which drains profitability and unmanageable consulting rates, unrealistic utilization targets for consultants, resource alignment/layoff after 10+ years of service = 1 month pay. Too many managers are unskilled in newer technologies and approaches. Not agile.
advice_to_mgmt: Remove unnecessary layers of management

years_at_company: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Respect, Advancement, training, professionalism, attitude
cons:
No cons,
Enjoyed entire experience
advice_to_mgmt: Open door policy

years_at_company: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Amazing benefits. Opportunity for advancement. Great way to start off in IT.
cons: You receive what you put in.

years_at_company: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Great work-life-balance with the ability to work from home
cons: The structure does not encourage promotions.

years_at_company: I have been working at IBM full-time
pros: Good for growth opportunities and risk taking
cons: Don't necessarily reward work, more focused on tenure

years_at_company: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Use to be a great company which supported and invested in their employees and clients. Work balance and autonomy was fantastic if you achieved.
cons: Ageism is rife. Retrenching majority of “older” people for many years who are on six figures. Replacing with young cheap labour. All about the bottom line for CEO and shareholders.
advice_to_mgmt: Get rid of CEO - has lost focus - people are very important to the success of a company.

years_at_company: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Few projects in a sap
cons: Everything is moved to offshore. Cost cutting.

years_at_company: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
pros: As an offering manager (i.e. product manager) the ability to shape the roadmap of a product used by customers. Opportunities to evangelize the usage of a product. A huge variety in day to day work and experiences.
cons: The company's divisions are only incentivized for their own particular offerings. Thus if a division takes business away from another division it is rewarded. This meant a lot of internal competition and bad behavior -- even if it made IBM look bad in front of a customer. . Also constant management changes meant a lack of consistency.
advice_to_mgmt: Reward collaboration with other groups. Do not constantly re-organize.

years_at_company: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Lot of ways to grow
cons: Your PeM should be good
advice_to_mgmt: Salaries has to be revised with the economics of the place and individual. Respect the one who is with you for a long term than to hire a new one

years_at_company: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Colleague are great to work with and we try to hale one another due to lack of management assistance. You can expand your knowledge in various areas since there is a wealth of education in most topics.
cons: Sr management is absent in the GTS project management division when dealing with the clients I work with. I cannot speak for the other divisions or clients. They will say one thing and never follow through. Not sure how anything get done on time and on budget.
advice_to_mgmt: A poll should be taken of what the project and program managers feel about management and their involvement when their assistance is needed.

review_title: It's what you make of it
years_at_company: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Tools and methods are modernizing rapidly, pay is getting better, respectful and helpful culture, wealth of resources to tap into for learning and mentorship, long hours are not mandatory to get by but can only help you
cons: No stock for non-execs, execs are a little out of touch, product managers cannot make up their minds and stick to something most of the time. When they do, it can be wildly successful because of IBM's resources and people. But too often, it is too little too late.

years_at_company: I have been working at IBM full-time for less than a year

if you want to feel like a number.

There is a general culture of APATHY here. If you want to work where no one cares, work here.

review_title: Don't come here. This company is dying. Key people are filing out the door. They are downsizing.

review_title: Not bad if you don't mind corporate politics and churn
years_at_company: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
broad latitude to work with the technologies that interest me
- plenty of opportunity for self-improvement
- relatively low stress/pressure
cons:
frequent directional pivots due to internal politicking and reactionism
- difficult to get promoted even when deserved
- a lot of the work I'm given doesn't seem that valuable to the company
advice_to_mgmt: Focus on empowering your best people and give them time to succeed. I see a lot of frankly incompetent middle managers making objectively poor decisions for political reasons, while the best technical and thought leaders spin their wheels waiting for clear requirements.

review_title: Over-all great group of people to work with
years_at_company: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Products are competitive with ongoing innovation. Some managers are good and some are not. Giant company with tons of job options. IBM tends to take a long term view of employee performance, so this can cover for the ups and downs of quarterly fluctuations
cons: Environment can be political. Because of the matrix style organization, many managers are interested in a given opportunity - therefore, lots of coordination and inspection calls

years_at_company: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 5 years

years_at_company: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 8 years

cons: Many functions are very siloed and the communication from the various channels become sensory overload. The number of meetings make it impossible to get your work done during a normal 8 or 10 hour workday.

years_at_company: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 8 years

years_at_company: I worked at IBM

review_title: AML jobs in Denver are not really with IBM - don't be fooled!
years_at_company: I worked at IBM full-time for more than a year
pros: Access to IBM continuing ed online modules. Okay place to hang out while you look for something better.
cons: The AML jobs available in Denver are with an IBM subsidiary called Promontory Risk Review that IBM acquired a few years ago. Promontory is a horribly run company that runs an AML white collar sweatshop with a call center environment. If you've always wanted to work in close proximity to 60-80 other people of varying degrees of professionalism, this is for you! No career development, no raises or performance based bonuses (everyone gets the same bonus), and no possibility of moving up in the organization.
advice_to_mgmt: They have no intention of improving anything, so I won't bother with advice.

years_at_company: I worked at IBM full-time for more than a year

advice_to_mgmt: Listen to what the customer want out of the products you sell.

review_title: Great Company but Colocation is a challenge
years_at_company: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
pros: You are surrounded by some incredible minds and diverse talent. There is a great emphasis on personal and professional development.
cons: A lot of politics, and often times a lack of unity. Constant re-orgs and colocation policies have resulted in losing some great people.

review_title: Most generous way I could describe it is "adequate
years_at_company: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than a year
pros: They are hiring a lot of younger folks, which is good news for new grads. They have a number of decent long term projects and as long as you're getting your work done you have good job security.
cons: They underpay, hard. They are not competitive especially at the entry level. Older, long time employees have benefits that new employees can't even get anymore (smaller PTO ceiling, etc). Generally the government contracts are working with outdated technology or in house stuff that nobody outside would have even heard of because nobody else uses it since there are popular, well functioning alternatives is basically everything. Raises are done on a schedule and are incredibly difficult to negotiate.

employee_status: Digital Sales Specialist in Dallas, TX

review_title: A fun workplace full of smart people
years_at_company: I worked at HP Inc. full-time for more than 5 years
pros: The people are fun to work with. The work is interesting for a mechanical engineer. If you are early to mid career, there are many experienced people who can help you to become a much better engineer.

review_title: A good company. Not a great company
years_at_company: I worked at HP Inc. full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
Open to flexible/remote employment (but less so now than in the past)
Not a dog-eat-dog environment.
Ethical and cares about hearing the voice of the worker.
cons:
No stock unless you're a manger - does nothing to retain top talent.
Stingy company. Squeak when you walk budgets. Even travel is rare.
They always want to hear your voice, but nothing ever seems to change.
advice_to_mgmt: HP is a slave to its high margin Supplies business and they have been unwilling to disrupt it - even a little. They have been so slow and unwilling to disrupt it that they would not budget properly to sell printers. And what happens when you don't sell low margin printers today? Yes, you guessed it. You don't sell high margin supplies tomorrow. And now those chickens have come home to roost. Layoffs of 7k-9k employees most likely on the print side coming in the next couple of years. HP has lost its way by hanging on to the old way of doing things. They don't innovate nor do they do what it takes to retain top talent. Fresh young talent is not offered stock. Get those golden handcuffs out, HP. Make it rewarding to stay and hard to leave. But without stock, anyone can be tempted to leave for nothing more than extra pay because we don't have to give up anything to go. By giving stock to everyone you will make it a lot harder to leave. These things should be obvious but only make HP look cheap. That's why HP is nothing more than a good company, not a great company.

advice_to_mgmt: Break rules. Run your organizations like a small business - focus the org and the team on your core purpose - and remember you have many customers.

review_title: Good people, stagnant thinking, uncompetitive salary and benefits
years_at_company: I have been working at HP Inc. full-time for more than 5 years
pros: It’s surprising when you run into some very sharp people working at a stagnant legacy tech company, but really, there are very good people to work with at HP.
cons: For a company that has focused on essentially 2 things forever, it’s unsurprising that change is hard. However, with all the profit printing cartridges have rung up over the years, HP management and CTO really failed to ever invest in the “next business.” 3D print may become a good business over time, but it cannot be the only business. For a company that has the muscle and makeup for building hardware, HP has been inept at acquiring or home-growing any growth businesses.
advice_to_mgmt:
You have to make some calculated bets. 2D print is not going to return the same revenue and profit over the next 10+ years that it used to. Acquire a complementary hardware company in a growth area - is it a POS company, a media streaming company, an IOT play... I don’t know, but I’m hoping you do. Whatever you do, don’t go for anymore value plays - I.e., a company on the decline - palm was a garbage buy, Samsung laser printer business was mediocre. Be bold, be creative, let’s gamble now while we still have the chips rather than just die a slow death by 1000 tiny cuts.

Also, you really need to take a hard look at your management. People unwilling to change, stuck on the old ways, wanting to play it safe, cut them. Complacency is a slow-growing but fatal cancer that will kill a company. HP still has time, but that window is closing. Changing business structures isn’t addressing the issues, it is just kicking the can down the road.

review_title: You’ll be just another cog in the gargantuan HP machine
years_at_company: I worked at HP Inc.
pros:
1. People. Coworkers were almost always great. 

2. Flexibility of work schedule. WFH and flexibility in working hours was great. 

3. Pay. I’ve yet to get a job that pays me even 64% if what I made at HP. 

4. Benefits Package. (PTO + insurance + retirement)

5. Company-provided equipment. (Laptops, monitors, etc) 

6. Empathy and compassion from management (depending upon your individual manager) if something tragic or traumatic happens. After the death of a parent, my boss let me take four weeks of paid bereavement leave that didn’t come out of my PTO balance.
cons:
1. The culture created by management. You’re just a cog in the gargantuan HP machine. HP cares not about your hopes and dreams or your career advancement. Even if you push hard for something like mentorship, which is something they promote, your requests will likely be ignored or pushed aside. 

2. Adherence to the bottom line creates job instability for employees. Sudden and unexpected layoff occur. I was “let go” and given fake reasons why. What it came down to was that I was laid off without HP calling it a lay-off so they didn’t have to report it, which would have been detrimental to the stock price. 

3. If you get laid off or let go, you won’t see it coming. I had a one-on-one scheduled with my manager. As we were walking to find a conference room, we chatted like it was any other day. Just chitchat. Then we walked into a conference room in a different building and he immediately hit me with the news I was being let go. When I questioned why, he gave me a made up reason related to my performance. When I challenged him and told me he was incorrect, he fumbled over his words and gave me a different reason that was equally made up. 

4. Lack of interaction with management. In the nearly five years I worked at HP, I can probably count on two hands the number of times I had real interaction (something beyond chitchat) with the two different managers for whom I worked. 

5. Also, if you accept a severance package, as I did, you will never be eligible for rehire. EVER. After working for HP for 4 years and just shy of 11 months, my severance package was a half a month’s pay, but no one ever told me I’d never be able to come back and my severance paperwork never indicated as much, either. 

6. Favoritism. This is definitely a problem. My first manager took the words of another person I worked with as the God’s honest truth when that person blamed me for a mistake she made. My manager never even asked me if I knew anything about the problem created by this other person. She just automatically assumed the problem arose because of me. I was told “you set us back weeks” after this other person mucked up some data she was analyzing for a new metric. This other person had asked me to look at the data and run a test, which I did exactly as she asked me to. I ran the test on literally 100 rows out of 100,000 rows for approximately 15 minutes and didn’t save anything. My second manager played favorites and I felt as if I had been “left behind” (for lack of a better term) while the other new hires I worked with were brought along much more quickly than I was. The other two new people on the team were given special treatment and paid special attention that I wasn’t. It helped if you were an athlete of some kind or if you liked mountain biking. That helped you “fit in” with the little clique created by my manager. Apparently I didn’t “fit in” because I didn’t join them on their mountain biking trek or their whitewater rafting trip one summer.
advice_to_mgmt: Shift a lot of your focus from stakeholders to employees. You’ll be more successful in the long run. Open the lines of communication and help employees achieve success.

years_at_company: I worked at HP Inc. full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Great Team, Great Environment, Good lead generation
cons: Tended to have troubles figuring out commissions and career advancement outside our doors seemed to be difficult

years_at_company: I worked at HP Inc. full-time for more than 10 years
pros: It's not one company. It's like a 1000 companies rolled into 1. It's a great place to learn if you grow from one business unit to another, from one role to another. You cannot run out of things to learn.
cons: It's luck driven. If you are lucky to have good management, everything is great. If you have the bad luck to report under a bad management - good luck. Pressure is high especially when the external environment is bad - this leads to bad executive managers showing their lack of understanding of the business. Bad decisions then lead to very bad things happening for the business, for the employees, and then finally themselves. HP used to pride itself for paying amongst the leaders, no more. Previous hits like the audio oscillator, calc, hp3000, inkjet, laser, etc... will not drive the company into the future. The recent breakup into HP Inc, HPE, and DXC... not sure if that is smart. The HP way has been flushed down the toilet in recent years, especially in Asia.

years_at_company: I have been working at HP Inc. full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Great work - life balance, great benefits, opportunity to move around.
cons: Large company with convoluted messages from management.
advice_to_mgmt: Be clear about business strategy.

review_title: Great Culture, not much upward mobility
years_at_company: I worked at HP Inc. full-time for more than 5 years
pros: eCommerce had a cooperative and caring culture
cons: Not much upward mobility. A lot of leadership positions came from outside.

years_at_company: I have been working at HP Inc. full-time for more than 10 years
pros: 401K match, volunteering opportunities, work life balance is okay - at times no work and sometimes it gets crazy with urgent issues.
cons: No snacks or drinks, no cups to drink water, free coffee that sucks, bad cafeteria, lack of motivation since they are slowly shifting everything to Houston and Taipei. Biased management - they will have parties on other site but ignore Palo Alto. Salary hikes are joke (1%-2%), bonus mostly 3%, if company does well (which is rare) then 5%. Minimum internal promotions/growth - they just hire people from outside to be managers, lots of layoffs every cycle. Extremely negative environment to work in - all my friends slowly got laid off with no replacement.
advice_to_mgmt: Bay area is the birth place of HP. Please try to preserve it. Value your loyal employees who have worked years for you, instead of laying them off with poor severance package and benefits.

years_at_company: I worked at HP Inc. full-time for less than a year
pros: Great pay and nice place to work, everyone I worked with on the floor for the most part was great.
cons: Be careful of management. They don't care if you have health issues. They will let you go even if you have a doctors note
advice_to_mgmt: Try to be more understanding if your employees have health issues.

review_title: Amazing people in an overly political environment
years_at_company: I worked at HP Inc. full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Brilliant people, decent benefits, work from home availability, supposedly flexible work hours though that hinges entirely on how "old school" your manager is. This is a really great place to go if you are NOT a starting engineer, as they have little interest in developing talent and new engineers are the first on the chopping block.
cons: Toxic workplace created by management, incredibly political, all decisions lead by out of date engineers that are brilliant but unwilling to take in new or updated technology.
advice_to_mgmt: Piling work onto older, experienced engineers and not giving younger engineers a chance to develop is a reoccurring problem. Many lower level managers don't think much of the "HP Way" and punish their teams for having flexible hours, despite what upper management says. Many of them also like to offer internships with no plans to hire in the future.

years_at_company: I worked at HP Inc. full-time
pros: good work environment and culture
cons: not so great opportunities for career growth

review_title: Disorganized, intellectually deficient, and cheap company
years_at_company: I have been working at HP Inc. full-time for more than a year
pros: Free trips, food, and other perks
cons:
It appears other than the bright folks that are working on developing new products for HP, the regular employees especially the middle management and above are the most pathetic folks I have ever met. Their fixation is on the wrong things to cover their inept and inadequate leadership skills in running a firm in one of the most competitive industry. All levels of the management structure are highly hierarchical, simply content with taking from support staff (or individual contributors) without even showing any level of appreciation.

The dribble they masquerade as a strategy is nothing but fluffy good feeling hogwash that hide the lack of substance that underlies a firm that is serious about competition and creating value for stakeholders.
advice_to_mgmt: If you have a choice to work elsewhere please do so.

review_title: Proud to be a member of this Outstanding Organization
years_at_company: I have been working at HP Inc. full-time for more than 3 years

cons: Too many great opportunities to have enough time to fit it all in!!

review_title: Solid values, good people, fair compensation and benefits
years_at_company: I worked at HP Inc. full-time for more than 8 years

cons: A little slow in industry, red tape

years_at_company: I have been working at HP Inc. full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great flexibility on work schedule!
cons: Somewhat limited opportunities for growth.

review_title: The right priorities, healthy culture, strong leadership
years_at_company: I have been working at HP Inc. full-time for more than a year
pros:
HP is full of tremendously talented people who are genuinely committed to each other's growth and success. It's a culture that puts people first and leads with integrity, humility, and empathy. 
-The work is meaningful and just the right level of challenging. 
-Frequent constructive feedback on performance. Growth mindset is taking hold across the organization, emphasizing the importance of continuous growth, taking risks, and figuring stuff out. 
-Employees are recognized and rewarded not only for what we do, but how we do it. Getting results is important, but not at the expense of our core values or business priorities. 
-Boundless opportunities to stretch into new areas, take on new responsibilities, and explore potential career paths. 
-The executive leadership team is clear about expectations, shares information with transparency, holds themselves accountable for results, and works to make sure employees have what they need to be successful. 
-Companywide commitment to sustainability, diversity & inclusion, and learning & development is inspiring and demonstrates that HP wants to be more than a financially successful enterprise. It's a company with purpose and a heart out to improve lives and communities.
cons:
Strong bias toward collaboration can gum up the decision-making process. 
-Some senior managers focus too much on managing tactical details rather than ensuring alignment with strategic vision and goals.
advice_to_mgmt:
Identify and retain our strong talent. 
-Recruit and hire the next generation of technical gurus. Maintain HP's emphasis on meaningful innovation. 
-Strongly encourage and empower faster decision-making among employees beneath middle to upper management.

years_at_company: I have been working at HP Inc. full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Amazing people. Strong leadership. Great culture. Ability to innovate and realize your career goals. Leaders are humble and gracious. Focus on the customer.
cons: Like all companies, I’m sure there are downsides. Fortunately, I work in an environment that encourages you to talk about those downsides and works to resolve.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you are doing.

years_at_company: I have been working at HP Inc. full-time for more than 10 years
pros: HP pays attention to the market and trends in employee experience and customer needs. The company is forward-thinking and we're happy to have 5 generations in the workforce. Diversity of employees is valued and highly leveraged to make it a great place to work and so we can deliver the best to our customers. Dion is an excellent and vibrant leader!
cons: None that I can think of at the moment.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep going in the direction we're currently headed.

review_title: Great place to learn and grow
years_at_company: I have been working at HP Inc. full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Quality of leaders and managers; Expertise and collaboration with my colleagues; Culture that makes me proud to work here; Meaningful work and a commitment to have a positive impact on Sustainability.
cons: Agility and adaptability is sometimes hindered by lack of process and tools. We could do so much more if we got serious about creating processes and infrastructure that enable agility and future-proof the business.

review_title: A company that's truly reinventing itself

Proud of the technology, diversity, and sustainability consciousness of HP as well. Great community volunteer opportunities throughout the year. Winning culture! The tech and mindset of the people here is outstanding, and have much to contribute to society. Very honored to be part of this innovative company that has much to offer to people, inside and out. I highly recommend HP.
cons: Only con was how long it took me to find and get into HP!

years_at_company: I have been working at HP Inc. full-time

review_title: Strong culture, incredible people, and tremendous growth opportunities
years_at_company: I have been working at HP Inc. full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Our culture evokes a sense of community and belonging in a fun, supportive, and connected environment. You can get involved in a variety of activities outside your core role and build your network beyond the people you work with on a regular basis. The work is challenging and meaningful. You are encouraged to think creatively and to be innovative--ask questions, challenge the status quo, take some risks, and explore the possibilities. Career and personal growth is available through formal and informal development programs, coaching and mentoring, on-the-job learning, and stretch assignments. I enjoy partnering with people around the world. Leadership is inspired at every level. I've been here more than 10 years, and I've never been more proud of who we are as a company. I can't imagine working anywhere else.
cons: Depending on your role, there can be a high volume of work so you must be able to think of work and life in an integrated way.
